IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Visualizing and quantifying tissue and cellular pathologies are central to understanding the pathogenesis, progression and complications of metabolic disease and related disorders, and to monitor the effectiveness of treatment. The Advanced Tissue Pathology and Imaging (ATPI) Core of the NIH-funded Columbia Diabetes Research Center provides investigators with access to confocal microscopy that is essential for their research. This application proposes to replace an aging system and to enhance the capabilities of the ATPI to meet new and growing demands for confocal microscopy with the purchase of a Zeiss LSM 900 with Airyscan 2.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative:  EZHIP-mediated PRC2 inhibition globally reduces H3K27me3 levels in cells and underlies PFA ependymoma, an epigenetically driven tumor primarily found in children. The overall goal of this search is to study a newly identified molecular mechanism, which specifically disrupts the EZHIP–PRC2 complex and thereby reshapes the unique epigenetic and metabolic pathways associated with PFA ependymoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The Pediatric Oncology Career Development Program at St. Jude is designed to provide protected time for early career faculty to conduct patient-oriented research focused on cancers in children and adolescents and engage in career development programming to facilitate transition to successful careers as independent clinical investigators. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in understanding and preventing health care problems faced by cancer survivors, little has changed in the delivery of survivorship care. With the lack of a planned and formal transition of the cancer survivor from the cancer care to the primary care team, non-cancer-related comorbidities are poorly managed. The proposed study aims to use a multi-level intervention including patient and PCP strategies to optimize the management of CVD comorbidities during and after cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Overall section) The CPH-NEW Total Worker Health® (TWH) Center of Excellence will conduct research and outreach activities to advance worker safety, health, and well-being using participatory worker-centered methods that engage workers in organizational decision-making to advance worker well-being. Research projects focus on the well-being, work-life balance, and organizational support of teachers; novel implementation strategies for health and safety promotion among healthcare workers; and the crisis preparedness of small- and medium- sized enterprises. The Center will also translate research to produce evidence-based workplace tools and integrated programs that can be used to promote health and well-being for all working people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: OVERALL - PROJECT NARRATIVE The programs of the SCERC impact occupational health and safety in three ways: Our graduates contribute directly to worker safety and health through their employment as professionals in the field and many go on to assume leadership positions in business and various state and federal agencies. Our research contributes to longer term improvements in worker health through improved understanding of workplace exposures, health effects, and their control. Our Outreach and Continuing Education Programs facilitate the translation of research results into actual occupational and public health and safety practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Neutrophils protect against infection but also contribute to tissue injury in diseases such as inflammatory arthritis and vasculitis. We show that two related neutrophil surface proteins, Ly6G in mice and CD177 in humans, alter integrin-dependent neutrophil migration and distinguish distinct neutrophil subphenotypes. We test the possibility that these Ly6-family molecules provide unique insight into neutrophil function and heterogeneity in a manner that may expose opportunities for safe therapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Vascular calcification and stiffness are hallmarks of diabetic vascular disorder, a prevalent cardiovascular complication in the Veteran's population that leads to increased morbidity and mortality. Disrupted circadian clock is a common issue in military personnel, which affects many of our Veterans. The proposal will establish a novel paradigm underlying circadian regulation of O-GlcNAcylation-mediated signaling in diabetic vascular calcification. The mechanistic insights learned from this proposal can not only advance our understanding of the basic mechanisms governing pathogenesis of diabetic vascular calcification, but also provide molecular insights into the development of novel strategy or drugs for prevention and therapy of these diabetic complications.

PHR: NARRATIVE  The proposal requests partial support for the 14th through the 18th Annual Meetings of the Organization for the Study of Sex Differences (OSSD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is relevant to public health because it develops artificial intelligence–driven tools to generate descriptions for online videos, making them accessible to blind and low vision individuals . PHR: Project Narrative At least two years of mentorship and training in research approaches and techniques are absolutely essential as graduates of dermatology training programs or PhD programs transition from student to independent biomedical scientists. The Harvard Dermatology Training grant provides this support, partnering the most promising trainees with accomplished and supportive research mentors who will sponsor their work in their laboratories. We wish to continue to build on the extraordinary success that this program has achieved over the last 45 years, in training the best and the brightest biomedical scientists of tomorrow.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE This program will investigate the role of secondary and tertiary RiboNucleic Acid (RNA) structure in controlling gene expression. We will use experimental data to compute models of how disease-causing genetic variants alter the precursor and mature messenger RNA structures. These models will discover and validate novel mechanisms by which RNA structure change causes human genetic disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Learning, memory and cognition are all dependent on communication between neuronal cells within the brain. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is a leading cause of permanent vision loss in the United States and worldwide where the only treatment is to lower intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP is largely governed by how aqueous humor (the fluid in the eye) exits through drainage pathways; and recent discoveries have uncovered that aqueous humor outflow (AHO) is not static and unchanging but instead shows previously unappreciated behaviors such as dynamic variable outflow (DVO): including dynamic, segmental, and rescuable characteristics. Specifically, in this proposal we work to 1) discover the regulation of DVO and study how glaucoma 2) surgeries and 3) pharmacological drugs alter or are impacted by DVO in different parts of the eye as a way to improve current treatments and help innovate future ones.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of control eating is a key feature of many eating disorders, and loss of control in general is pervasive in psychiatric disease, demanding an improved understanding of its physiology. Pathophysiological understanding of loss of control eating is limited to preclinical and neuroimaging evidence of dysfunctional corticolimbic and striatal circuits, however, invasive animal studies are yet to be confirmed in humans and neuroimaging methods lack the spatiotemporal resolution to inform new treatments. For the first time in the field, we will use exquisite tools to invasively probe aspects of loss of control eating (i.e. anticipation of palatable food, cravings, etc) in subjects implanted with depth electrodes in the nucleus accumbens attached to an intracranial deep brain stimulation device capable of sensing to pave the path forward more refined, understanding of the neuroanatomy and physiologic underpinnings of loss of control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Achieving tolerance remains the most important goal in transplantation. The significance of the current proposal is that it will define the function and mechanisms of specialized stromal cells and stromal structures in the lymph node that determine transplantation tolerance, and how they determine the choice between immunity versus tolerance. The findings from these investigations will have general applicability to other areas of immunology such as infection, vaccination, and autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Narrative The COPII vesicle pathway, the focus of this grant, is essential for normal cellular function. It is essential for secretion of hormones and antibodies, and is subverted for the assembly of viruses including HIV. Le- sions in genes encoding components of this pathway cause a variety of human diseases. The fundamental research in this Project may ultimately help to guide development of therapeutics to treat viral infections and genetic lesions that cause COPII-associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to endocrine disrupting chemicals such as phthalates contributes to increased rates of human infertility and reproductive disorders worldwide. The proposed research will fill a public health need by developing a method to investigate the mechanisms through which endocrine disrupting chemicals such as phthalates act to cause toxicity in the ovary. The results of this project will facilitate the development of safer alternative chemicals and contribute to the identification of new treatments to protect the ovary from environmental chemical exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: In cardiac ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury, approximately 50% of cell death is due to reperfusion injury, for which there are no standard clinical therapies. This proposal will study the importance of two biological processes using specific FDA approved medicines to induce autophagy and PGC1-mediated mitochondrial biogenesis during reperfusion injury. This study may lead to a new therapy for heart attack patients that results in less heart damage and a better quality of life for these patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevance Squamous cell carcinoma arising in chronic wounds is the leading cause of death in patients with recessive dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa. This project aims to elucidate the mechanisms underlying cancer initiation in these patients by interrogation of HMGB1, a protein involved in both inflammation and genome maintenance. The results from this study will provide a foundation for new drug targets in this fragile patient population and will shed new light on carcinogenesis in the broader context of inflammatory disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation plays both protective and damaging roles in Alzheimer's disease (AD), so to identify a long lasting and effective treatment, it is critical that we better understand the underlying processes. Our studies implicate a cytokine called interleukin-18 (IL-18) as a factor that accelerates AD pathology. Here we propose to uncover the mechanisms by which this cytokine alters basic cell biological functions and how these changes affect AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Current vestibular rehabilitation only addresses impairments and does not include targets that contribute to low activity and participation in people with vestibulopathy. It is unclear whether reductions in vestibular impairment translate to improvement in activity and participation and, if so, through what mechanisms or predisposing factors. This project will use input from stakeholders (patients with vestibulopathy and the physical therapists who provide vestibular rehabilitation care) to iteratively refine an enhanced vestibular rehabilitation that aims to improve activity and participation and augment current vestibular rehabilitation.

PHR: Project Narrative The COVID-19 pandemic shredded safety nets in the child welfare system; it made evident to providers, administrators, and policymakers how fragile our child protective system is. In-home services, a critical source of support for families, were quickly replaced with telehealth services. This study addresses the effectiveness and acceptability of delivery of an evidence-based home-visiting program to families in the child protective system with children under the age of 18 months at enrollment using telehealth methodology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The neuroscience training mission of BU resonates with a shared belief that major discoveries relevant to public health will come from innovative thinking and an interdisciplinary community of faculty and students. An essential feature is a set of core courses that are taken by all students in the Graduate Program for Neuroscience, which is aimed at developing a community of thinkers, who move through their training together, building relationships that cross inter- departmental and inter-campus barriers, and foster cross disciplinary collaborations. Every effort is expended to provide an individually tailored mentorship and educational program for each student with an emphasis on rigor and reproducibility that builds upon their unique strengths and interests, while also recognizing areas that need enrichment via faculty guidance and curriculum choice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: Project Narrative: Polysaccharides such as cellulose hold great promise for tissue repair and regeneration, but overcoming barriers to their full clinical potential will require developing and testing new innovative composites. Our proposal aims to address issues of adaptability, strength, and degradability by designing and evaluating a cellulose-based putty- enabling platform with tunable degradation, broad bioactive factor release properties, and appropriate mechanical strength for bone healing. This work is expected to enhance our understanding of cellulose and its utility as a biomaterial for tissue repair by evaluating its effects on cell behaviors and bone regeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to provide new evidence on the causal relationship between income and health and the mechanisms underlying this relationship by evaluating a large-scale unconditional cash transfer program that randomly assigns participants to a treatment group that receives $1,000 per month for 3 years or a control group that receives $50 per month. To estimate the causal effect of the additional income on health, we will examine treatment/control differences in physical and mental health outcomes and intermediate outcomes, such as physical activity, nutrition, neighborhood characteristics, and medical care access and utilization, that could affect longer-term health outcomes. Our study will provide new, timely, and policy-relevant evidence on the health implications of income support and the causal mechanisms underlying the relationship between income and health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic technologies promise to transform our understandings of human biology and history and offer unprecedented power to influence the health of individuals and generations. Such knowledge and power imply immense responsibility to use them in ways that promote social and ethical values in the service of the public’s health. This research training program aims to nurture a diverse cadre of interdisciplinary scholars prepared to engage critically and respectfully with, and advance our knowledge and understanding of, the profound ethical, legal and social (ELSI) challenges that genomic technologies raise.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Balanced immunity in the gastrointestinal tract is essential to health, and imbalance contributes to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), cancer, allergic, and metabolic disorders. Our studies identify new mechanisms and cells and their roles in establishing the gut immune system to protect newborn babies against viruses and bacterial infections, and to prevent inflammatory bowel disease, allergic and infectious diseases in adults. The results will improve our understanding of a healthy mucosal immune system, and could provoke novel preventative, therapeutic treatment strategies or cures for these infectious and inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sound-sensing cells in the human inner ear are vulnerable to damage, resulting in permanent hearing loss. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a major health crisis with no approved therapeutics and many failures in the clinic. A vascularized patient-derived liver acinus microphysiology system (vLAMPS) is an innovative precision medicine platform for optimizing clinical trial design for NAFLD. We will test the response of induced pluripotent stem cell-derived liver cells from NAFLD patients in vLAMPS with either the high-risk variant PNPLA3 I148M or the wild-type to the drugs (pioglitozone, Obeticholic acid and two controls).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study aims to develop, implement and evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a mobile, integrated PrEP intervention that delivers on-site PrEP and peer navigation to increase the engagement of people who inject drugs in the PrEP continuum. The intervention will be delivered to the target population through a stepped wedge cluster randomized trial and outcomes will be evaluated through a prospective cohort and qualitative interviews. The study will lay the foundation for the implementation of initiatives targeting these populations in other locales to simultaneously address the pressing public health challenges conferred by HIV, COVID-19 and opioid use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The molecular and cellular cargo that escapes the intestinal mucosa has the potential to spread inflammatory signals or infections, but how the intestine is poised to sort such cargo between blood and lymph to minimize negative host outcomes in unknown. This application has assembled a multi-disciplinary, multi-institutional team that incorporates state-of-the-art multi-omics, intravital imaging, surgical prowess, and unique experimental models to define the molecular cargo traversing lymph versus venous blood from different regions of the gut and determine how these drainage sites are equipped to combat spread of inflammation. The resources, skills, and approaches of this group may be of broad interest to the mucosal immunology community in general, as much of the cargo draining other mucosal surfaces also remains undefined.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinal cord injury is a severely debilitating event that profoundly impacts quality of life, yet there are limited effective treatment options for the patient beyond rehabilitation. The proposed research will determine how removal of the adhesion receptor, L-selectin, affects the behavior of the most abundant immune cell type (neutrophils) in the acutely injured spinal cord and subsequent long-term recovery. This work will elucidate the role of neutrophils in acute tissue damage, determine how L-selectin regulates neutrophil behavior, and advance a novel therapeutic strategy that enhances L-selectin removal from the surface of neutrophils.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE The Center for Transformative Community-driven Research to Prevent Obesity-related Cancer (the Center) seeks to reduce cancer risk, and ultimately improve cancer outcomes for communities experiencing persistent poverty. The Center will include five cores: Administrative, Research and Methods, Career Enhancement, Developmental and Engagement Core. The Center will test interventions in the context of MD Anderson’s current place-based cancer prevention initiative (Be Well Communities™), around two scientific themes: 1) understanding social and environmental context of poverty (e.g., food insecurity, limited recreational infrastructure, few health promotion services) and 2) promoting health behavior changes of diet and physical activity as major contributing causes of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative The human papillomavirus (HPV) therapeutic vaccine being developed is likely to become a first-line therapy for high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (precursors of cervical cancer). This is particularly important for women who wish to have children because the standard surgical treatments have the unintended side effect of doubling the incidence of preterm delivery. In addition, the vaccine is being tested for the ability to reduce recurrence rates of head and neck cancers, and it may be used to prevent or treat other cancers caused by HPV, including anal, penile, vaginal, and vulvar cancers.

PHR: Physical activity has been shown to improve cancer survivors’ well-being and is associated with longer survival after cancer diagnosis. This project will test a program to help cancer survivors from Acres Homes increase their physical activity and access physical activity resources in their community. We will also identify how the survivors’ neighborhood environment affects their physical activity levels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence indicates that environmental exposure to pyrethroids, such as deltamethrin, at no-observed-adverse- effect level (NOAEL), increases the risk of neurodevelopmental disorders in the general population. Through an interdisciplinary approach that includes state-of-the-art confocal and mass-spectrometry imaging, electrophysiology, behavioral studies and viral vector-based chemogenetic manipulation in rodent models of early-life exposure to deltamethrin, we will provide a mechanistic model of neurotoxicity of pyrethroids in the developing brain. These studies will provide novel insights to evaluate the risk of neurodevelopmental disorders in the context of environmental toxin exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Modulation of the pupil by light is important for regulating visual sensitivity and acuity, serves as a standard neurological test, and is increasingly used to gain insight into affective disorders, metabolic disorders, and neurodegenerative diseases. The pupillary light response appears simple but is multifaceted, with properties and underlying mechanisms that are enigmatic. We will address this gap in knowledge to provide a deeper understanding of how the nervous system produces motor output according to environmental cues, and to help improve the use of pupillary responses in clinical diagnoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly all adolescents use social media sites, yet for a vulnerable subset of teens, social media use may increase risk for suicide. Given rising suicide rates among adolescent girls in recent years, it is critical to examine the reasons why social media use may be related to suicidal thoughts and attempts. Findings of this study will have the potential to inform future suicide intervention and prevention efforts that address the unique needs of adolescents in the digital age.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals who develop glaucoma before age 40 (early-onset glaucoma) have few treatment options and are most likely to become blind during their lifetimes. Only ten genes are known to cause this condition and these only account for 20% of cases leaving most patients without a molecular diagnosis. The overall goal of this proposal is to discover novel early-onset glaucoma causal genes that will provide opportunities for gene-based screening and diagnostic tests, allowing for improved risk prediction and genetic counseling, as well as new, and potentially curative, therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: The Acres Homes region in Houston, TX, is a predominantly African American and Hispanic community, a persistent poverty area with 69% of the residents living in food desert areas, and over 40% of the adult residents reportedly being obese. Ours is a cluster-randomized trial to assess the impact of Brighter Bites (BB), a school-based intervention improving access to fresh produce and nutrition education, on obesity and metabolic outcomes among children enrolled across 12 elementary schools serving the Acres Homes community and their parents. This project informs the translation and scaling efforts of BB, a highly successful natural experiment, and also advances dissemination and implementation science by studying and improving upon implementation strategies to increase program reach and impact in persistent poverty areas such as Acres Homes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Accurate and rigorous analysis of all visible axonal fibers (with and without signs of acute axonal injury) in 2D and 3D microscopy images of central nervous system (CNS) tissue of non-transgenic and transgenic animal models as well as in human postmortem CNS tissue holds the promise of enabling novel insights into physiological neural network connectivity patterns as well as into the neuropathological underpinnings of alterations in connectivity associated with human neurodevelopmental, neuropsychiatric, neurodegenerative and neurological disorders. Our proposed product will be a transformative technology, using a number of technical innovations that, for the first time, will enable researchers to perform such studies automatically and in a comprehensive manner. This system will allow researchers to make new discoveries based on new studies that are currently not feasible, ultimately providing the basis for developing novel treatments to prevent and fight complex brain diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This Genotype-Phenotype project involves the largest known cohort of older adults with fragile X-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS), one of the leading single-gene forms of neurodegeneration. By following these individuals over time, we hope to understand the natural history of FXTAS in multiple clinical and molecular domains, with a focus on better understanding why females progress faster than males in pain and psychiatric domains but more slowly in the motor and neurocognitive domains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The risk and burden of HIV are not evenly distributed anywhere in the world including in the most broadly generalized HIV epidemic settings. Characterizing the heterogeneity in susceptibility and infectivity across populations is fundamentally important to understanding the dynamics of HIV transmission and in turn, effectively measuring the population-level impact of specifically addressing the needs of those at highest risk. We have letters of support from governments, implementing partners, UNAIDS, the Global Fund and academic partners because we have proposed an ambitious, but achievable set of aims to empirically evaluate strategies to reevaluate HIV risk distribution to inform a more empiric, and ultimately, more effective HIV pandemic response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: The field of cancer prevention and control has grown, however, the cadre of trained and experienced researchers dedicated to cancer prevention in underserved communities grappling with persistent poverty, particularly those trained for multidisciplinary collaboration, remains too small to sufficiently advance the state of the art in cancer prevention and control. Our overall goal is to train early career investigators in the US to join a cadre of scholars who are able and purposefully lead key research efforts in multiple aspects of cancer prevention and control/population science. Long-term success in such career paths requires skills in career navigation, resilience, and career persistence that can be fostered through formal training, mentorship by assigned mentors, and role models that will be part of the Career Enhancement Core (CEC) and throughout the proposed Center for Transformative Community Driven Research to Prevent Obesity-related Cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative: Physician-scientists have repeatedly made critical contributions to our understanding of human health and disease that have had an outsized impact on patient and population level health. However, current clinical training programs have made the physician-scientist career path less and less accessible. This program seeks to restore the pipeline of physician-scientists focused on disorders of infection, immunity and inflammation by creating a new program that integrates clinical and scientific training in a vocationally structured manner.

PHR: The Developmental Core is designed to (1) encourage collaborations among researchers across funded centers and within the Persistent Poverty Initiative Network; (2) encourage horizontal collaborations among scientists and community partners within and outside the center to identify new, potentially fundable research opportunities, or to address emerging questions from the latest developments in the field; (3) engage new or established scientists whose specific expertise and skill set complement those of Center scientists, with emphasis on recruiting underrepresented minorities; and (4) identify and maintain a pipeline of pilot projects that may grow into full projects to accelerate generation of knowledge on effective interventions for reducing risk and suffering from cancer in the context of persistent poverty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE With prevalence of dementia expected to double in the next few decades, novel insight into these diseases is desperately needed. The proposed study is a structure-driven and targeted probe into multiple key aspects of the dementia-causing tauopathies, aimed at the elucidation of fundamental mechanisms mediating tau aggregation, polymorphism, and tau tracer affinity. The insight gained from this work will be vital in future design of aggregation inhibitor therapies and positron emission tomography tracers specific for individual tauopathies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gain-of-function mutations in activators of the complement system have been defined in rare genetic disorders and lead to increased inflammation and tissue damage. We propose here that engineering these mutant proteins to target specific cells or tissues will provide a new approach to driving and regulating localized complement activation and inflammation. In this application, we will generate proteins capable of directing complement activation to cancer cells with great immunotherapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: The Engagement Core within the Center for Transformative Community-driven Research to Prevent Obesity-related Cancer (the Center) emphasizes the vital role of active stakeholder engagement in accelerating research participation and achieving impactful outcomes. By focusing on communities affected by persistent poverty and building on established trust foundations, such as the Be Well Communities model in Acres Homes, the core aims to foster deeper community-academic relationships. The Center's initiatives include: (1) Leveraging our Be Well Acres Homes steering committee as the Center community advisory board; (2) Enhancing community-engaged research capacities; (3) Providing experiential service-learning experiences for trainees and investigators; (4) Promoting effective messaging to engage the Acres Homes community in cancer prevention research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE Vitiligo is an autoimmune disease of the skin that causes disfiguring white spots, with significant impact on those with darker skin. We will leverage existing data that we have already generated directly from the skin of vitiligo patients, a multidisciplinary team of leading investigators, cutting edge, translational tools designed for discovery, and an innovative strategy to discover how skin cells coordinate autoimmunity during vitiligo. This will support the development of advanced new treatment approaches for vitiligo and similar autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) is a major health problem in the United States that affects nearly 5.7 million Americans. Compelling evidence suggests that defects in mitochondrial function are implicated in HF development, however, how cardiomyocyte mitochondrial-derived stress impacts cardiac contractile function, metabolism and electrophysiology remains incompletely understood. This project will employ an innovative luminoptogenetic technology to specifically manipulate cardiomyocyte mitochondria in intact hearts to delineate the role of mitochondrial dysfunction in the pathophysiology of HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Given the gravity of the HIV epidemic in the South and globally and the new DHHS initiative that proposes to end the US HIV epidemic in the next 10 years, fostering the next generation of translational HIV scientists across the HIV research continuum is of utmost importance. To accomplish this, we propose a new HIV T32 training program for post-doctoral fellows at Emory University. Post-doctoral trainees will emerge from our T32 program ready for scientific independence and with a deep understanding of how their research fits into the multidirectional and multidisciplinary framework of HIV research with the long-term goal of ending the HIV epidemic.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Emory CFAR will contribute to ending the HIV epidemic by accelerating the highest caliber translational research — fostering team science, equity, and multidirectional stakeholder engagement. We will strive to build community trust in research through the intentional inclusion of key stakeholders at all stages of the research pipeline. We will achieve our goals by providing innovative services, tools, expertise, and access to state-of- the-art equipment through an Administrative Core, a Developmental Core, five Science Cores (Biostatistics and Bioinformatics; Clinical Research; Prevention and Implementation Sciences; Systems Immunology; and Virology and Molecular Biomarkers); and two Scientific Working Groups (SWGs) - Health Equity and Next Generation Therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall project goal is to address the critical need for self-care strategies to improve the physical and psychological health of older family care partners caring for patients with heart failure. This proposed study is relevant to public health because older family care partners often experience high caregiving burden that results in physical function decline, psychological distress, sleep disturbance, and poor health status. Implementation of this project's tailored physical activity coaching program, which uses integrated digital health technologies, will have the potential to support self-management and enhance the health and well-being of aging family care partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Two photon miniaturized microscopy can be used to record the activity of axons, dendrites, or cells located in deep tissue in freely behaving animals. In this proposal, we propose to develop open-source 2-photon miniaturized microscopes with enlarged field-of-view and volumetric imaging capability. We will disseminate these tools to the neuroscience community to drive new research directions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project investigates physiologic interactions between bone and adipose tissue during the response to two signals that stimulate new bone formation. Our hypothesis predicts that adipose tissue lipolysis induced by intermittent parathyroid hormone administration or exercise supplies fatty acids necessary to fuel bone formation by osteoblasts. Completion of this work may ultimately lead to the development of novel approaches for the treatment of both osteopenia and metabolic dysfunction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to develop physician-scientists through integrating rigorous scientific investigation and compassionate clinical training through our multi-institutional MD/PhD program. We enable training of a diverse national trainee pool in a wide variety of fields from engineering and biomedical devices, systems neuroscience, immunotherapy to development of novel therapeutics and discovery of molecular basis for disease. Trainees supported by this grant will become the future biomedical physician-scientists who will work towards increasing our understanding of fundamental pathogenesis of disease and cutting-edge approaches to treat patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Mutations in the proteasome shuttle factor UBQLN2 cause ALS-FTD in humans, and the mechanism of disease is not known. I discovered that UBQLN2 regulates the abundance of a poorly understood, proteolytically active and nucleic acid-binding protein PEG10, which is elevated in spinal cords of ALS patients. Here, we propose to deeply examine the (1) abundance and activity of PEG10 in disease, the (2) precise contribution of PEG10 to disease in vitro and in vivo, and (3) the molecular rules governing UBQLN2’s facilitated degradation of PEG10.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social interactions between animals and between humans can be explained quite well when the costs and benefits of specific actions are taken into consideration, but the genetic and neuronal mechanisms driving these types of context-dependent behavioral choices remain poorly characterized. Using the Drosophila fruit fly, we aim to determine the genes, neurons, and neural circuits that modulate behavior in response to two conditions that affect the perceived payoff of a fight: 1) social defeat, which increases perceived risk, and 2) nutritional deficits, which increase potential benefit. Similarities between flies and humans regarding the genes involved in social behaviors make it highly likely that results from this project will provide a foundation for understanding how genetic variation, especially those associated with neuronal disorders, can influence decision-making processes during human interactions.

PROJECT_TITLE: Genetic factors controlling the intensity of social behavior

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to continue our efforts as part of a consortium for large-scale production and phenotyping of knockout mice. The generation of mutant alleles and broad-based, systematic phenotyping will reveal gene contribution to mammalian biology and define new functions and pathways underlying the mechanisms of disease. All mouse lines and their phenotyping will be publicly released as they become available.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inappropriate action of neutrophils is often associated with severe complications of pneumonia. Neutrophils actively change the genes and proteins they produce as they travel to the lungs during infection. Our proposed study will examine how the changes in genes produced affects the way neutrophils function in pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project is a multicenter, randomized, double-masked, placebo-controlled clinical trial designed to test the hypothesis that oxidative damage is a major contributor to cone cell death in retinitis pigmentosa (RP) and that long-term oral N-acetylcysteine will promote cone survival and prevent severe visual disability in RP. It has the potential to provide a treatment that can slow visual function loss and that applies to all patients with RP regardless of the causative mutation. It will also answer the scientific questions that to what extent does oxidative damage contribute to cone cell death in RP and is it a target for the development of additional treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human development depends greatly on the shaping and movements of individual cells. Congenital syndromes, cancer, and other cell diseases occur when there is a breakdown in the regulation of the behaviors of specific cells. We will use the small, transparent embryos of Ciona, one of the invertebrates most closely related to humans, to better understand which genes are activated to regulate such behaviors during neural development, and how cell behavior goes awry when these genes are missing or defective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: OVERALL PROGRAM NARRATIVE The apolipoprotein E4 allele is the major genetic risk factor for late-onset AD; however, currently there is no consensus on how different apoE genotypes contribute to the pathogenesis of AD. The interrela ted studies proposed in the four cores and three projects of this P01 are anticipated to enhance our understanding of the differential effects of apoE isotypes on AD pathogenesis and accelerate the discovery of effective therapeutic approaches that address these diverse roles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Public Health Impact: Opioid Use Disorder (OUD) has emerged as a major US public health crisis, with over 2 million adults afflicted. The ED is a healthcare location where patients with OUD can be identified, evidence- based care initiated and treatment linkages proactively solidified. The systematic testing of the ED-LINC intervention, supported by the EDIE health information exchange platform, can begin to provide a critical evidence base that will enable emergency departments to better address the opioid epidemic.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project relevance  Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an environmental bacterium that is a leading cause of hospital acquired infections. This grant seeks to understand how this bacterium responds to rapidly changing environments, which may lead to new therapeutic approaches to treat human infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ideal antibacterial and hemocompatible surface would prevent bacterial biofilm formation as well as platelet adhesion and activation. This research project will develop and evaluate a catheter hub disinfection device designed using the synergistic effects of a photoinitiated S-nitrosothiol based nitric oxide (NO) release polymer that can provide continuous therapeutic NO levels at the catheter interface. These materials and devices will be studied for their prevention of microbial infection and platelet activation/adhesion, thereby solving major clinical problems of thrombosis and infection associated with long-term intravascular catheter devices.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: One of the most problematic and least understood aspect of myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), the most common muscular dystrophy in adults and children, is the heart problems in DM1, which are a leading cause of sudden death in patients. We will use a mouse model of RNA toxicity in DM1 to study its effect on the heart. Our goals are: 1) characterize and understand the drivers of this pathology in the heart, and 2) study the heart’s response to potential treatments under development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will harmonize genomic data from >2.6 million individuals to create large and diverse maps of structural rearrangements in the genome and use novel statistical methods to determine which genomic regions are intolerant to such alterations. It will then apply these new methods, measures of intolerance, and variants discovered from new technologies to genomic data from almost 400,000 cases with a diverse range of neuropsychiatric conditions to better disentangle the influence of genetic variation on these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project studies a new pathway that links p16 to outcome in head and neck cancer independent of HPV status via repression of homologous recombination. Tumors with activation of this pathway signaling are sensitive to radiation and PARP inhibition, while tumors that do not have this pathway activated can be treated with drugs currently in clinical development that specifically inhibit ubiquitin-specific protease 7 (USP7) to make them sensitive to both treatments. This project will lead to an ability to predict which head and neck cancer patients will respond to current therapy and which will benefit from the addition of USP7 inhibition to their treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulated cholesterol metabolism is associated with Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) pathology but the outcomes of these alterations and which cell types are responsible for them are still unclear. Astrocytes, non-neuronal glial cells that regulate neuronal function, are the main producers of brain cholesterol and are also affected in AD. The proposed project will investigate how cholesterol synthesis, trafficking, and secretion is altered in AD astrocytes and will identify potential targets for treatment of AD and other age-related neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Adeno associated virus (AAV) vectors can be used to deliver broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) against human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) to prevent transmission in animal models, making them promising candidates for HIV prevention. In this proposal, we will determine how the immune system interacts with next-generation bNAbs to prevent HIV transmission. This work will deepen our understanding of the immune protection from HIV and yield new AAV vectors that deliver bNAbs engineered for maximal preventative efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The small intestine has a crypt-villus structure that not only digests and absorbs nutrients, but also serves as a barrier to infections from the outside world. To maintain these functions throughout a lifetime and repair damaged intestinal tissue, crypts regenerate by dividing in a process called fission, and if this process goes awry, diseases like Crohn’s disease or Ulcerative Colitis can arise. To better understand crypt fission and its importance in intestinal tissue regeneration, we will develop an in vitro intestinal organoid model to study the dynamics of crypt formation and fission during injury and repair.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease is difficult to study due to its heterogeneity and lack of integration between molecular and clinical datasets. This research proposal aims to enable precision medicine approaches for Alzheimer’s Disease by utilizing integrative networks on a large set of clinical data to identify potential clinical and molecular associations. Ultimately, this project will facilitate the identification of hypotheses for disease mechanisms underlying heterogeneous clinical manifestations, providing a step towards improved patient stratification and personalized treatment approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative  Influenza (flu) infection is a leading cause of respiratory disease and death worldwide, causing 3-5 million cases of severe illness and more than 250,000 deaths during an average flu season, in which severe influenza diseases are accompanied by an aggressive pro-inflammatory response and an insufficient anti- inflammatory immunity. The production of the immunosuppressive cytokine IL-10 by effector T cells is critical in limiting the immunopathology during flu infection, however, our understanding of how this immunomodulatory event is regulated is very limited. The proposed research will define the biomarkers of regulatory CD8+ T cells, as well as transcriptional mechanisms how these cells develop and function, which will generate key information to help facilitate our understanding and enhance ability of modulating immune regulation to limit immunopathology, morbidity and mortality during flu infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative During cell division, each daughter cell must inherit exactly one copy of each chromosome as errors can lead to cancer and birth defects. Two large cellular machines are responsible for segregating chromosomes: the spindle and kinetochore. Here we probe how these machines’ building blocks together give rise to their function, aiming to uncover the mechanical design principles driving chromosome segregation and to ultimately better target dividing cells for therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) show decreased motivation to engage in social interactions that are less rewarding for them. Yet, the neural populations that mediate social reward and how activity is altered in these regions in models of ASD are not understood. Here, using new imaging tools, we will examine how the activity patterns of nucleus accumbens neurons and their inputs are altered in two models of ASD and whether real-time modulation of activity in these neurons can increase social interaction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Establishing and maintaining cell polarity is essential for cell function and tissue integrity, whereas the disruption of cell polarity is often linked to tumorigenesis and injury under ischemia. In this proposal, we focus on a novel mechanism based on the newly discovered electrostatic interaction between polarity proteins and plasma membrane (PM) phosphoinositides. Electrostatic PM targeting acts as an integral mechanism that not only regulates the subcellular localization of polarity proteins, but also directly controls their polarity functions. Our research will facilitate the analysis and treatment of diseases such as ischemia and cancer by understanding how polarity may be established, maintained, and restored under normal and pathological conditions, including hypoxia, ischemia, and tumorigenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic inflammatory disease with clear contribution of so-called Toll- like receptors (TLR); however, the mechanism how these receptors contribute to disease is incompletely understood. Based on detailed biochemical studies, we found a novel mechanism (pathway) how TLRs activate genes that are known to drive SLE. In this project, we will further study this pathway on a molecular level and establish its relevance for human SLE by using sophisticated novel mouse models, hopefully revealing a key mechanism that controls SLE as potential therapeutic target.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol abuse and consumption are associated with cognitive impairments, and the development of dementia. Alcohol consumption impairs lysosomal and mitochondrial biogenesis results in insufficient autophagy, accumulation of damaged mitochondrial and tau protein aggregates, and promoting Alzheimer's disease (AD). Elucidating the molecular mechanisms of how activation of transcription factor EB improves lysosomal biogenesis and autophagy that are impaired by alcohol will help to develop novel therapeutic strategies for treating/preventing AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative ME/CFS is a debilitating and complex disorder that affects millions of people worldwide; however, the underlying mechanisms that trigger ME/CFS symptoms and their treatment remain unknown. To better understand the causes and discover better diagnostics and treatments to improve the health outcomes for individuals with ME/CFS, RTI’s DMCC will continue to support this Network by (1) offering expertise in patient- centered research, data processing, and analysis; (2) providing tools to foster communication and monitor study progress; and (3) expanding the capabilities and reach of our publicly available ME/CFS research tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The aim of this project is to investigate a role of cyclophilin D-mediated mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP) in Tau pathology and mitochondrial stress, leading to neurodegeneration and cognitive decline relevant to the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease. The outcomes of the proposed studies would also support that CypD might be a potential new therapeutic agent for eliminating and limiting Tau pathology and Toxic tau species accumulation and restoring mitochondrial and synaptic function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will carry out basic research into the causes of Alzheimer disease (AD), specifically those forms of AD that are not attributable to specific genetic causes. We will use a novel animal model that expresses the human form of a protein known as the amyloid ß-protein (Aß), which is strongly implicated in the disease, to test the extent to which transient increases in the levels of Aß—either all forms of Aß or exclusively extracellular or intracellular forms—induced at different ages are sufficient to trigger AD-like pathology in old age. Because increases in Aß are a common consequence of several AD risk factors, this work is expected to improve our understanding of the origins of AD, and may lead to the development of innovative therapies and/or improved methods for the early detection of this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite achieving remission, up to 30% of patients with Crohn’s disease (CD) or ulcerative colitis (UC) will relapse over the subsequent 3 years. The mechanisms of sustained remission have not been defined. We propose a targeted effort that comprehensively and longitudinally profiles a homogeneous cohort of patients in deep remission to define the dynamic perturbations resulting in the inception of inflammation in quiescent disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Florida International University will establish a new Training program in Environmental Neuroscience (TENS) to support high-quality training of pre- and post-doctoral students in the unique and emerging field on neuroscience related to the environmental determinants of both neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases. As an Institution serving Hispanic and Underrepresented Minority groups, with a proven record of recruiting, retaining and graduating students in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics), we will provide a fully inclusive environment for the students to develop innovative technical and professional skills to approach the increasing neurological impacts related to the environment, which is increasingly affecting underserved minorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance The relevance of the project to public health is that it deals with host immune responses and inflammation during Toxoplasma gondii infection. This parasite is classified as a class B biodefense pathogen that can cause life-threatening disease in immunocompromised populations and in congenital infection. The project may ultimately identify new targets to treat disease and to improve immunity to microbial infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the leading global cause of cancer-related mortality. For patients with advanced lung cancer harboring ALK gene fusions (‘ALK+ lung cancer’), highly effective ALK inhibitors have improved their outcomes, and yet, acquired resistance to these drugs remains a major problem resulting in disease relapse and ultimately death. The goal of this research is to identify therapeutic strategies to overcome resistance to the current standard-of-care ALK inhibitors, in hopes to extend and improve lives of patients living with this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: AMERICAN SOCIETY FOR BONE & MINERAL RES
PHR: This application seeks funding for a three year R13 grant to advance the field of musculoskeletal diseases by focusing on three specific areas of scientific research: 1) “Rare Diseases: From Molecules and Mechanisms to Therapeutics”; 2) “Osteocytes in Bone Health and Disease and as Therapeutic Target Cells”; 3) “Energy Metabolism in Skeletal Development and Disease”. These three areas cover a range of topics that collectively contribute to major clinical morbidity, disability and mortality. The overall objective of this R13 is to stimulate further advances that will result in improved patient care for musculoskeletal diseases by bringing together the best researchers for each of the three symposia that will be held in conjunction with the Annual Meetings of the American Society for Bone and Mineral Research, the largest professional, scientific and medical society established to bring together clinical and laboratory-based scientists who are involved in the study of bone, mineral and musculoskeletal science.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stabilized HIV-1 envelope trimer vaccines such as BG505 SOSIP elicit strong neutralizing antibody responses that protect against the matched virus in nonhuman primates. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This is a renewal application for a successful training program supporting predoctoral and postdoctoral trainees in research on cardiovascular disease at the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center. Cardiopulmonary diseases, including heart disease, stroke and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, continue to be the leading causes of death in the U.S., and disproportionately affect medically underserved populations. This training program aims to prepare highly skilled scientists from diverse backgrounds underrepresented in the field of cardiovascular and pulmonary research to reduce the future health impact of these diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This training program is motivated by the fact that mental disorders are among the leading causes of disability in the world, and improved strategies to reduce their burden are needed. The goal of this training program is to produce the next generation of psychiatric epidemiologists who can address this need by conducting research that will advance our understanding of the causes and consequences of mental disorders, and developing, implementing, and evaluating rationally designed interventions to prevent and/or control these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: LAY NARRATIVE Inconsistent and unpredictable treatment outcomes across individuals are reported in most neuropsychiatric conditions and highlight a major challenge in mental health care. We propose to use a measure of systems- level brain activity and machine learning to determine if information within brain activity could be used to implement individualized interventions in a pre-clinical model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Long-range cell-to-cell communication is vital to all multicellular organisms during development and in maintaining homeostasis. Recent discoveries suggest that cells can communicate precisely and reliably via long, thin cellular protrusions. Our research has revealed such a process in zebrafish development that also requires the involvement of macrophages as signaling intermediaries. Studies proposed here will reveal underlying molecular mechanisms of cellular protrusion-mediated signaling and interrogate whether such signaling is generally utilized in other cell types.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the structure and function of auditory cortex is critical for a complete understanding of the human auditory system, yet a consistent and accurate approach to parcellating even the primary auditory region A1 has not been established. This project takes a state-of-the-art, multimodal approach to characterizing A1, by combining ultra-high-field (7T) magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) anatomical data at an unprecedented resolution (0.35 mm3) with task-based and resting-state functional measures of auditory cortical processing. This comprehensive research will expand our understanding of auditory cortical processing in normal-hearing individuals, aid in the standardization of auditory cortex characterizations in future studies, and help inform the development of effective treatment options for various auditory processing deficits, such as those rooted in central auditory processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  In the proposed research we will examine the mechanisms by which memantine, one of the few drugs approved for treatment of Alzheimer's disease, protects nerve cells from damage. We will study how memantine works physiologically, use computer modeling and medicinal chemistry to design and synthesize new neuroprotective drugs, and use the new drugs to deepen understanding of neuroprotective strategies. The proposed research will examine a new approach for developing therapeutic drugs and will produce lead compounds for future development of improved medications to treat Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narratives/Relevance  The EXPLORER total-body PET scanner has limitations due to its poor timing resolution and lack of DOI-encoding, both of which offset its effective sensitivity gain, specially for imaging single organs, despite the very costly improvement of its geometric coverage. In the proposed work we will develop cost-effective and practical single-ended TOF-DOI-Compton PET detector modules, where these capabilities are enabled by using our novel right an-gle prism mirror light guides which enhance (1) light sharing by efficient 180-degree bending of photon paths and (2) crystal identification by localiz-ing the shared photons to only those immediate neighboring pixels that help with the correct identification. Our Prism-PET scanner with < 120 ps timing resolution, 1.85 mm DOI-encoding, and 88% Compton-scatter recovery miti-gates the limitations with the EXPLORER total-body scanner and achieves unparalleled spatial resolution and sensitivity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The serotonergic (5-HT) and dopaminergic neuromodulatory systems have both been implicated in aggression, yet the specific cell types and circuitry involved remain unknown. This project will study a dopamine (DA)- responsive serotonergic neuron subtype involved in the modulation of aggression and acoustic startle reactivity in mice and will inform on the functional interplay between 5-HT and DA in the modulation of behavior. Understanding the circuit structure of this 5-HT neuron subtype may inform better therapeutics for the treatment of escalated aggression and/or altered startle reactivity, which can occur in neuropsychiatric disorders such as intermittent explosive disorder, schizophrenia, autism, and post-traumatic stress disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis is the most common autoimmune joint disease worldwide where fortunately over 15 treatments are available, however finding the most effective treatment for a patient remains a trial-and-error approach. This proposal is directly in line with NIAMS’ strategic plan to use machine learning to define personalized medicine profiles through the integration of electronic health records. In this study, we apply state-of-the-art approaches such as semi-supervised machine learning and inference modeling to maximize the data obtained from an RA clinical trial, RA registries, and EHR data towards more efficiently matching RA patients with treatments that will work for them.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Poor postpartum health has implications for maternal mortality and infant outcomes. However, eligibility for pregnancy-related Medicaid ends after 60 days postpartum, leading to high rates of postpartum insurance loss. The proposed project evaluates how the Medicaid continuous coverage requirement during the public health emergency affected postpartum coverage, care, and infant care overall, by maternal race-ethnicity, and during various periods of the COVID-19 pandemic context, with implications for state postpartum Medicaid extensions under the American Rescue Plan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Gene expression changes that occur during postnatal development, and how these are regulated by genetic variation and through epigenetic mechanisms, remains largely unknown in humans. As the Laboratory, Data Analysis, and Coordinating Center for the Developmental Genotype-Tissue Expression Project, we will characterize multiple human tissues across developmental stages using single cell and spatial sequencing technologies to map spatiotemporal changes in gene expression across tissues and development. We will integrate these results with RNA sequencing data from ~3,600 tissue samples, from 120 postnatal post-mortem donors, to identify genetic regulatory effects that are specific to development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Polyomaviruses (PyVs) cause debilitating human diseases, including the often-fatal Merkel cell skin carcinoma. How these small DNA viruses transport to the nuclear membrane and then into the nucleus, where genome replication leads to infection and transformation, is not well understood. This innovative study aims to elucidate the nuclear entry mechanisms of two distinct PyVs and the role of host motor proteins in this process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The neural mechanisms of regulation support socioemotional competence and may operate as resilience factors in the face of risk for psychopathology. The current proposal will examine how local and global neural markers of regulation develop in infancy, and how these trajectories are potentially influenced by (1) infant and maternal risk for psychopathology and (2) dyadic patterns in the mother-infant relationship. The current proposal also presents a direction for expanding this research in the postdoc phase, by integrating simultaneous assessments of neurocognitive mechanisms in mothers and children in relation to the socialization of regulation and psychopathology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research plan will provide a link between enhancer-promoter interactions and the contributions of transcription factor binding to the regulation of gene expression. Robust descriptions of these events, in fixed and live cells of the differentiating Drosophila embryo and ovary, will give insight into the inner workings not only of eukaryotic cells generally, but also into the still poorly understood role of regulatory DNA and chromatin architecture relating to dysplasia and diseases; mutations in non-coding loci have been repeatedly implicated in their occurrence. Because many genes, pathways and regulatory mechanisms are shared between Drosophila and higher organisms, improved understanding of how complex loci are coordinated in flies is likely to inform new approaches to understand these phenomena in wild-type as well as developmental- and disease-relevant human contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The ability to navigate complex environments and engage in effective goal-directed planned behaviors is a core human trait. The lack of spatial planning abilities results in debilitating capacities to negotiate known and novel environments and is associated with a variety of neurological disorders. Thus, understanding the neural computations that can support this behavior can help reveal the underlying causes of certain major neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury (AKI) is a common complication in post-surgical patients, and it significantly decreases patient quality of life and leads to increased rates of death. The proposed research in this grant application is relevant to public health because it seeks to understand the cellular mechanism of a novel kidney protective therapeutic that could be given prior to surgery or kidney transplantation to protect the kidney from injury. Thus, this proposal fulfills both aspects of the NIH's mission: to seek fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems and the application of that knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There has been a rapid increase in the use of highly concentrated THC liquids inhaled by cannabis consumers through vaping devices. This project will utilize a combination of observational, laboratory, and clinical trial designs to provide timely and novel data on THC doses and speed of delivery from liquid THC concentrates used with vaping devices. This project will provide important information that will be relevant for prevention and treatment of problematic cannabis use, and future regulation of vaped cannabis products.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Reoviridae viruses include important pathogens of humans and animals as well as oncolytic viruses that kill cancer cells without harming patients. The proposed studies will provide insight into fundamental mechanisms of viral genetic diversity that are mediated by the assembly and transmission processes of viruses in the Reoviridae family. The impact of this research on human health will come from application of these fundamental principles to the rational engineering of improved vaccines, oncolytics, and other virus-based therapeutics and to the identification of factors that predict outcomes of coinfection and transmission for pathogenic Reoviridae viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Several tiers of regulation ensure that genes are properly expressed in cells. Cap structures added to the beginnings of messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are critical for their regulation and represent one such mechanism. Cytoplasmic capping is an understudied process that returns a cap onto uncapped mRNAs and is likely another layer of the cell’s regulatory framework. This work’s goals are to determine how targets are generated for the cytoplasmic capping machinery, how that machinery recognizes mRNAs and the effects of cytoplasmic capping on cellular proteins in normal and stressed conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative While many consequences of college risky drinking affect the students themselves (e.g., hangovers, embarrassment), other problems such as impaired driving jeopardize public safety and must be addressed. Reports show: 1) college student drinkers experience disproportionally more problems, including increased impaired driving, than other age groups, and 2) although over 1.3 million drivers in the U.S. are arrested for impaired driving annually, they only represent 1% of the estimated 121 million self-reported episodes of impaired driving each year. In response, we embarked on a new endeavor and developed a brief intervention to reduce resistance and tailor parents' experiences to change their permissiveness toward allowing underage drinking, and in turn, reduce student risky drinking and consequences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glioblastoma ranks among the deadliest of all human cancers, with current therapies offering only palliation. In this research project, we will study a novel regulation of brain tumor cells that resemble stem cells and are often resistant to radiation and chemotherapy. Cellular metabolism and regulation have been reprogrammed by these brain tumor stem-like cells, revealing potential new treatments for patients afflicted with glioblastoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite being cured of their tuberculosis (TB), millions of TB survivors each year suffer from chronic lung damage. Unfortunately, the nature of this lung damage is not well understood, which limits our ability to care for patients suffering from chronic lung disease after TB. By characterizing the role of neutrophilic and profibrotic activity as risk factors for post-TB lung damage, this study will inform future treatment strategies to prevent or reduce this devastating complication of TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The tRNA cleavage pathway is an emerging mechanism of gene expression regulation based on the production of various tRNA-derived fragments. This mechanism is critical not only for survival under adverse conditions but also implicated in many human diseases such as cancer and neurodegenerative diseases. Here we propose to systematically characterize biogenesis, functions and molecular mechanisms of tRNA-derived molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Single-cell RNA-seq technologies have transformed the field of genomics and experiments are becoming widely used across both basic science and disease research. Yet, statistical methods and tools for analysis are exceedingly complex for non-experts and not adapted for more complex experimental designs. The proposed research programs will remove analytical barriers to analyzing scRNA-seq data and enable researchers to obtain deeper insights into their data by optimizing and streamlining their analyses without compromising on quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) affects almost 15% of Americans and greatly increases the risk of cardiovascular disease. This proposal will improve our understanding of how the cell cycle and metabolism in chronically injured tubules affects tubule function and the development of fibrosis. If successful, these studies may also reveal novel therapeutic targets for slowing the progression of CKD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: This project will further establish a novel and promising model of late-onset sporadic Alzheimer’s disease – the most common type – in vervet monkeys. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Chronic HIV is a serious medial problem for which there is no cure. The reservoir of HIV in the brain is a major challenge, causing high morbidity, and because drugs cannot cross the blood brain barrier, eradication of the virus is impossible. We propose a solution to this problem by intra-arterial transplantation of glial-restricted progenitors, engineered to express HIV neutralizing antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The present project aims to determine if there are sex differences in the neurobiological mechanisms underlying the formation of alcohol-associated memories or their modulation by acute stressors that mediate increased vulnerability to relapse in females. We will use a rodent model to determine if there are sex differences in 1) the amygdala-dependent plasticity that underlies alcohol-related learning, 2) the modulation of alcohol-associated neural ensembles by stress, or 3) the circuits activated by alcohol cues and stress, in order to identify potential targets for sex-specific treatment development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE The Yale Superfund Research and Training Program (YSRTP) is motivated by community-based concerns about emerging drinking water contaminants. The program will engage in problem-based, solution-oriented research related to 1,4-dioxane, an emerging water contaminant of particular concern because it is widespread and persistent in the environment, poorly regulated, has consistently shown carcinogenic effects, co-occurs with toxic chlorinated solvent contaminants (1,1,1-trichloroethane, 1,1-dichloroethane and 1,1,1-trichloroethylene), and is not mitigated using standard approaches. This proposal will address critical gaps in our understanding of cancer mechanisms, mixtures interactions, and detection and treatment technologies through innovative techniques that will inform risk assessment and regulatory standard-setting as well as help affected communities address health questions and remove this contaminant from water supplies.
