IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goals of this project are to identify molecular mechanisms involved in 1,4-dioxane (1,4-DX) liver carcinogenicity and to assess the capacity of co-occurring contaminants (TCE and 1,1-DCA) in modifying 1,4- DX carcinogenicity. We propose to examine the mechanistic roles of key redox pathways and biological network motifs in 1,4-DX-induced liver carcinogenesis and elucidate the carcinogenic potential of co-occurring contaminant mixtures. This research will establish the dose response for key perturbations that are associated with 1,4-DX liver carcinogenicity and reveal whether unique susceptibility factors may predispose to a greater risk of liver carcinogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A blood-brain barrier (BBB) comprised of multiple different cell types in and around blood vessels shields the brain but is unfortunately damaged in diseases such as stroke, causing bleeding, swelling and entry of potentially injurious substances. Our application examines how the GPR124/RECK/WNT7 pathway ensures normal BBB function and how drugs targeting this pathway can therapeutically stabilize the BBB to improve stroke treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The industrial chemical 1,4-dioxane has been identified as a drinking water contaminant throughout the United States and has been classified as a probable human carcinogen based on evidence from experimental animal studies. Human exposure and health impacts of 1,4-dioxane remain poorly understood in part because traditional techniques cannot detect low-level concentrations of 1,4-dioxane in biological samples or drinking water samples. To address the goals of the Superfund Research Program, our study will use a more sensitive approach to measure human exposure to 1,4-DX and its co-occurring contaminants, and assess links to early biological effects to determine the potential health impact for residents of Long Island, New York, an area with many Superfund sites potentially affected by 1,4-DX.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Groundwater often serves as a source for drinking water supply. Near Superfund sites, groundwater can be contaminated with a wide range of chemicals. Individuals exposed to these hazardous chemicals through contaminated drinking water can be subjected to adverse health effects. Because current analytical methods to detect hazardous chemicals involve expensive and time-consuming laboratory analyses, monitoring public exposure necessitates development of new, rapid, low cost approaches to measure water contaminants. Sensor technologies and wireless sensor networks embedded in drinking water systems can provide rapid on-site detection and monitoring of target contaminants, thus enhancing the safety of drinking water and protecting human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our overarching goal is to design, fabricate, test, and implement point-of-use small-scale water treatment units that can destroy 1,4-dioxane and its frequently co-occurring pollutants from contaminated ground water through advanced oxidation. Unlike any existing advanced oxidation processes, these reactors will not require continuous chemical supply and will use minimal energy. The prototype reactors will be tested both in the lab and in the field sites in Region 1 in collaboration with other project teams to verify the feasibility of real world use, to confirm the elimination of human toxicity, and to establish faster technology transfer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR:  Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer is the deadliest of the common cancers and one of commonest causes of cancer death. Detecting pancreatic cancer at an early stage greatly improves survival from pancreatic cancer. We propose to validate the diagnostic accuracy of a tumor marker gene blood test for pancreatic cancer early detection and use this test in a clinical trial to improve the early detection of pancreatic cancer for patients with an increased susceptibility to pancreatic cancer undergoing pancreatic screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acid-sensing ion channels, membrane proteins found throughout the brain and body, activate when extracellular pH becomes more acidic and this can lead to a host of cellular responses. Using cutting edge electrical and optical methods we are investigating how pH causes these channels to open and close, what movements they make and what other proteins they may interact with. Our results will provide important insights into the operation of these proteins, furthering basic research while potentially informing drug design and therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The uncertainty about risk and appropriate courses of action surrounding emerging contaminants in drinking water, such as 1,4-dioxane (1,4-DX), creates an atmosphere of confusion, blame, anxiety and mistrust in communities impacted by these issues. The focus of the Community Engagement Core (CEC) in the Yale Superfund Research and Training Program (YSRTP) is to address these challenges through facilitation of engagement and information exchange among diverse constituencies in two states currently impacted by 1,4- DX issues (i.e., New York and New Hampshire). The CEC will create opportunities for stakeholders – including residents, government agencies, community and educational organizations – to learn from each other, and by utilizing multilateral partnerships among the projects in the YSRTP, will strengthen relationships across stakeholder groups, foster educational opportunities, and promote active and sustained community engagement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative  This project aims to develop a rapid and robust quantitative magnetization transfer imaging method sensitive to early in vivo amyloid beta pathology in cognitively normal individuals. This innovation is enabled by the use of two key technologies: the hybrid spin-ensemble state and unrolled neural networks. Successful completion of this project will establish quantitative magnetization transfer as a viable technique for tracking Alzheimer's disease progression and monitor patient's responses to novel drug therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Identifying solutions for the treatment of microbial infections, aberrant immunological diseases, and other emerging global health problems requires combined expertise and collaboration among scientists. A better understanding of the mechanisms by which pathogens infect multicellular eukaryotic hosts and how hosts, in turn, defend themselves against pathogens is critical for developing new alternative strategies to manage microbial infections and better understand the function of the immune system. Real world solutions are possible by investing in the training of new investigators to become facile in thinking and working across multiple disciplines to solve complex problems related to microbial pathogenesis, immunity, and host defense.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal utilizes both human postmortem brain tissues and a preclinical model of rodent stress to study astrocyte plasticity and how it contributes to the pathophysiology of inflammation-related psychiatric disease, such as MDD, which is a high priority public health interest. The project aims to use single-nuclei resolution RNA- seq to characterize the functional changes in cellular maps and transcriptomes resulting from astrocyte-specific inflammation in the rodent orbitofrontal cortex, a brain structure critically involved in reward processing, motivation, and anhedonia. Examining the regulatory drivers of gene expression changes during astrocyte inflammation will help identify novel pharmacotherapeutic targets aimed at normalizing or reversing inflammation-induced neuroadaptations that underlie the pathophysiology of stress-related disorders, including MDD.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The use of genetically engineered (GE) pigs is critical for advancing both biomedical and agricultural applications but are underutilized, in part, due to the safety and efficacy of the technology, as well as, the time required to establish and propagate these models. Developing strategies that assist in preserving genome integrity and for rapid identification of phenotypes will allow for the rapid expansion of GE pig models. Increasing the availability of GE pig models will have clear impacts on preclinical models for gene therapy and quickly identifying pigs with improved agricultural traits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hantavirus disease is a form of zoonotic viral hemorrhagic fever (VHF) that results when humans inhale excreta from hantavirus-infected rodents, with case-fatality rates exceeding 40% for some hantaviruses. In its natural reservoir host, the brown rat, Seoul virus causes asymptomatic, lifelong infection, posing a persistent threat to humans worldwide due to the global rat distribution. The work proposed here leverages the genetic, immunological, and commercially available tools of the laboratory rat reservoir model to investigate the innate immune mechanisms driving differential disease outcomes in reservoir and non-reservoir hosts for hantavirus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Despite broad interest in understanding the biological implications of protein lipidation, how the structure of appended lipids regulates the conformation and function of disease-related lipidated proteins remains unclear. To close this gap, this MIRA program will elucidate the biophysical rules governing assembly, aggregation, and function of physicochemically diverse libraries of lipidated proteins, prepared from operationally simple, high- yield biosynthetic routes. These biophysical insights will contribute to a mechanistic understanding of the role of lipidated proteins in health and disease and facilitate the application of lipid-modification in the development of next-generation drug carriers, biomaterials, and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given the increasing burden of obesity, diabetes, and heart disease in the community, new methods are necessary to identify individuals who are at greatest risk of developing these conditions. For this purpose, we propose to measure small molecules in the blood (that reflect body metabolism) before and after a standardized meal challenge in a large community-based sample. Our results will clarify how intake of meals results in dissimilar patterns of small molecules in blood in different people and how these distinctive patterns may identify novel markers of heart disease and diabetes risk that may not be apparent with blood measures obtained in a fasting state.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety disorders are common in children and adolescents; however, up to 40% of pediatric patients fail to respond to the first-line antidepressant treatment. We hypothesize that pharmacogenetically-guided dosing of the antidepressant escitalopram will increase treatment response while decreasing medication side effects in adolescents with anxiety disorders. We believe that this study will inform clinicians, patients, parents, and payers whether pharmacogenetically-guided escitalopram dosing in pediatric anxiety disorders improves outcomes for anxious adolescents who need antidepressant medications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Using two different modalities capable of imaging intact tissue, we will identify spatial changes in metabolites and proteins during the progression of Alzheimer's disease. By comparing these changes in a vulnerable brain region with a resilient brain region and integrating data on location and morphology of various cell types in these brain regions, we aim to determine metabolic and protein signaling pathways contributing to cellular vulnerability in Alzheimer's disease. Outcomes from this study will provide insights into the mechanisms leading to neurodegeneration and reveal targets within pathways that could be protective in Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The United States Department of Agriculture has sponsored the Summer Food Service Program since 1975 to address the summertime nutritional gap experienced by children from low-income families. It provides meals to children, however, characteristics of the program providers and participants as well as the program’s impact on child health outcomes are not well-documented. The proposed project aims to address the research gap by identifying details about the program providers and users and assessing changes of children’s food insecurity, diet quality and weight gain accounting for the program usage, which will guide further program improvements and provide a venue for an innovative summer childhood obesity prevention program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: High risk prostate cancer (PCa) accounts for the vast majority of deaths from localized PCa, a very common disease, and is often treated with a “one-size-fits-all” strategy of radiation therapy (RT) and long-term androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). While this strategy optimally treats the 20% of patients who need long-term ADT for cure, it undertreats the 50% of men whose cancer will recur despite this therapy and needed treatment intensification, and overtreats the 30% of men who could have been cured by only very short-term ADT and could have avoided prolonged ADT side effects. There are no clinical-grade biomarkers that can differentiate these three groups prior to treatment, so we will develop and validate cost-effective biomarkers, for patients with high-risk PCa treated with RT, that can differentiate these groups and allow personalization of their systemic therapy to maximize their treatment response and minimize unnecessary toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The goal of my research program is to investigate mechanisms by which Gram-positive bacteria maintain translation fidelity and efficiency. We will determine how ribosome stalling impacts cellular physiology and proteome integrity, and how protein synthesis can be regulated by atypical translation events such as frameshifting and stop codon read-through. Knowledge gained from these studies will increase our understanding of essential ribosome rescue pathways and uncover new antibiotic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Our goal with this work is to identify the basis for the progressive white matter loss that characterizes aging, with a focus on the failure of remyelination by glial progenitor cells (hGPCs) that attends both aging and age-associated neurodegenerative disorders. We will do so by establishing human glial chimeric mice with embryonic stem cell-derived hGPCs that have been subjected to serial mitotic expansion in vitro before transplant, comparing the in vivo colonization and myelination competence of hGPCs of different ages, and as a function of time after neonatal engraftment; conversely, we will transplant young hESC GPCs into older adult brains, and compare their expansion and differentiation competence to that of aged hGPCs in the same grafts. We will then use RNA sequence analysis – both bulk and single cell - together with both ATAC-Seq determination of chromatin occupancy, and measures of DNA methylation state and telomeric length, to define the effect of aging on the transcription and epigenetic state of hGPCs in vivo, our goal being to define and target those age- associated repressors that may delimit hGPC competence, and by suppressing their expression, to restore the expansion and fate competence of aged human glial progenitor cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. Project Narrative Adolescence is an “age of risk” for the emergence of bipolar spectrum disorders (BSDs), a major public health problem. Using an innovative biobehavioral high-risk approach with a prospective, longitudinal design, this application will examine bidirectional relationships between circadian and reward function at multiple levels of analysis and their joint prediction of first onset of BSD and increases in hypomanic/manic and depressive symptoms. It will provide critical tools for identifying vulnerabilities for first onset of BSD, integrate two separate research traditions to increase our understanding of specific etiological pathways to BSD, and facilitate development of behavioral and biological interventions for ameliorating reward processing and circadian rhythm abnormalities that contribute to BSDs, and their lifelong negative consequences.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The microenvironment shapes cellular function and this process involves transmitting signals from extracellular cues to a specific set of response genes. Our goal is to understand how the factors that transmit signals and direct gene expression can initiate diverse, yet context-specific gene programs, thus yielding insights into dysregulated gene expression and disease susceptibility. This work is highly relevant to NIGMS’s mission of seeking fundamental understanding of biological processes to lay foundations for novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Excess consumption of ultra-processed (UP) foods (i.e., foods that are composed of mostly cheap industrial sources of dietary energy and nutrients plus additives) has strong biopsychobehavioral parallels with substance use disorders (SUD). Withdrawal is a core element of SUD and emerging evidence suggests that reducing UP food intake may result in symptoms of withdrawal for at-risk individuals, although this research is limited by a lack of prospective, experimental research. Better understanding whether reducing UP food consumption results in symptoms of withdrawal can contribute to the development of more effective interventions and inform the scientific debate about whether UP foods should be considered addictive.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall objective of this proposal is to collaboratively address dissemination and implementation gaps for PrEP care for cisgender women in Atlanta. Anchored in implementation science and community engagement, with a cross-sector clinic-academic-CBO collaboration, and innovatively blending the two through human centered design methods (HCD), we will a) prepare and evaluate tailored PrEP implementation strategies in Atlanta Title X clinics; b) use and evaluate an evidence-based community organizing approach to increase awareness and interest about PrEP and connection to PrEP care among women across Atlanta; and c) use innovative HCD methods to collaboratively engage community and Title X clinic sites to develop patient- centered, acceptable, and feasible PrEP care models for women. Given limited research pertaining to strategies to increase PrEP reach among cisgender women in the South, the findings from each of our aims will fill critical gaps and optimize clinic and community strategies to strengthen HIV prevention for women in the Southern US.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Child maltreatment is a significant public health issue affecting millions of youth and families every year. To date, there are no systematic training programs that address the need to expand child maltreatment science across the wide range of disciplines relevant to child maltreatment. The CMT32, using a transdisciplinary approach, will integrate training in child maltreatment across four tracks of training: biological embedding, developmental processes, prevention and treatment, and policy, administrative data systems to create pre and postdoc scholars who are fully equipped to contribute to the complex nature of child maltreatment science.
PROJECT_TERMS: next generation;Science
PROJECT_TITLE: Creating the Next Generation of Scholars in CM Science (CMT32)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: In this study, we will culture human PAX7::GFP+ skeletal muscle stem/progenitor cells on aligned, electrospun fibrin microfiber bundles to induce their fusion into myotubes and assembly into 3D skeletal muscle grafts. We will optimize the delivery of soluble and tethered agrin in combination with insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) to promote the growth and myogenic differentiation of PAX7::GFP+ cells. Subsequently, we will use skeletal muscle grafts engineered with and without soluble and tethered agrin/IGF-1 to promote neuromuscular regeneration and functional recovery in a murine model of volumetric muscle loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal is centered on the hypothesis that cardiac ischemia induces biosynthesis of a group of atypical, toxic sphingolipids that promote cardiomyocyte death. Our evidence indicates ischemia in humans and mouse models upregulates Sptlc3, a novel subunit of serine palmitoyltransferase (SPT), that shifts the substrate preference of SPT, leading to accumulation of atypical, toxic sphingolipids. We will explore whether cardiomyocyte-specific depletion of Sptlc3 attenuates cardiac pathology arising from acute and chronic ischemia in vivo, determine the mechanisms of Sptlc3 regulation, identify specific atypical sphingolipids produced, and determine the cell mechanism(s) by which Sptlc3 products induce apoptosis.

Our proposal addresses key issues that are directly related to therapeutic response and resistance in cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One limitation to fight off persistent viruses is the poor knowledge on the factors that could promote immunity in the context of the inhibitory environment that characterizes chronic viral infections. We have identified cytokine and microbiota positive effects on viral control in a murine model of persistent infection. We propose to study the mechanisms involved in order to best harness these factors to prevent or attenuate viral persistence.

PHR: The Penn Center for Musculoskeletal Disorders (PCMD) will continue to provide critical resources and programs to, and enhance research productivity of, investigators to address multidisciplinary research strategies for musculoskeletal problems. The overall goal of this Center is to promote cooperative interactions among investigators, accelerate and enrich the effectiveness and efficiency of ongoing research, foster new collaborations and new research, and ultimately, translate our research efforts into better and new therapies for musculoskeletal disorders. Our PCMD is the home for musculoskeletal research across the Penn campus and a hub for the musculoskeletal community across the region and neighboring states .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women suffer more from Alzheimer’s disease (AD) than men, as shown by higher levels of tau – one of the hallmark brain changes in AD. Because sex hormones represent potential underlying causes of such sex differences, here we aim to understand the role of testosterone – a major sex hormone existing in both sex – in female mice that develop tauopathy. Results from this project will provide a direct physiological link between a sex hormone and tau pathogenesis, and guide hormone-based therapies against AD for both sexes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Understanding changes in the brain that occur during the transition from adolescence to adulthood is critical for informing how major mental illness such as schizophrenia, mood disorders, substance use disorders, and others emerge at this time. Past studies, primarily in animals and in postmortem human brains, indicate a normative decrease of neural connections that is critical for refining brain communication and determining adult trajectories. We propose to use state of the art brain imaging and genetic approaches to delineate how the brain refines from adolescence to adulthood to support maturation of cognition, a critical first step for discerning what goes awry in psychopathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Our interdisciplinary team of engineers, data scientists, and clinicians are developing a wearable device that can analyze odors from the skin. Using data from this new wearable device, we will develop algorithms to detect and monitor a variety of diseases and conditions, including skin diseases/conditions (e.g., psoriasis), emergency diseases/conditions (e.g., stroke), pulmonary diseases/conditions (e.g., asthma), and pediatric diseases/conditions (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis). Because people will simply wear the small device, it can be used in a variety of settings like point-of-care, homes, and workplaces.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The accumulation of fat inside of podocytes, which are key cells of the kidney filter, is an important event that contributes to progression of kidney disease. With this application, we propose to investigate how deficiency of a protein named Apolipoprotein M (APOM) affects fat content and utilization in podocytes, contributes to the leakage of protein into the urine and we aim at understanding if patients with deficiency of APOM are at higher risk for the progression of kidney disease. The strength of this proposal lies in the innovative idea on how this protein modulates fat content in the kidney, how it can be utilized to identify patients at risk, and how replacement of the deficient protein can cure kidney disease in experimental models

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS MED BR GALVESTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) is a leading cause of respiratory illness for which no effective therapeutic or licensed vaccine are available. The proposed study would provide critical new understanding to the function of hypoxia inducible factors to the pathogenesis of viral respiratory infections. This has the potential to strengthen drug development against RSV infections and reduce the burden on infants, young children, and the elderly alike.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Drug dependence and addiction continue to constitute a major health and economic burden and our inadequate understanding of the underlying neurobiology limits better diagnostics and interventions. The proposed studies will investigate the role of neuromedin s (NMS) neurons in the ventral tegmental area in morphine responses. These data will provide rationale for design of specific NMS pharmacological reagents, offering the promise that insights gained in these studies could lead to improved treatment of addiction, a high interest priority of NIDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative People with sensorineural hearing loss face the most difficulty understanding speech in noisy backgrounds, with significant individual differences in this ability across people with the same degree of clinically defined hearing loss. This study synergizes expertise in animal and human auditory neuroscience in a coordinated cross-species experimental design that will characterize the effects of sensory, neural, and synaptic dysfunction on modulation coding and perception of signals in noise. Data will be harmonized in an open-source data-science framework to facilitate short-term advances in our understanding of the relations between individual differences in peripheral pathophysiology and real-world listening, and long-term advances in personalized audiology to target treatment and counseling to individual patients, which will ultimately lead to better hearing health, quality of life, and lower healthcare costs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Many medical device infections are caused by Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus), which are debilitating due to their chronicity and antibiotic tolerance. We will explore the possibility that rewiring the metabolism of granulocytic myeloid-derived suppressor cells, an immune population that is key in preventing biofilm clearance, will inhibit their immune suppressive effects and decrease S. aureus burden. A better understanding of how metabolism controls immune cell function will guide the development of future strategies for the treatment of S. aureus biofilm infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) for prostate cancer induces cognitive impairment that negatively impacts the quality of life for prostate cancer survivors, for which there is currently no treatment. We will study the neural mechanisms underlying this cognitive impairment to identify potential treatment targets using a rat model of prostate cancer in which ADT is produced by chemical castration. We will then test the utility of novel therapeutic candidates for treating cognitive impairment after ADT without interfering with the anti-cancer efficacy of ADT. The overall goal is to improve the quality of life for prostate cancer survivors and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narratives: Hearing loss is the most frequent sensory defect in humans and about one in 1,000 children is affected by severe deafness at birth or during early childhood. This grant proposes to systematically elucidate how a small group of progenitor cells are induced to become functional sensory neurons and hair cells in the inner ear. Identifying enhancers that mediate the activity of transcription factors and chromatin regulators to instruct sensory or neuronal-cell specific gene expression program should provide valuable insights into the genetic and epigenetic networks that underlie congenital neurosensory deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual violence (SV) is common among individuals with opioid use disorder (OUD) and confers risk for worse OUD-related clinical outcomes. Shame is a potential mechanism that may explain worse outcomes among individuals with OUD who have a history of SV, and the current study seeks to identify associations between event-level shame and short-term clinical outcomes (substance use, cravings, medication adherence, motivation, and self-efficacy for changing substance use) as well as associations between aggregate levels of shame and long-term clinical outcomes (treatment dropout, percentage of treatment appointments missed) among individuals in OUD treatment who report a history of SV. Improving our understanding of these associations will aid in the development of interventions to improve clinical outcomes among this high-risk population.

PHR: Public Health Relevance The Carolina Center for Population Aging and Health will support a productive group of scholars as they increase the pace and focus of their research on topics related to the demography and economics of aging. Faculty will conduct research and primary data collection in support of three themes: aging in diverse contexts, links between social and economic productivity and health, and measurement and methods. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adult hypertension is common, is a leading cause of death, and originates in childhood; pediatric hypertension is increasingly common, causes heart and kidney injury, and predicts hypertension in later adulthood. Poor treatment response occurs in half of children, increasing the risk of heart and kidney injury; the reasons behind this are not well known, limiting patient care of this important disease. The goal of this K23 Mentored Career Development Award is to obtain further training and initiate a mentored research project to establish a foundation of clinical evidence of angiotensin-(1-7) in pediatric hypertension and related injury to the heart and kidneys by identifying differences in disease progression and treatment response and informing causal mechanisms with ultimate goals to i) define novel causes of disease; ii) inform a targeted treatment strategy; and iii) inform development of novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research is relevant to public health because antibiotic resistant infections caused by Klebsiella aerogenes, Klebsiella oxytoca, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and P. aeruginosa were responsible for approximately $2 billion in attributable healthcare costs and over 12,000 deaths in 2017 alone. Nearly half of all patients who develop severe pneumonia caused by pathogens like these will experience antibiotic treatment failure and up to 30% will not survive. This proposal will advance the NIH mission to protect and improve patient health by addressing the urgent for new and effective treatment strategies that restore antibiotic activity against these serious pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The high rates of premature dropout in addiction treatment programs prevents clients with substance use disorders from receiving and fully benefiting from the wealth of evidence-based treatments available. While the assessment-based approach used during a client’s initial contact with a treatment program offers important information for regulatory agencies, gathering information rather than exploring client reasons for treatment may influence a client’s decision to return to treatment. This patient-oriented career development award will provide the candidate with mentorship and hands-on training in order to examine (1) the clinical utility of a stand-alone motivational interviewing intervention on client engagement, (2) the extent to which in-treatment factors explain engagement-related outcomes, and (3) feedback from treatment personnel on the feasibility, facilitating factors, and barriers to implementing MI at intake in addiction treatment programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Via a longitudinal study of brain development (from late childhood to early adolescence), this study seeks to find additional evidence supporting a hypothesis of overly rapid followed by too slow brain maturation in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD); positive findings will suggest a basic mechanism that results in a patterned derailment of emerging neural processes in ASD that extends far beyond infancy and early childhood. In parallel, the study will map a shifting landscape of ASD auditory encoding and resting-state neural markers in order to identify late childhood and early adolescence diagnostic markers and treatment targets that are specific to age, brain location, and neural process. Finally, building upon the PIs adult studies, analysis of simultaneously collected magnetoencephalography (MEG) and high-density electroencephalography (EEG) will assess the consistency of MEG and EEG measures as well as the prospect of translating MEG and EEG brain source-space findings to much more clinically scalable scalp EEG.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial viruses, called phages, infect and kill bacteria and thus represent a potential alternative to antibiotics. However, bacteria are equipped with diverse immune systems that prevent phage replication. We have identified a phage family possessing the most potent immune evasion tactics discovered to date, and will characterize their molecular mechanisms to identify and develop better phage therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal will improve our understanding of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Candida auris, two antibiotic-resistant pathogens common to nursing homes that spread by colonizing the body and shedding profusely into the environment. This work in nursing homes will identify risk factors associated with MRSA and C. auris carriage, which predisposes individuals to infection. It will also evaluate whether common care activities result in contamination of nearby objects, which would suggest the need for post-activity cleaning in the rooms of MRSA and C. auris carriers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL While the name is not familiar, N-nitrosamines are among the most mutagenic chemicals known to humankind, and they are not only present at hazardous waste sites, but they are also present in our water, food and drugs. In response to the needs of agencies that are responsible for management of N-nitrosamine-contaminated sites, and to the needs of impacted communities (including the Passamaquoddy Tribe), the MIT Superfund Research Program scientists and engineers will work together to create new technologies to sense contaminants in the environment and to reveal their health impacts. Research will lead to new knowledge and technologies that will guide effective cleanup, destroy hazardous chemicals in drinking water, and identify opportunities for interventions that prevent disease, efforts that will collectively have a significant and sustained positive impact on public health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Significant variation currently exists amongst hospitals regarding NICU admission rates and clinical thresholds for admission in late preterm infants that is not explained by clinical illness. This suggests potential overutilization of NICU care, which may lead to unnecessary separation of the mother-infant dyad. The proposed research develop a prediction model identifying which late preterm infants are most likely to benefit from automatic admission to a NICU at the time of birth, safely minimizing mother-infant dyad separation and its associated implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 N-nitrosamines are probable human carcinogens that are present not only at Superfund Sites, but also in the municipal water that is used by the Passamaquoddy Tribe, making it imperative that the NIEHS Superfund Research Program enable problem-based solution-oriented research on N-nitrosamines using cutting edge technologies. Genetic engineering will be used to create `canary in a coal mine' mice that can be used to detect the potential danger of conditions that people are experiencing (e.g., long-term low-dose exposure in drinking water), and by using chemicals that make cells sensitive to N-nitrosamines, we will be better able to predict the health consequences of N-nitrosamines, and so be in a better position to develop ways to prevent disease. Technologies that will be developed and results from these studies will be shared with stakeholders, including other scientists, community members, and organizations that oversee cleanup and environmental policies (including the EPA) in order to maximize the impact of this work on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 According to the World Health Organization, about one-quarter of human deaths are associated with environmental factors, dominated by air and water pollution. Genetic changes and cell signaling disruptions produced by such environmental chemicals underlie many of these disease outcomes. Given that carcinogenic chemicals were released from prior industrial activities at Superfund sites, this project uses a systems-based approach to examine the impact of these toxicants on the human genome and the repertoire of proteins that are involved in critical signaling systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chromosomal deletions at 22q11.2 are among the highest known genetic risk factors for the development of psychotic illness, while duplications at the same locus may be associated with decreased risk. Here we will prospectively study links between gene dosage effects, brain structure and function, sleep physiology and neurobehavioral outcomes in youth with 22q11.2 deletions and duplications, in order to advance our understanding of the mechanisms by which disruption of genes in this locus impacts brain development and ultimately contributes to disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Public Health Relevance Statement: While osteoporotic hip fracture rates had been decreasing, these serious and sometimes fatal fractures are again increasing in per capita incidence. One reason for this is that patients fear rare side effects caused by the available medications that are used to prevent the bone loss that can lead to fracture and are refusing treatment. The osteoblast is the cell that builds bone and this study is focused on identifying the regulators of osteoblast function, and potentially novel druggable targets that promote anabolic bone formation. The results of this project have the potential to lead to newer, more effective treatments for this common disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Overall Program Project Narrative  This project will advance understanding of diarrheal diseases caused by three important enteric pathogens, including two types of diarrheagenic E.coli and Shigella. A recently developed model of the human intestine called enteroids allows the formation of human mini-intestines that can mimic important aspects of disease due to these organisms and can be co-cultured with innate immune cells to more closely resemble normal intestine. Three universities with long histories of contributions in studying diarrheal diseases will collaborate in utilizing this novel model to study basic mechanisms of disease, characterize attenuated vaccine strains, and elucidate interactions with the immune system. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 4 N-nitrosamines are probable human carcinogens that are present not only at Superfund Sites, but also in the municipal water that use used by the Passamaquoddy Tribe, making it important for this team to develop novel technologies for detecting N-nitrosamines in the environment and in people's tap water, as well as to create novel nanotechnologies and biotechnology approaches to destroy N-nitrosamines. The proposed studies will enable 1) agencies to understand the fate of this important class of compounds in the environment, 2) identification of contaminated water, and 3) deployment of under-sink devices that will protect people from these hazardous chemicals. Technologies that will be created and results from these studies will be shared with stakeholders at the local, state, tribal, and national levels (including the Environmental Protection Agency), in order to maximize the impact of this work on public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Both tau and amyloid-β peptide (Aβ) form unusual clumps in brains of Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients. While Aβ forms plaques extracellularly, tau has been thought to form tangles within the cytoplasm of neurons. However, increasing evidence shows that tau physiologically exists in the extracellular fluid. In fact, vascular deposition of oligomeric tau (o-tau) was observed in brains of AD patients and Tg2576 mice. In turn, o-tau has been reported to be the most toxic form of tau. These recent findings lead to a new hypothesis that vascular deposition of o-tau is involved in driving the vasculopathy in AD. To test this hypothesis, we examine the roles of NADPH oxidase, cytosolic phospholipase A2, and NFκB in the effects of o-tau on oxidative stress, inflammation, expressions of adhesion molecules, and membrane tether adhesion mechanics in human brain microvascular endothelial cells (HBMECs), and transmigration of THP-1 cells across the HBMEC layer. The retina, as a part of the brain, opens a window for high-resolution study of neurovascular defect. We also employ the non-invasive optical coherence tomography (OCT) and OCT angiography (OCTA) (i.e. OCT/OCTA) to study microvascular characteristics and neurodegeneration, as quantified by the ganglion layer thickness (GLT), and their relations to oligomeric Aβ (oAβ), and o-tau contents in retinas of Tg AD mouse models for studying the influences of human tau and amyloid pathology including APPswe/PSEN1dE9 and 3xTg AD mice. This project will fill the research gap between extracellular o-tau and neurovascular abnormalities in AD by providing information regarding adhesion mechanical responses to o-tau in HBMECs, and changes in retinal vessel network characteristics and GLT in relations to Aβ and o-tau, and ultimately provide insights into therapeutic strategies for AD treatment by regulating tau's effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – ADMINISTRATIVE CORE The Administrative Core plays a central role in orchestrating the MIT Superfund Research Program (SRP) so that many types of data can be combined to gain knowledge that will guide decisions on safety and cleanup, and so that work can be done hand-in-hand with community members to detect and destroy hazardous chemicals using novel filtration devices (to be created by MIT SRP engineers). The Administrative Core creates and strengthens connections among members of the MIT SRP, and between the MIT SRP and other stakeholders at local, state, national, tribal and global levels. By ensuring effective teamwork within the MIT SRP and between the MIT SRP and its stakeholders, MIT research, teaching, training, and community engagement will be optimized for their greatest impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality among people living with HIV (PWH) including in sub-Saharan Africa where approximately 70% of the global population of PWH reside. However, CVD screening and prevention remains extremely limited in practice in that region, due in part to lack of patient-oriented research (POR) on diagnostic modalities and locally-derived risk prediction criteria. Dr. Mark Siedner is a clinician scientist and emerging leader in research on CVD among PWH who has an extensive track record of scientific mentorship in patient-oriented clinical research. This award will provide him the protected time and support to 1) develop a POR mentoring program on CVD research focused on PWH in sub- Saharan Africa, 2) grow the careers of promising scientists in this area, and 3) identify optimal CVD screening algorithms and risk prediction scores for PWH in the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – DATA MANAGEMENT AND ANALYSIS CORE Water near Superfund Sites and municipal drinking water are contaminated with potentially carcinogenic chemicals (N-nitrosamines), and the purpose of the MIT Superfund Research Program includes gaining a better understanding of the health effects and risks associated with exposure. The Data Management and Analysis Core makes the most of MIT SRP data by making sure anyone can learn from MIT SRP data (via data sharing), fostering collaborations among scientists, and by providing cutting-edge data analysis methods so that we can learn as much as possible from study results. The DMAC supports the MIT Superfund Research Program in accomplishing its goals of being better able to predict and prevent diseases caused by these hazardous chemicals, and of using knowledge of exposure risks to guide decisions on cleanup.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Vitamin A deficiency is a widespread problem in low-income countries and recently has been identified as a strong risk factor for developing clinical tuberculosis disease. This research aims to better understand the mechanisms by which a lack of vitamin A influences the ability of immune cells to respond to infection, and consequently, the outcome of tuberculosis disease. The goal will be to identify points in which vitamin A deficiency contributes to a more severe tuberculosis outcome in order to inform supplementation and host- directed therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT CORE The mission of the MIT Superfund Research Program (SRP) Community Engagement Core (CEC) is to continue to strengthen robust bidirectional communication and collaborations with stakeholders that will make it possible to be responsive to the needs of community members by reducing the amount and toxicity of hazardous chemicals in the environment. The CEC will use tactile learning kits (invented by the CEC leader) to teach community members about how environmental chemicals can cause cancer and will work with educators to inspire underrepresented students to pursue research careers in environmental health. Working with the EPA, community members, and other MIT SRP members, the CEC will do Citizen Science research to reveal the amount of contamination in water, and will provide filters that will reduce the amount of hazardous chemicals in drinking water.

PHR: Project Narrative: This project will investigate the molecular mechanism underlying a genetic syndromic disorder called Timothy syndrome showing severe and lethal cardiac arrhythmia. Our team will take advantage of our new technology and expertise to develop new drug candidates on experimental platforms using cardiac muscle cells derived from human patients as well as small animal models. This translational approach will open new avenue to identify novel therapeutics for human genetic cardiac arrhythmias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RESEARCH EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING COORDINATION CORE The Research Experience and Training Coordination Core (RETCC) recruits the best and the brightest trainees, provides cross disciplinary research training, and propels all of the activities of the MIT Superfund Research Program that, together, enable protection of people from the effects of hazardous chemicals. The RETCC coordinates with the Administrative Core and the Community Engagement Core to ensure that trainees have exciting research translation opportunities (and regular contact with community members and organizations at the local, state, national, and tribal levels), as well as opportunities to listen to, learn from, and collaborate with community members and tribes. By fostering teamwork and nurturing trainees with a supportive environment, strong mentorship, and formal and informal enrichment activities, the MIT SRP trainees will continue to promote the public health impact of the MIT SRP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Vocal fatigue (VF) is among the most common voice-related complaints among individuals who rely on their voices to make a living (teachers, singers, etc.) and is implicated as an etiologic and/or reactive component in most common voice disorders. This project will use a combination of an existing ambulatory voice monitoring dataset and newly acquired data to quantify vocal function and behaviors that are associated with the causes and impact on phonatory mechanisms of VF among patients with voice disorders and vocally typical individuals. Achieving the goals of this project will lay the groundwork for the development of new clinical tools for preventing, assessing, and alleviating VF, which will be particularly valuable for professionals in occupations requiring heavy voice use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  The pathogenic Neisseria are obligate human pathogens with a long evolutionary history within human populations. The studies outlined in this proposal will continue our investigations into the molecular mechanisms used to replace one pilin type with another following high-frequency nonreciprocal recombination events, which allows the organism to evade the adaptive immune system and continually infect susceptible individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The role of natural killer (NK) cells in the immune response to COVID-19 is not yet clear. This proposed work will use replication-competent SARS-CoV-2 to investigate the immune evasion strategies of SARS-CoV-2, assess the impact of COVID-19 severity on primary NK cell responses, and identify the mechanisms underlying the activated and exhausted phenotype seen in the NK cells of severe COVID-19 patients. These experiments will clarify the functional role of NK cells in COVID-19, providing crucial insights into how vaccination and therapeutic strategies should seek to modulate NK cell responses in this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL NARRATIVE In collaboration with residents and representatives of communities living in Persistent Poverty in Alabama, the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB)'s Center for Cancer Control in Persistent Poverty Areas (C3P2) will build a research program and research capacity to improve cancer prevention and control in these communities. Starting from nine urban Persistent Poverty Census Tracts identified as such by the NCI, the C3P2 goal is to support transdisciplinary multi-level research to address Social Determinants of Health, in particular addressing poor living environments, and to provide efficacious adapted interventions to enhance health promotion and adoption of healthy behaviors across the cancer continuum from prevention to survivorship.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A female’s prior mating experience––positive or negative––informs her subsequent mating strategy, but how the brain computes and encodes this complex assignment is unknown. The proposed study will elucidate the molecular and neural mechanisms that underpin sexual reward in the brain of female Drosophila, which will advance our understanding on the rewarding aspect of mating behavior and provide novel insights into fundamental principles for the encoding and regulation of natural reward.

PHR: Deregulation of phosphorylation signaling in cell division has been implicated in many human diseases, including cancer and birth defects. In this application, we will advance a quantitative chemical proteomics strategy to enable us to interrogate key mitotic kinases, identify their substrates, uncover the regulation of dynamic phosphorylation via specific opposing phosphatases, and elucidate phosphorylation signaling networks of key mitotic regulatory kinases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Since the STEEP SRP Center was first funded in 2017, PFAS have emerged as national priority pollutants, with the EPA and states grappling with setting PFAS standards for drinking water while assessing the human and ecological risk linked to emissions from contaminated sites, point, and diffuse sources. STEEP II builds on the successful collaborative it established within the first STEEP SRP Center (STEEP I) to further advance the science, training, engagement, and outreach in support of SRP mandates. In order to successfully tackle the complex biomedical and environmental science surrounding PFAS, and provide actionable insight, tools, and solutions, STEEP II’s research is focused on problem-based, solution-oriented PFAS research that covers critical health effects, mechanistic studies, risk assessment, detection and remediation of PFAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 EXPOSURE Results of this project will help identify populations potentially at risk for elevated PFAS exposures through contaminated drinking water/ fish and enhanced atmospheric PFAS deposition. Work associated with this project will investigate the downstream impacts of PFAS contamination from aqueous film forming foam (AFFF) use at the Joint Base Cape Cod, which is a designated Superfund Site for PFAS. Improved risk assessment methods, particularly for polyfluoroalkyl precursors that degrade into terminal PFAS, developed as part of this project will be directly useful for managing contaminated site remediation goals and the development of public health guidance. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Asthma morbidity continues to be a major public health problem among low-income minority children living in urban neighborhoods, and the major contributors are thought to be exposures to pest allergens and indoor pollution. With this current proposal, we will extend our previous Mobility Asthma Project (MAP, R01 ES026170-05), where we followed children with asthma as they entered into the Baltimore Housing Mobility Program and moved to low poverty neighborhoods, to determine if these reductions in home exposures and asthma outcomes are sustained over a 4 to 7 year follow-up period, whether lung function growth is changed with mobility, and whether parent/caregiver stress may mediate or modify the effects of changes in indoor exposures on asthma outcomes. The proposed project is strongly positioned to both influence housing policy around mobility and has implications for interventions designed to reduce asthma morbidity in children who remain living in high-poverty neighborhoods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 CRITICAL EFFECTS STEEP achievements support the notion that PFAS exposures incurred during early development can affect immune system and metabolic functions and trigger potential vaccine failure and metabolic abnormalities that may lead to infections, obesity, and osteoporosis, all of which constitute important public health problems. This project is conducting prospective studies of about 1000 children from two birth cohorts generated in the Faroe Islands, where PFAS exposures are investigated prenatally, via breastfeeding, and beyond, and clinical features and blood biomarkers are assessed to determine adverse effects of profiles of PFAS exposures. The aim is to identify windows of vulnerability related to developmental pathways at ages 5 and 14 years and to determine exposure-related outcomes as a basis for improved risk assessment and protection against exposures to these persistent environmental contaminants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Asthma affects over 300 million individuals worldwide and accounts for an estimated $82 billion in direct health care costs in the United States annually. This study seeks a thorough understanding of the role of small circulating cell-cell signaling molecules called microRNAs and of microRNA genetics in the control of asthma symptoms and in symptoms response to therapy. Since microRNAs are both stable in the circulation and may be targeted, this study has the potential to uncover novel biomarkers and therapies for the persistently symptomatic person with uncontrolled asthma, thereby decreasing asthma costs, morbidity, and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Acute respiratory syndrome (ARDS) is common in patients suffering from conditions such as major trauma, sepsis or shock and is the primary cause of death. The severity of lung injury remains a critical determinant of survival in patients suffering from ARDS and sepsis. This proposal seeks to identify and characterize a novel cell death pathway caused by a packaged delivery of Gasdermin D in microparticles by monocytes; thereby uncovering novel insights into ARDS mediated lung injury of septic patients and thus create new therapeutic opportunities to prevent and treat patients with ARDS and other inflammatory diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 3 MECHANISMS Per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances (PFAS), have been detected in human serum and excreta, and some are associated with adverse health outcomes in humans. STEEP Project 3 (P3–Mechanisms) elucidates the cellular mechanisms by which PFAS are absorbed, retained, and are eliminated in the body to inform Projects 1, 2, and 4 for bioaccumulation modeling and enable predicting PFAS absorption, distribution, and excretion in humans. P3–Mechanisms will apply mechanistic approaches SRP Mandate #3 and SRP Mandate #4, as well as support interdisciplinary training.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Pre-existing conditions such as diabetes, heart disease, and high blood pressure, which share underlying obesity, increase the severity of COVID-19. Conversely, patients with COVID-19 often present with newly- diagnosed diabetes, or develop diabetes and other aspects of metabolic disease after recovering from COVID- 19. This project will investigate this two-way relationship between COVID-19 and obesity using a nonhuman primate model, since the nonhuman primate response to the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus and to obesity is similar to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 4 DETECTION Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) have become the most high-profile pollutants in the US, based on the detection of thousands of contaminated sites, the discovery of PFAS in public water supplies serving millions of Americans, and their highly persistent, toxic and bioaccumulative nature, resulting in food chain contamination worldwide. P4–Detection proposes (i) the development and design of simple yet effective materials for remediating PFAS-contaminated groundwater plumes and in situ monitoring of field trials of ex situ treatment approaches on Cape Cod using passive samplers from STEEP I; (ii) further development and field application of passive samplers as screening tools for legacy and novel PFAS in the Delaware River region with a focus on their bioaccumulation; and (iii) characterizing complementary air sampling tools for stakeholder needs to assess the importance of PFAS inhalation as an exposure pathway. P4-Detection will continue to work with federal (EPA ORD) and state stakeholders (DE, RI) to advance the use of passive samplers in characterizing bioaccumulation and biotransformation of legacy, novel, and total PFAS by aquatic biota, and to rely on passive samplers to assess the atmospheric transport of PFAS away from PFAS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Older adults who encounter adverse interpersonal experiences (AIEs) in their social environment, such as loneliness, typically have higher risk for Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). This project examines the significance of AIEs for diminished cognitive functioning in later life by conducting a follow-up of the Minnesota-Carolina Twin Study of Aging (MCTSA), a longitudinal study of 800 pairs of ethnically diverse twins. The twin design of the study allows a strong test of the hypothesis that AIEs are linked to diminished cognitive functioning and Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) with downstream implications for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) risk through environmental pathways.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE The aging of America together with escalating age-related cognitive decline and increasing alcohol drinking in older men and women signals an urgency to investigate the role of alcohol use in exacerbating cognitive decline toward dementia and postural instability as risk for falls attendant morbidity and mortality. Outcomes of this research have the potential to confirm alcohol consumption as a modifiable risk factor for dementia and for standing and walking instability, thereby providing justification for implementing balance, cognitive, and alcohol assessment in treatment settings and for creating protective strategies to enhance postural stability in standing and walking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – ADMINISTRATIVE CORE (AC) Since 2015, when the first STEEP Center proposal was submitted, the universe of poly- and perfluorinated alkyl substances (PFAS) has substantially expanded, many have been recognized as major pollutants threatening public health across the U.S, and new adverse health effects have emerged, thus provoking a need to reconsider current guidelines for maximum concentration levels or exposure limits. The continuation of the proposed STEEP II SRP Center will characterize PFAS exposures and health risks, and address the evolving needs of communities affected by PFAS-contaminated drinking water, whether past or present, or by other sources of PFAS exposure, including contamination of the food web (fish/shellfish), consumer products, air, soil, and dust. Maintaining and accelerating STEEP’s focus on innovation and collaboration remains the AC’s primary goal, and its team will build on the success already achieved by STEEP I in regard to the forefront of PFAS science, the inspiration and training of the next generation of PFAS scientists, and supporting equitable community engagement, comprehensive research translation, and inclusive outreach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) antibody-associated disease (MOGAD) was recently recognized as a spectrum of central nervous system inflammatory conditions that are separate from multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder (NMOSD). Research indicates that MOG-specific T cells have a central role in the pathogenesis of MOGAD, yet there is essentially no knowledge regarding MOG-specific T cells in MOGAD. The goal of this project is to identify and characterize MOG-specific T cells in MOGAD, and by using a model of MOGAD, to determine how MOG-specific T cells and B cells cooperate to cause MOGAD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – DATA MANAGEMENT AND ANALYSIS CORE (DMAC) DMAC is an essential component of the proposed STEEP II SRP renewal, providing data management, biostatistical, and data science support and ensuring resource sharing for all four of STEEP’s research projects. This DMAC proposal is expressly relevant to the NIEHS mission because it implements Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, Reuse (FAIR) principles, quality assurance and quality control (QA/QC), and state-of-the-art statistical methods to determine how PFAS exposures impact health outcomes. DMAC will ultimately provide a data management example of a user-friendly, low-cost, and FAIR compliant infrastructure, as well as reproducible and precise empirical results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Threat-coping behaviors evolve over time, as humans and animals initially avoid and eventually learn to overcome potential threats. Abnormality in such dynamic adjustment is thought to underlie various psychiatric disorders such as post-traumatic stress disorder and anxiety disorders. The result of the proposed study will identify novel neural circuits that critically regulate such dynamic adjustment in threat-coping, and thus will provide crucial insights into these psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT CORE (CEC) The Community Engagement Core (CEC) will address community concerns on Cape Cod, Massachusetts, about per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), with a goal of identifying local sources of PFAS exposures and developing intervention strategies to reduce these exposures and prevent adverse health outcomes. CEC will foster bidirectional partnerships with local water and health officials, members of the Mashpee Wampanoag Tribe, high school teachers and students, environmental nonprofit organizations, and other concerned residents through focus groups, community events, a community advisory committee, and resident participation in the design and implementation of a sampling program for local foods. CEC will advance public health by potentially reducing exposures to PFAS from the local environment, by providing new information about sources of PFAS exposure, and by supporting decision making by local, state, and federal water and health agencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Toxocariasis is the most common zoonotic helminth infection in the United States (US) and represents one of our nation’s most important contributors to childhood health disparities. Despite its enormous health and socioeconomic importance, toxocariasis remains underdiagnosed in the US due to limited access to and poor test performance of commercially available diagnostic tests. This study will produce an innovative Toxocara diagnostic assay with improved accessibility and test performance in order to guide public health interventions to prevent Toxocara-induced morbidity in US children.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RESEARCH EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING COORDINATION CORE (RETCC) The University of Rhode Island (URI)-led STEEP (Sources, Transport, Exposure and Effects of PFAS) Center will provide solutions to the NIH Superfund Research Program (SRP) in addressing emerging per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances (PFAS) for reducing human exposure, providing training, and engaging affected communities. In response to the SRP mandate, the STEEP Research Experience and Training Coordination Core (RETCC) will provide trainees (pre- and post-doctoral) with resources and opportunities to become skilled scientists/engineers, equipped to address various aspects of emerging contaminants, specifically the scientific, remediation, community, and translational facets of PFAS, through research experiences and community engagement. Beyond their individual research projects, all STEEP II trainees will participate in joint laboratory meetings, laboratory rotations, the PFAS Scholars seminar series, an annual trainee retreat, and a new “Action Team” initiative where trainees will work with STEEP PIs, the Administrative Core (AC) and Community Engagement Core (CEC), on applied aspects of their research through education, outreach, or policy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The long-term goal of this proposal is to develop new novel therapies to decrease venous neointimal hyperplasia (VNH) and subsequent venous stenosis (VS) after angioplasty of stenotic hemodialysis arteriovenous fistulae (AVFs). End-stage kidney disease affects >4M patients globally. A well-functioning vascular access using an AVF is required for renal replacement therapy using hemodialysis, however, 60% of AVFs require PTA to maintain vascular patency and these fail due to the development of recurrent VS caused by VNH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although 20% of Americans live in rural communities, there are significant gaps in our understanding of rural cancer care disparities, the influence of community-level social determinants of health, and efficacy of policy solutions to improve equity of cancer care delivery. Utilizing multilevel modelling, geocomputational and spatiotemporal approaches, and econometric methodology, this research will determine the extent to which rurality and community-level socioeconomic deprivation influence disparities in cancer care delivery and how they interact with other social determinants of cancer care, including insurance coverage. Further, the project will assess the degree to which health insurance expansion influences care delivery across rural and socioeconomically strained communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The cells lining the lung form a protective layer that acts as both a barrier and an alarm system for infections. During some respiratory infections, including COVID-19, this alarm system responds inappropriately, leading to lung inflammation and an often-fatal condition known as Acute Lung Injury/Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ALI/ARDS). In this project, we will develop a new technology for tracking the alarm response in real-time, which will enable us to identify the best drugs to regain control of the signals and treat respiratory inflammation in multiple types of infection.

PHR: The Emerging Infectious Disease and HIV Scholars at Brown University program is a collaboration between the Alpert Medical School of Brown University, the affiliated hospitals, and the Rhode Island Department of Health. The program seeks to develop a physician- scientist workforce focused on clinical research to inform practical responses to HIV and associated infections the important role of clinical research, particularly among marginalized communities, to help end the HIV epidemic. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Live attenuated vaccines based on the same genetically heterogeneous virus are used to reduce chickenpox and zoster, but the basis of skin attenuation is unknown. The vaccine can be problematic in some recipients because it is genetically a mix. The work proposed here will show that attenuation involves changes in a VZV regulatory protein that influences DNA repair. The results may lead to a more defined vaccine candidate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity and related metabolic disorders, including insulin resistance, type 2 diabetes, and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, are an ever increasing worldwide problem leading to severe medical complications with substantial morbidity and mortality. It is well recognized that immune cells, such as macrophages, accumulate in obese fat tissue and liver and these cells have traditionally been implicated in promoting metabolic disease. We have found that macrophages also have a potentially important beneficial effect in these tissues, due to their ability to ingest and degrade excess lipids in adipose tissue and liver. Therefore, we hypothesize that genetically reprogramming macrophages to augment their lipid degradation machinery is a strategy to prevent and/or treat certain obesity- associated metabolic diseases. We propose to dissect the links between the macrophage lipid degradation machinery both in vitro and in vivo with the goal of developing a novel strategy for the treatment of obesity- associated insulin resistance and fatty liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health impact of cancer-related cognitive impairment (CRCI) is substantial; up to 80% of breast cancer patients exhibit CRCI during chemotherapy which can be debilitating. Some patients (survivors) of breast cancer also experience persistent long-term CRCI but long-term CRCI trajectories have been understudied. This proposal will add to the field by characterizing long-term CRCI with novel cognitive neuroscience-based measures and incorporating pre-chemotherapy and post-chemotherapy time-points. Lastly, we will assess the impact of CRCI on function and the role of inflammation in long-term CRCI by leveraging a large, nationwide, prospective study conducted in NCI-funded community oncology network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV infection is a risk factor for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and COPD exacerbations, but risk factors for and outcomes following COPD exacerbations as well as the prescribing patterns and effect of guideline-concordant COPD care in people with HIV (PWH) are unknown. We therefore propose to perform a cohort study of HIV-infected and uninfected comparators with COPD using administrative and electronic health record data from multiple health systems across the US and a causal inference framework to identify modifiable risk factors for COPD exacerbations and poor outcomes and to investigate the links between processes of care and outcomes in PWH. Ultimately, this research will inform efforts to develop effective management strategies for high-quality COPD care in people with HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The present proposal will test the effect of a novel intervention based on memory reconsolidation blockade on the participants’ physiological reactivity during script-driven imagery of the traumatic event. The project will test two interventions, mismatch vs. standard memory reactivation, under the influence of propranolol (a pharmacological agent that blocks memory reconsolidation). The project will serve as a proof of concept study for later, clinical propranolol mismatch stud(ies).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: The ocular surface was initially thought to be sterile due to difficulty in obtaining viable microbes using traditional culture-based techniques, not to mention the potent anti-microbial defenses present in tears. Recent work has indicated the ocular surface is not sterile but contains a low biomass microbial community, which suggests these microbes may play a role in ocular health. In response to this U24 RFA, we propose to better define the breadth of microbes and microbial communities that populate the ocular surface through a combination of targeted cultivation and metagenomic sequencing approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although there is increasing evidence that financial incentives can improve the health of people living with HIV infection (PLHIV), it is unknown whether these benefits extend to PLHIV who have disengaged from HIV care. In this study, we will evaluate an incentive-based intervention for Tanzanian adults to support engagement in HIV care and adherence to antiretroviral treatment. Our findings will result in generalizable knowledge about the effectiveness of incentives for retention in HIV care and achievement of global targets to control HIV.
