IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite significant improvement in treatment using immune checkpoint inhibitors, non-small cell lung cancer remains the leading cause of cancer death, representing 22% of all cancer deaths. The gut microbiome has been identified as an independent, novel modulator of systemic anti-tumor responses to immunotherapy, but data remain limited by inconsistencies, lack of longitudinal analysis, and lack of functional characterization. The current proposal seeks to identify key metabolites and microbes or microbial communities that mechanistically impact systemic and intra-tumoral immune responses that either enhance or inhibit responses to immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

PHR: The fellows and mentors trained by this program will contribute to short- and long-term improvements in global health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dendritic cells are professional antigen-presenting cells and play a pivotal role in antitumor immunity and effective immunotherapy. We found that platinum-based chemotherapy reprograms lipid metabolism in small cell lung cancer, which reshapes the function of dendritic cells and leads to immune evasion. In this proposal, we will uncover the molecular mechanism by which platinum induces lipid reprograming and validate PPARa signaling as a therapeutic target to improve platinum/immunotherapy combination in small cell lung cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Relevance Decreased sound tolerance (DST) is one of the most prevalent and persistent sensory features of autism spectrum disorder (ASD), currently affecting an estimated 2–3 million Americans with ASD and contributing to substantial distress and functional impairment. By providing a foundational understanding of both the psychological and physiological aspects of DST in ASD, this project is expected to improve the recognition, classification, and measurement of sound intolerance. In doing so, we will lay the foundation for future work aimed at developing targeted interventions for this debilitating symptom in persons on the autism spectrum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatoblastoma and hepatocellular carcinoma are the most frequently diagnosed liver tumors in children, and they represent a remarkable variety of biologies, histologies, and outcomes: low-risk HBs are cured with a combination of chemotherapy and surgical resection, while high-risk HBs and HCCs continue to have a dismal prognosis of 30-50% at 5 years despite of aggressive medical and surgical therapies. Treatments for these tumors include chemotherapy using cisplatin and other chemotherapeutic agents, as well as surgical resection and liver transplantation; these treatments are associated with risks that range from developmental impairments to death due to toxicity, transplant rejection, or secondary drug-resistant lesions. We propose to systematically validate assays and models that will help distinguish between tumor subtypes, evaluate risk, and help select optimal toxicity-to-outcome treatment tradeoffs for HB and HCC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: There is a high prevalence of loneliness among people with schizophrenia, yet little is presently known about the effects of loneliness on health and well-being in this at-risk population as they age. This information is critically important as loneliness is not just psychologically distressing, but is also associated with increased risk of worse health outcomes such as medical disorders, cognitive decline, reduced independence skills, worse overall well-being, and early mortality. This study will comprehensively examine the effects of loneliness and aging in schizophrenia in terms of such health outcomes in order to better guide comprehensive personalized care for older adults with schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is the most common chronic liver disease in the world, and it occurs when overnutrition and obesity trigger fat accumulation and inflammation in the liver through mechanisms that are poorly understood. This research aims to investigate how inflammation perturbs the metabolic state of liver cells, and influences the development of NAFLD and its associated complications. These studies will help develop novel approaches for improving the metabolic health of patients with NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Soil-transmitted helminth parasites like roundworms, whipworms, and hookworms affect the health of over a billion people in developing countries and are most common in children between the ages of 3 and 8. Treatment includes using nicotinic anthelmintics like levamisole and pyrantel, which paralyze the nematodes by activating the cholinergic ion channels on their muscle. These parasites are complex organisms that recover from exposure to nicotinic anthelmintics through mechanisms that are not well understood. Our study will provide insight into the mechanisms of nicotinic anthelmintic recovery using a parasitic nematode model, Brugia malayi, and how macrocyclic lactones can prevent this recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: NARRATIVE We seek to design novel hydrogels to increase the viability and enhance the differentiation capacity of human oligodendrocytes upon transplantation to demyelinating brain. We will also develop novel animal models of brain demyelination that mimic human diseases such as multiple sclerosis and employ them to test cell therapies. The proposed work has enormous implications for regenerative medicine, as it has the potential to develop novel strategies to enhance stem cell delivery for treatment of devastating neurodegenerative diseases that remain intractable to current treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Patients with Alzheimer’s disease have plaques in their brains containing, among other things, caspase cleaved tau protein. The goal of this proposal is to characterize the role that caspase cleavage of tau plays in the progression of tau pathology. The outcome of these experiments will provide valuable insight into events happening early in the progression of Alzheimer’s disease as well as further validate caspases as targets for the development of treatments for the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: This translational study presents a novel epigenetic approach for attenuating periodontitis, the leading cause of tooth loss, in which two epigenetic modulators, with distinct and complementary effects, will be carried and delivered to the targeting cells in the diseased sites by nanoparticles newly developed at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). A synthetic BET inhibitor specifically targets inflammatory and bone-resorbing cells to halt the progression of the disease, and a particular noncoding RNA deploys the endogenous capacity to restore the normal structure contours and functions of the tissues damaged in periodontitis. This approach represents a paradigm shift in developing a strategy, because it efficiently challenges the major etiology of periodontitis and regenerates a healthy periodontium, saving the teeth of millions of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Schistosomes are water-borne blood-flukes that are transmitted by snails, infecting over 250 million people in more than 70 countries, and causing severe and chronic disability. We will identify new genes that make some snails naturally resistant to infection by schistosomes. Identifying such genes will reveal potential new ways to reduce parasite transmission at the snail stage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major challenge in treating Fontan heart/circulation failure is in understanding the unique mechanisms of failure in these patients, since standard heart failure therapies are ineffective in this population. We have previously shown that mitochondrial injury plays a major role in this form of heart failure, and here will evaluate how mitochondrial injury in cardiac muscle cells leads to impaired function in cardiac blood vessel cells by cell-to-cell transport of damaged mitochondria. Through better understanding of the unique mechanisms of single ventricle heart failure we are poised to develop new strategies for prevention and treatment focused on cellular energetics and vascular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Bacterial pneumonia is a major health burden worldwide, and new treatment approaches are urgently needed. Follistatin-like protein 1 (FSTL-1) is a novel host immunomodulator in the lung, though the role of FSTL-1 in lung host defense is unknown. This proposal aims to determine the molecular and cellular requirements of FSTL-1-mediated pulmonary host defense pathway, and outcomes of these studies will inform host-derived, immune targeting therapeutic approaches for the treatment of bacterial pneumonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Developing policies and practices that maximize later life-course health and well-being while minimizing disparities across population subgroups requires understanding the social determinants of physical, emotional, cognitive, and economic health. The Life Course Center (LCC) at the University of Minnesota provides the theoretical frameworks and outstanding research infrastructure—including access to innovative sources of population data—needed to address these crucial issues. The Center facilitates interdisciplinary collaborations to directly addresses Goal E of NIA’s Strategic Directions (2016): to “improve our understanding of the consequences of an aging society to inform intervention development and policy decisions”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intergenerational malnutrition is a global health challenge; the contributions of the small intestinal microbiota remain enigmatic due to the difficulty in obtaining biospecimens from malnourished children living in resource- poor settings. We have combined gnotobiotic mouse models with esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) of stunted Bangladeshi children who failed a nutritional intervention to provide evidence that small intestinal bacterial taxa are causally related to their small intestinal enteropathy. This proposal seeks to delineate mechanisms by which the small intestinal microbiota contributes to maternal/child malnutrition and identify therapeutic targets and candidate therapeutic leads.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose the Child Health Equity Research Program for Post-doctoral Trainees (CHERPP-T), a mentored, research project-based training program that provides didactic training in rigorous health services and clinical research methodologies, experiential research training, career development, opportunities for community- academic partnerships, and a long-term network of mentors, collaborators, and partners. The program will focus heavily on recruiting underrepresented minority (URM) trainees by leveraging existing relationships with predoctoral and early career URM pipeline programs for academic pediatricians. CHERPP-T will increase URM faculty scientists in pediatrics as well as address major gaps in child health equity research capacity, both of which will reduce inequities in child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: OVERALL-NARRATIVE Organ transplantation has become a standard procedure to save the lives of patients with irreversible organ damage. One of the greatest unmet needs for improving long-term transplant outcomes is to devise safer combinatorial immune therapies that enable the specific targeting of effector alloimmune responses while augmenting the development of suppression and tolerance. These two highly synergistic projects centered on the lymph node as the critical locus of alloimmunity, seek to produce mechanistic data to lay the groundwork for developing highly targeted and innovative therapeutic strategies for transplantation.

The goal of this proposal is to generate highly innovative data that will address the key unmet clinical need to devise highly specific, targeted immune therapies for transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Achieving tolerance remains the most important goal in transplantation. The significance of the current proposal is that it will define the function and mechanisms of specialized stromal cells and stromal structures in the lymph node that determine transplantation tolerance, and how they determine the choice between immunity versus tolerance. The findings from these investigations will have general applicability to other areas of immunology such as infection, vaccination, and autoimmunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Tobacco dependence is a leading cause of premature death and disease in the United States. We have shown that medial habenula neurons that project to the interpeduncular nucleus play a critical role in regulating the motivational properties of nicotine. In new findings, we show that the transcription factor Tcf7l2 acts in the habenula to exert profound control over nicotine intake. Here, we will use cutting-edge molecular, cellular and behavioral approaches to understand the mechanisms by which Tcf7l2 acts. This program of research promises to identify new classes of targets for the development of therapeutic agents to aid smoking cessation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE We will develop a comprehensive multi-omic, phenomic, and trans-ethnic computational methodology that bridges the gap between Genetic Epidemiology and Functional Genomics. This research provides a rigorous framework for investigating relevant mechanisms underlying complex traits, including disease risk and quantitative traits. We will leverage and integrate high- dimensional molecular data, electronic health records, and genetic studies in diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The basal ganglia, including dopamine neurons, are crucial for learning about stimuli that predict rewards (cues), but it is not understood how this system receives sensory information needed to guide cue-based learning. Here, I use new techniques for mapping and manipulating brain circuits to investigate the role of projections from the superior colliculus, an evolutionarily ancient visual structure, to the dopamine system in the transformation of sensation to action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although many women with estrogen receptor positive (ER+) primary cancers are successfully treated with surgery and adjuvant anti-estrogen therapies, metastatic ER+ cancers account for the majority of breast cancer related deaths. Lack of in vivo models with an intact immune system has impeded our understanding of how factors, including estrogen itself, orchestrate cooperation between tumor cells and other cells in the environment to drive local disease and promote metastasis. The goal of our proposed studies utilizing an immunocompetent mouse model of aggressive ER+ disease, complemented by study of clinical samples, is to illuminate the effects of estrogen on dissemination and lung metastatic colonization in ER+ breast cancer. These studies have implications for breast cancer therapy, dormancy and recurrence, and the potential to reveal sites for intervention.

PHR: Project Narrative In the U.S., cancer has become the leading cause of death in the aging HIV-positive population. In this application, we propose to investigate targets that impinge on the PI3K/Akt/mTOR pathway in KSHV- associated cancers. These investigations will uncover the next generation of therapies against KS and lymphoma in the context of HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With the success of antiretroviral therapy (ART) and public health strategies to reduce new HIV infections, much of the HIV burden in developed countries is now as a chronic disease, including among drug users. Cocaine is one of the most frequently abused illicit drugs among HIV+ individuals and is known to worsen HIV progression, even with ART, and is likely to increase the latent reservoir of virus: the latent reservoir blocking efforts for an HIV cure. We will apply cutting-edge big data techniques across multiple genome-wide data types and cohorts to produce important new insights into key elements of HIV as a chronic disease among cocaine users, providing a basis for improved treatment and identification of targets for new medication development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The proposed study will inform prevention science, and contribute to reducing health disparities among Hispanic adolescents, by identifying physiological mechanisms that explain the effects of cultural stressors on alcohol/drug use and conduct problems in this population. The study will also identify protective mechanisms that can be targeted in preventive interventions. An innovative two-site (Miami and Los Angeles) design will be used to ascertain generalizability of findings across different geographic areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a common chronic autoimmune disease consisting of inflammatory arthritis. Patients with RA are susceptible to developing interstitial lung disease (ILD), which results in substantial excess morbidity and mortality. This research will investigate whether RA-related autoantibodies and articular inflammation contribute to subclinical and clinically apparent RA-ILD across the disease course of RA (pre-RA, early RA, established RA). Discoveries made through this research are directly relevant to the National Institutes of Health’s mission by providing insight into RA and RA-ILD pathogenesis that may ultimately lead to RA-ILD screening and prevention strategies for this devastating complication of RA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Triple negative breast cancer is an aggressive disease; prevention and treatment have been hampered by its lower frequency and limited understanding of its biology. By integrating whole exome tumor mutation profiles with germline genetics, prospective risk factor data, pathology, and immune signature data this proposal addresses a number of important knowledge gaps—in particular, it will shed light on how genetic and nongenetic factors influence breast tumor molecular biology. Linking specific risk factors with triple negative tumor mutations will provide important mechanistic understanding in tumor evolution, which will open up avenues for prevention and treatment of triple negative breast cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research project is relevant to public health because nephrotic syndrome is a leading cause of end stage kidney disease in the United States. Current treatments for nephrotic syndrome are associated with severe side effects and are not always successful, so new approaches are urgently needed. Studying the mechanisms by which a blood clotting protein called thrombin injures specialized kidney cells called podocytes is expected to lead to discovery of new treatments for nephrotic syndrome and help prevent end stage kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rotator cuff (RC) tears are among the most common orthopedic injuries in the United States, resulting in more than 450,000 repairs are performed per year at a cost of more than $523M [1,46]. Current repair techniques focus on the development of biological or synthetic scaffold devices to reinforce the mechanical strength of the tendon- to-bone connection; however, these techniques do not promote enthesis regeneration, contributing to a failure rate of current RC repair procedures ranging from 20-95% [40-42,50,53]. STEL’s Engineered Tissue Graft for Rotator Cuff (ETG-RC) is an innovative approach to rotator cuff repair offering the possibility of a radical improvement in RC patient outcomes resulting from a fully biologic “off-the-shelf” tissue-engineered RC tendon graft that restores biomechanical properties of the tendon-humerus enthesis while providing an underlayment that allows the migration of endogenous cells, enhancing the regenerative capacity of the torn RC tendon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICI) produce durable responses in many cancer patients, but may cause cardiac, vascular, and other organ inflammation leading to morbidity and mortality. We propose to determine the role of ICI in mitigating cardiovascular injury using genetic and pharmacologically treated mouse models, and perform intensive cardiac monitoring in a large cohort of long-term survivors treated with ICI. This study will provide significant insights into the long-term complications of these therapies and enable targeted screening and prevention strategies for patients at risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The pathways linking individual differences in midlife cardiovascular stress physiology to risk for cerebrovascular disease and vascular determinants of later life dementias are uncertain. From a public health perspective, it is important to specify these pathways to (1) understand plausible mechanistic factors by which stress relates to cerebrovascular risk and (2) identify factors that could be objectively identified and possibly targeted for modification in otherwise healthy midlife adults at risk for future dementia.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE The World Health Organization developed the dementia toolkit for community workers, consisting of evidence-based practices for early detection and management of dementia and caregiver support. However, the toolkit has not been adopted because there is lack of an appropriate and effective implementation strategy. We propose to develop and evaluate the feasibility of a culturally tailored implementation strategy consisting of the WHO dementia toolkit by indigenous village-based LHWs to provide dementia care at village level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Fibromyalgia is a chronic debilitating pain condition that affects about four million people in the U.S. alone. The objective of this project is to establish and validate a clinically relevant animal model of fibromyalgia. This new model will provide a useful preclinical platform to evaluate novel therapeutics for fibromyalgia treatment and to conduct in-depth mechanistic investigations of fibromyalgia pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) is a debilitating disorder, which manifests as problematic patterns of alcohol use and cravings in the face of abstinence. Here we use the fruit fly to understand how alcohol co-opts neural circuits to drive maladaptive drug seeking behaviors. Understanding how these circuits change in the context of alcohol is critical for the development of more specific and effective circuit-based AUD treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Our proposal aims to detect neurodegenerative changes in the multiple sclerosis (MS) spinal cord prior to axonal loss and irreversible neurological disability using the best available imaging modalities with 7 Tesla (T) MRI. The premise for our hypothesis that T2* intermediate lesions detect ongoing neurodegenerative processes are based on our MRI-pathology studies. Results from our proposal will inform the applicability of our methods to clinical 3T MRI and the feasibility of determining the role of spinal cord lesion subtypes with clinical disability and axonal loss (atrophy).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative PACS2 E209K pathogenic substitution is solely responsible for patients presenting with PACS2 Syndrome, yet the mechanisms that lead to the neurodevelopmental defects remain largely unknown. In this proposal, we will use modern molecular biology and stem cell techniques combined with neuroscience tools to identify functional consequences resulting in alterations in neural differentiation and excitability. Understanding at a cellular and molecular level the basis for how the PACS2 E209K substitution affects the developing nervous system, may lay the foundation for novel therapeutic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose the first histologically-validated and detailed anatomical study using ultra-high resolution MRI of the human cerebellar cortex. The human cerebellar cortex contains the majority of neurons in the central nervous system and is increasingly recognized as being affected in a range of neurological disorders, but there is little detailed knowledge about its anatomical organization, particularly the architecture of the molecular layer. Results will elucidate the three-dimensional anatomical organization of the human cerebellar cortex and relate it to MRI based measures to produce validated methodologies that can be employed translationally to detect structural alterations in clinical populations.

PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because of the critical need for more effective treatments for osteoarthritis (OA), which is a common disease with a large societal impact. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low back pain affects almost half of all Americans per year and is the most common reason for which opioids are prescribed. Multiple randomized controlled trials have demonstrated that early referral to physical therapy in the outpatient setting is efficacious for low back pain, but it is unknown whether these same benefits can be extended to patients evaluated by physical therapists in emergency department settings. This multi-site feasibility trial will test the feasibility and fidelity of an “embedded” emergency department physical therapy intervention for low back pain in preparation for a future full-scale multi-site trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optic nerve injuries often lead to the degeneration of retinal ganglion cells causing irreversible blindness. While the late stages of degeneration, in which retinal cells die, are well studied, much less is known about the earliest signs of retinal dysfunction following these injuries. We are developing a new preparation of the intact, perfused mouse eye where, for the first time, we will be able to make chronic recordings of retinal ganglion cells for hours to days after optic nerve cut and map the earliest changes in their light responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The loss of skeletal muscle mass can occur through genetic or external factors such as disease, hospitalization, or aging, and affect the quality of life for many people. In my proposal, I address this problem by studying an important protein (Ubiquitin Protein Ligase E3 Component N-Recognin 5) to determine its role in the development of skeletal muscle atrophy and growth. Findings from my proposal have great potential to improve the lives of people impacted by muscle wasting and may provide a basis for new therapeutic strategies to be identified.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To date, science has not produced a detailed elucidation of the circuitry involved in the physiological and emotional response to pain. The goal of this project is to identify the neural mechanisms through which surgical and neuropathic pain alters circuit function dynorphin-expressing neurons in the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC). Because the mPFC is a key node in the emotional network of the brain, findings from this project should produce critical knowledge regarding the affective dimension of pain and pain disorders that could lead to novel strategies for analgesic therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wastewater research and surveillance can provide early warning of the spread of known diseases of public health importance and inform public health responses, but it can also provide highly sensitive and potentially stigmatizing information, raising ELSI considerations, including how to manage return of results in a way that maximizes the benefits of wastewater research and public health surveillance and builds public trust while protecting privacy and avoiding the exacerbation of health inequities. We propose an innovative embedded ELSI research project that will directly impact the development and implementation of strategies for results dissemination from a statewide wastewater research and surveillance program in Texas. This project will collect critical empirical data from stakeholders and engage diverse members of the community to identify and develop strategies to address the ethical, legal, and social implications of return of results from public health research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The breakdown of hydroxyproline, a component of collagen, significantly contributes to the heightened synthesis of oxalate resulting in kidney stone formation as well as renal damage in those with primary hyperoxaluria, especially types 2 and 3. This proposal focuses on the development and optimization of drugs that will block this process and prevent such occurrences in those afflicted with these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It has been recognized that there is a deficiency in adequately trained cancer physicians that will grow by 2025. The rapid nature of innovation in cancer research creates added challenges for trained medical, radiation, surgical, pediatric, and gynecologic oncologists who will form the next generation of researchers with backgrounds that support and optimize clinically relevant investigation. The Columbia Paul Calabresi Clinical Oncology Training Program (K12) will provide an ideal setting in which outstanding and comprehensive clinical research training can assure a cadre of future well-trained clinical investigators who will have the greatest impact on cancer care in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance This proposed R21 will provide an innovative examination of the causal impact of the Covid-19 mortality shock in France and the United States by combining important developments in the formal demography of cohort survivorship with a novel cohort discontinuity causal identification strategy. Findings from this study will break new ground by providing evidence on the impact of Covid-19 on cohort mortality and the degree to which Covid-19 may have offset or reversed pre-pandemic improvements in cohort survival. Our proposed analyses of data for France and the United States will provide credible causal evidence relevant to ongoing mortality research and debates on racial disparities, health systems, pension schemes, and population dynamics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to develop the adult Danionella cerebrum, a close relative to zebrafish (Danio rerio), for optical-based studies of kidney-related disease mechanisms. This novel model will provide advantages and serve as an attractive alternative to existing animal models because its small size, optical transparency, and ease of use. Development of this novel adult disease model will facilitate future studies allowing for the in vivo visualization of cell signaling events and cell-cell interactions responsible for kidney disease initiation and resolution, or disease progression and development of end stage renal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite 85% of women giving birth in their lifetimes, we know remarkably little about how the human brain changes during pregnancy and the consequences these changes on mood and cognition. The longitudinal project will provide insights into the neurobiological changes across pregnancy using multiple magnetic resonance imaging modalities, how hormonal shifts may influence these changes, and whether brain changes are associated with mood, cognition, and mental health. The findings will contribute fundamental knowledge on the human brain with translational relevance for the individuals and families affected by peripartum depression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Even though the emerging evidence-base for low-dose buprenorphine inductions is promising, these approaches are difficult to implement in the emergency department (ED) or outpatient setting. Existing evidence suggests extended-release buprenorphine injection may function as a low-dose induction due to its pharmacokinetic properties, which if safe will permit buprenorphine to be administered without waiting for withdrawal. We therefore propose to conduct a study to evaluate the safety and pharmacokinetics of using extended-release buprenorphine as a low-dose induction strategy and lay the groundwork for a randomized trial in the ED and outpatient setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative Despite habits' essential role in everyday decision-making and in the cultivation of healthy lifestyles, and despite their relevance to many psychiatric conditions, cognitive neuroscientists have struggled to systematically and experimentally study how habits are formed and expressed. We hypothesize that habits can be robustly revealed when humans are induced to naturally disengage control in situations that mimic the hierarchical nature of their real-life decision-making, where choices made in a deliberate way are then executed in a more automated way. We will develop a new experimental protocol following this insight, investigate its ability to disentangle habits from control processes, and test the the validity of our hypothesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project will test a multimodal neurotherapeutics intervention approach for treatment resistant depression. Specifically, we will test the combination of FDA-approved repetitive Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (rTMS) with breath-focused attention training targeted towards suppression of default mode network activity. The R61 phase will focus on dose response for neural target engagement, while the R33 phase will replicate neural target engagement and also aim to show improvement in cognitive control and greater symptom response to treatment in a randomized controlled trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: LAY ABSTRACT Understanding of the shared and distinct molecular bases of risk for neuropsychiatric disorders is necessary for developing prevention and treatment strategies. In this proposal, we quantify circRNA in PsychoENCODE cohort and other public datasets. We will use these to generate genetically regulated circRNA expression models and then apply these models to genome-wide association studies of Psychiatric disorders to understand shared and non-shared pathways of risk across linear and circ transcripts.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abnormalities in the calvaria (upper part of the skull) are a major class of birth defects in humans. The proposed project will provide detailed information on the genetic regulation of calvarial development with a focus on Fbn1, a human birth defect gene. The knowledge gained from this project can help devise new methods for diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of birth defects affecting the calvaria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) is a common chronic condition that affects over a billion people worldwide. Current assessments of OSA severity and other physiological mechanisms require a burdensome in-lab polysomnography study, and while at-home sleep tests are becoming popular, they do not necessarily measure pertinent physiological signals. In this proposal, we will develop and validate a novel, nanotechnology enabled, adhesive-like wearable (SLEEPTRONIX) that is capable of measuring sleep and breathing patterns for multiple nights in addition to temperature and cortisol.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a vascular disease that affects 5-10% of men and 1% of women over the age of 65, ranking as the thirteenth leading cause of death in the United States. Unfortunately, there are no pharmacological treatments available for the prevention of AAA progression and rupture; the only option for these patients is surgical intervention. The purpose of this project is to examine the potential for healing programs in the platelets and macrophages of the unique Acomys regenerative mouse model in order to develop viable therapeutic options in human AAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Respiratory viruses are a major public health problem, with SARS-CoV-2 causing more than 1.1 million deaths in the U.S. since 2020, and influenza typically causing hundreds of thousands of hospitalizations each winter season. Interferons are proteins made by the body that protect against respiratory viruses, but regulation of this response is critical, because excessive interferons can cause tissue damage. This project will define the role of a unique type of interferon in the respiratory tract in fine-tuning the balance between defense and tissue damage, and this new understanding will ultimately inform new strategies to prevent respiratory virus infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The cerebellum is an evolutionary old brain area, whose role in sensorimotor integration and motor learning is well studied. However, little is known about cerebellar interactions with other brain centers, such as the neocortex, although emerging evidence points to a role in cortical development, cognitive control and related disorders. Here, we propose to study whether cerebellar climbing fibers – known to provide an instructive signal in cerebellar learning – are able to similarly supervise cortical plasticity, using receptive field plasticity in the mouse barrel cortex as a test case.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE This project focuses on a heritable ectopic calcification disorder, pseudoxanthoma elasticum (PXE), for which there is no effective or specific treatment currently available. The proposed studies will utilize previously established rodent models as a platform to apply novel AAV-based ABCC6 gene therapy targeting the underlying genetic cause of ectopic calcification in PXE. Successful studies in animals as proposed in this application could then lead to a new treatment strategy for clinical trials in patients with PXE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Vision depends on a complex network of brain regions, but little is known about visual processing in higher- order, multimodal areas of the medial temporal lobes (MTL). In our prior work we established that the MTL plays a critical role in visual perception of complex materials. However, the specific functional role (or roles) that the MTL plays in supporting visual perception is just beginning to be understood, and there are now several competing theories about the role that different regions within the MTL, such as the different hippocampal subfields, play in visual perception. The proposal aims to determine how regions within the MTL contribute to complex scene perception and visual working memory using a combination of studies examining patients with focal lesions to specific MTL subregions, high-resolution functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), eye monitoring methods, and several novel psychophysical paradigms. The studies aim to understand how the brain supports high-level visual processes, and will provide a more complete characterization of the cognitive deficits associated with temporal lobe damage suffered by various psychiatric and neurological populations, which is essential in the development of targeted rehabilitation strategies that better capitalize on both the disrupted and the spared functions in such patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The disruption of connections between the eye and the brain causes irreversible vision loss. The proposed research will develop the novel use of stem cell therapies and nerve relays to restore the lost connections between the eye and the brain and enable whole eye transplants. This is relevant to public health because restoring vision and reversing blindness would significantly improve the lives of individuals blinded by optic neuropathies or retinal disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an aggressive breast cancer subtype with higher incidence and worse clinical outcomes for non-Hispanic Black (NHB) and Hispanic women compared to non-Hispanic White women (NHW), even when risks are adjusted for clinical and socio-economic factors. We recently identified four TNBC subtypes robustly prognostic for therapy response based on BRCA1/2 gene status and the level of expression of an immune-related gene signature. Here, we propose to determine the prevalence of these distinct molecular subtypes in NHW, NHB, and Hispanic TNBC patients to assess whether they disproportionally occur in specific racial/ethnic groups and may therefore contribute to the observed disparities in therapy response outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neonates and infants are highly susceptible to infections, particularly those caused by intracellular pathogens, because their protective CD4 T helper 1 responses have not reached adult levels. A subset of Innate-like T cells, unlike conventional CD4 T cells, are poised for rapid Th1 responses in early life, and may have protective roles against intracellular pathogens, but our understanding of their function in infants is limited. We propose an approach based on the analysis of transcriptional and chromatin accessibility profiles in the cord blood innate- like cells to study their function, with the long-term goal of learning how to harness their potential to improve infant responses to vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: In the short term, this work will provide new knowledge showing that healthy lifestyle adherence improves BC outcomes through enhanced anti-tumor immunity (increased infiltration of activated CD8+ T cells). In the long term, this work has the potential to uncover novel, clinically significant immunologic insights revealing that lifestyle intervention could be used as a non-invasive clinical strategy, especially in the context of boosting the efficacy of immunotherapy and other standard or novel therapies by way of shifting a cold tumor hot. Wherein the immune system is a major player in treatment response and efficacy, such developments would be especially impactful for populations who are disproportionately diagnosed with aggressive tumors (i.e., TNBC) that are less responsive to current treatments, including immunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Our current understanding of how blockages in human coronary arteries become unstable is incomplete, and our ability to predict future heart attacks in patients who have had blockages treated with stents and balloons is limited. We have developed a novel way to determine the genes expressed in human coronary plaques by obtaining the genetic material from balloons used when blockages are opened. These data will provide a deeper understanding of human coronary atherosclerosis, show important biological differences between stable and unstable plaques, identify potential therapeutic targets, and establish a new tool to predict the future risk of heart attacks in patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sex differences in concussion is important but little studied. We propose to develop subject-specific multiscale computational models to study the biomechanical basis of sex differences in concussion and subconcussion. We will characterize sex differences and validate the approach with a range of biomarkers using data from male and female athletes participating in contact sports and noncontact controls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: There are few training programs devoted to training of PhD nurse-scientists in cancer research so that they may develop independent research careers. This is a critical gap since nurse-scientists are in the best position to perform research focused on patients, families, and communities and translate this knowledge into improved cancer delivery and care. Importantly, while the emerging field of “symptom science” has been driven by nurse-scientists, there are remarkably few opportunities for them to acquire the oncology background needed for other areas of cancer research. This new K12 proposal addresses this gap while also aiming to increase representation of nurse-scientists from underrepresented backgrounds into the ranks of cancer researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Aged individuals are more prone to develop long-term cognitive impairment as a result of sepsis, and peripheral immune cell infiltration resulting from blood brain barrier alterations during the acute severe infection phase is emerging as a key mechanism linked to cognitive impairment and increased dementia risk associated with these infections. We have identified that the LHCGR ligand, hCG, has powerful neuroimmune regulating capabilities and improves cognition in impaired rodent models. Therefore, we seek to address the therapeutic value of hCG on sepsis-induced cognitive dysfunction and evaluate the neuroinflammatory mechanisms underlying such effects in the aged brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Viridans group streptococci are bacteria that commonly cause life-threatening bloodstream infections in patients with hematologic cancers who have few white blood cells because of chemotherapy. These bacteria are often resistant to fluoroquinolone antibiotics used to prevent infections in these patients. The proposed research is relevant to public health and NIH’s mission because understanding how often patients with hematologic cancers carry fluoroquinolone-resistant viridans group streptococci in their mouth, how to best screen for carriage of these bacteria and how mouth carriage increases the risk of bloodstream infection, could lead to the design of novel individualized strategies to prevent these infections in this vulnerable patient population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative This research will investigate the role of gonadal hormones (estrogen in females, testosterone in males) in programming adolescent development of the mesocorticolimbic dopamine circuit, which is functionally linked to motivation, reward, and cognitive control. Studies will reveal how hormones influence typical maturation and within what developmental window(s) these influences can occur, and how typical maturation can go awry (e.g., atypical timing of puberty onset). Knowing how typical maturation can go awry will provide novel insights into the developmental processes during puberty and adolescence that could lead to the emergence of psychopathology marked by deficits in cognitive control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Our mixed methods study will use a bioethics environmental justice framework and collaboration with key community-based stakeholders to develop a home-based family child care intervention that will evaluate the impact of reporting back results of pesticides identified in the facilities on adoption of strategies to reduce pesticide exposure. The study will enroll family child care homes in marginalized, primarily Latinx, Central Valley counties in California. Qualitative and quantitative findings will inform the process of reporting back pesticide exposures, impact of reporting back as part of an integrated pest management intervention, and development of best practices for reporting back pesticide exposures in family child care homes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is a significant and lifelong threat to health and quality of life for the ~100,000 autistic youth who transition to adulthood each year in the United States. The transition to adulthood represents a critical window for obesity treatment, and there is no existing comprehensive treatment for obesity designed specifically for autistic individuals transitioning to adulthood. This project will identify a set of stakeholder-generated and prioritized testable treatment components that will lay the foundation for optimization of an obesity intervention for transition- age autistic youth that is stakeholder-accepted, effective, and maximized for implementation and community uptake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: To develop effective interventions for Parkinson's disease, it is crucial to understand the wide variety of conformations adopted by α-synuclein (α-syn) protein aggregates. This project aims to bridge the gap between in vitro and in vivo models by investigating how cellular environments influence the propagation of α-syn fibril conformations. By leveraging advanced sensitivity-enhancement technology and biosensor cell lines, we will gain atomic-level insights into the structural features of α-syn fibrils inside cells, facilitating the development of selective ligands for targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: We hypothesize that stress plays a major role in health-related quality of life (HRQOL) among long-term breast cancer (BC) survivors. In this R21 pilot study, we will collect data on both individual-level (cancer-specific and social stressors) and neighborhood-level stressors and HRQOL for 270 long-term BC survivors, and collect blood samples to measure inflammatory biomarkers that may mediate the stressor-HRQOL relationships. The study findings will inform the design of a larger study of stress, inflammation, and HRQOL, as well as the development of targeted interventions to improve HRQOL for the growing number of long-term BC survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative How are specific neural circuits established in a cortex where neurons with different preferences are spatially intermixed? Here we consider the hypothesis that the visual properties of receptive fields of V1 neurons correlate with transcriptomic cell types, which also guide their projection patterns and orchestrate the wiring of local and long-range connections. The project addresses one of NEI’s strategic priorities: to improve the understanding of neural activity and molecular events in the formation of central visual circuits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The rat has emerged as a surrogate for studying vocal fold atrophy due to the lack of accessible human donor larynges. However, the rat's thyroarytenoid muscle fiber composition differs from that of humans, raising concerns about the validity of rat models and our understanding of critical biochemical processes. This proposal aims to compare atrophic responses in muscles with varying fiber types to determine the relevance of fiber type in atrophy and ultimately develop novel therapeutic strategies for individuals with voice-related disabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Endoscopies are commonly performed for various diagnostic purposes, and 3D understanding is typically done in the mind of the clinician performing the procedure and analyzing the endoscopy videos. However current state-of-the-art techniques for 3D reconstruction use camera motion only and do not work well or fail entirely for real organs since they lack strong geometric features, have highly reflective mucus layers, and often deform over time. In this project, we address these challenges by explicitly modeling the reflection of light from mucus layers and by accounting for time-varying deformation to obtain 3D reconstructions of unprecedented quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The overall objective of this proposal is to optimize, validate, and evaluate the effectiveness of strategies for reporting back environmental sampling results to rural Native American populations, with a focus on the balance between real-time and delayed feedback for both acute and chronic exposure concerns. The bioethical question of interest is: How does the information source (i.e., the messenger, format, and/or timing of education) impact the effectiveness of report-back strategies in rural tribal populations? The ultimate outputs of this work will be a set of validated guidance on the most effective approaches, with a focus on increasing engagement with exposure-reduction activities in rural tribal populations, informing the broader research community, and helping build local capacity for the sustainability of evaluation activities in these populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kidney disease is a common complication for patients with diabetes that can progress to kidney failure and death and our research has shown that the hormone aldosterone may play an important role in causing kidney disease in patients with diabetes. Since there are widely available medications that can prevent aldosterone- mediated kidney disease, it is critical to understand how aldosterone may cause diabetic-kidney disease. This proposal will investigate the presence of excess aldosterone among people with diabetes to characterize whether aldosterone-blocking medications may prevent kidney disease in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Levodopa (L-dopa) remains the front-line therapy for treatment of motor disorders associated with Parkinson’s disease. However, metabolism by the gut microbiome reduces the concentration of L-dopa available for uptake into the brain, complicates determination of optimal dosage, and may contribute to the need for dose escalation over the course of the disease. Treatment with a probiotic that mitigates L-dopa metabolism by the gut microbiome is a promising and novel approach to enhance the effectiveness of oral L-dopa therapy in Parkinson’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative There is a need for non-invasive, real-time bedside tools to monitor brain health in newborns with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) at risk for brain injury. We propose a novel, low- cost, wearable near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) device able to continuously measure the oxidation state of cytochrome c (oxCCO), a marker of cerebral metabolism, in newborns at risk for brain injury after hypoxia-ischemia. The successful development, validation, and demonstration of clinical feasibility and effectiveness of this proposed technology will lead to the opportunity to intervene at the bedside to reduce brain injury and improve neurodevelopmental outcome.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Multiple factors have been found to hinder older adults’ ability to fully optimize their use of patient portals and their ability to retrieve and understand lab test results. In this project, we will employ a user-centered approach to develop and evaluate a working prototype of a patient-engagement tool called LabGenie specifically designed to aid older adults’ comprehension of lab results by providing visualizations of lab test results and tailored question prompts to help them prepare for follow-up consultations. Our long-term goal is to integrate these innovative technologies and approaches into patient portals and to conduct a large-scale randomized controlled trial to evaluate the efficacy of the enhanced system on improving older adults' self-management of chronic conditions.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: LabGenie: A Patient-Engagement Tool to Aid Older Adults' Understanding of Lab Test Results

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is a leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide, but the mechanisms underlying optic nerve damage are poorly understood. This is partly due to a lack of adequate model systems to test mechanisms of optic nerve cellular dysfunction. This proposal aims to develop a 3D model system of human optic nerve head cells to test how pathologic mechanical strains induce tissue fibrosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple negative breast cancer is a frequently recurring and metastatic disease with dismal survival rate among the African American (AA) compared to the European American (EA) women. Early detection of the aggressive lesions and their recurrent prediction may significantly reduce the disparity gaps in terms of disease associated morbidity and mortality. The present study aims to develop an mtDNA based novel liquid biomarker tool for early detection and monitoring of the racially disparate population to ultimately improve their overall survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondrial ATP synthase houses a leak channel that is activated during ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury. This project will investigate the single-particle cryo-EM structure of Artemia franciscana ATP synthase, a mysterious organism that tolerates profound calcium concentrations and survives anoxic conditions for years. Successful completion of this project will reveal distinct structural features of ATP synthase that enable brine shrimp to resist extreme anoxic conditions and will unlock the development of new therapeutics for treating I/R injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to understand the function of molecules inside living cells (such as proteins and DNA), we need tools that can visualize these molecules at a high level of detail. Although cryo-electron microscopy and tomography imaging allow researchers to visualize the 3D structure of life-like preserved molecules, both purified and inside unperturbed cells, there are still technical limitations (e.g., localization and identification of molecules in cryo-tomograms) that can be improved. Therefore, we propose to develop new tools and strategies to address these limitations so that we can better understand the structure and function of biomolecules, and the inner workings of cells in health and disease, and to potentially use this knowledge to design effective therapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial/ethnic inequities in chemical exposures from consumer product use are shaped by social-structural factors and can amplify health disparities across the life course. Reporting back research results to individuals can help advance environmental health literacy and drive collective action; however, we currently lack best practices for ethical report back of consumer product chemical data to multiply marginalized groups. This project will build on an existing community-engaged consumer product exposure study (Taking Stock) in order to enhance current report back methods by centering intersectionality and to advance the field from right-to-know to right-to-understand.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Elevated urinary oxalate excretion heightens the risk of calcium oxalate kidney stone formation and may increase the risk of progression of chronic kidney disease. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease which affects approximately 25% of the US population is associated with increased urinary oxalate excretion. The goal of this project is to generate preliminary data for a larger multi-disciplinary/multi-institutional NIH application focused on the mechanisms of endogenous oxalate synthesis in calcium oxalate kidney stone formers with and without NAFLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance/Narrative Understanding the complex workings of the immune system is crucial for the relevance of health and disease, as it serves as our body's intricate defense mechanism against illnesses. The development of a label-free dynamic imaging tool is essential to further this understanding. By enabling real-time observation of immune cells in their natural state, this tool can potentially facilitate personalized treatment approaches and ultimately improve health outcomes for individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Light sheet fluorescence microscopy has greatly expanded our capability to visualize, track and quantify biological dynamics with high spatiotemporal resolution, but its adoption in biomedical research is limited due to its incompatibility with widely used high-throughput sample holders like multi-well plates or microfluidic chips. Our proposal aims to address this incompatibility issue by integrating optical metasurfaces with light sheet fluorescence microscopy, enabling the development of open-top light sheet imaging systems for high-throughput noninvasive 4D imaging in live cells and multicellular organisms. To demonstrate the efficacy of our approach, we will develope a metasurface-integrated lattice light sheet microscope and apply it for high-content molecular dynamic mapping of chimeric antigen receptor T (CAR-T) cells and organelle profiling of zebrafish development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Substance use disorders such as opioid addiction affect millions of adults in the United States each year, but the delivery of high-quality, effective addiction services is disrupted by organizational issues such as counselor burnout and turnover. Clinical supervisors are essential for supporting counselors in specialty addiction treatment programs, but few supervisors receive supervision-focused training. This project seeks to modify and pilot an evidence-based supervision strategy that has a high potential to enhance supervision and result in improved counselors' well-being and performance and, in turn, to improve client outcomes.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to acquire a state-of-the-art high-power pulsed Q-band Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectrometer as a multi-user shared instrument, to be managed by the Integrated Molecular Structure Education and Research Center (IMSERC) facility. The research scope of the major users is broad, and ranges from structural biology of folded proteins and intrinsically disordered proteins that are targets for therapeutics development, or of biomolecular assembly that serve as platforms to modulate live cellular activities. This will be the first pulsed Q-band EPR instrument established at NU for a shared user facility, with a critical focus on dissemination of the powerful EPR structural biology tools to a broad user base by establishing robust workflows for sample preparation, measurements, sample storage and automated data processing.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Smith-Magenis syndrome (SMS) is an autosomal dominant neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by the deletion of one Rai1 allele (Retinoic Acid Induced-1). As a transcription factor, this deletion causes a reduction in Rai1 expression and concomitant changes in expression of downstream targets, many critical to neurodevelopment and function. We have assembled a small library that were selected based on their ability to increase Rai1 expression. Our overarching goal is to demonstrate that Rai1 expression in SMS can be increased using a pharmacologic approach and many of the transcriptomic defects can be corrected.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sexual and gender minority (SGM) individuals are often diagnosed with late-stage cancer and often die from cancer prematurely; however, the cancer-specific needs of SGM people are under-reported and therefore under-studied. Our preliminary data reveals that oncology clinicians’ reluctance to ask about sexual orientation and gender identity is a root cause for the lack of systematic collection of SOGI information. This R03 application will enable the principal investigator to refine a concise, innovative training module for oncology clinicians focused on why and how to ask about patient sexual orientation and gender identity in cancer clinics, based directly upon formative clinician and SGM patient feedback, with an ultimate goal to improve affirming cancer care for SGM people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Anorexia nervosa (AN) is a lethal psychiatric disease that disproportionately affects female-identified individuals and has high relapse rates (~35-41%), leading to chronic comorbidities and lifelong disability. Despite recent findings that AN susceptibility can be linked to genetic and metabolic factors, the neurobiology coordinating the preference and motivational drive for a starved rather than sated state is not well studied. The proposed research will examine the mechanisms used by hunger-promoting hypothalamic neurons that promote bodyweight gain in an animal model of AN using a combination of knock-in mouse models, and circuit-based behavioral neuroscience approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative The cornea is the transparent, outermost layer of the eye. Disease can cause the cornea to become cloudy, resulting in vision loss. We aim to use experimental data and computer modeling to understand the complex functional interactions between three membrane-transport proteins MCT1, NBCe1, and SLC4A11. This multidisciplinary project will provide new insights about corneal function and how NBCe1 and SLC4A11 mutations cause vision loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is a blinding disease that affects millions of people worldwide, but the underlying mechanisms are incompletely understood. This stems, in part, from a lack of model systems that accurately replicate the fluid drainage tissues responsible for intraocular pressure regulation. This work seeks to engineer a novel tissue platform that faithfully models the complex architecture and function of the outflow tract to facilitate improved investigations of glaucoma causes for identification of potential cures in the future.

PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use has been suggested to induce and exacerbate flare periods and the pathology in patients suffering from colitis. These studies are likely to help in developing new therapeutic strategies to maintain gut homeostasis and protect it from alcohol mediated exacerbation of symptoms associated colitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – ROLE OF JMJD4 IN BREAST CANCER Breast cancer constitutes the second most lethal malignancy for women in the US, indicating the dire need to develop novel efficacious therapies. Our research will elucidate how the JMJD4 enzyme facilitates the development of this disease. This may also nominate JMJD4 as a potential novel target for therapy in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The poor survival rate of African Americans (AA) in lung cancer underscores insights into molecules responsible for the oncogenic progression of benign pulmonary nodules in AA. We identified an AA-specific pfeRNA following the requirements of a CLIA-compliant LDT and will provide mechanistic rationale and therapeutic insights into this druggable pfeRNA. The project will provide a new opportunity to reduce racial and ethnic health disparities in AA with NSCLC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will design and tailor interventions and develop plans for a large-scale trial to test these interventions to implement high quality active surveillance among men with favorable-risk prostate cancer. By identifying interventions to improve the quality of active surveillance, we will ensure its sustainability and protect against avoidable cancer morbidity. By focusing on scalable interventions, we will ensure that those developed can be implemented across large population groups.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Many environmental carcinogens are agents that damage DNA in target cells, creating characteristic patterns of mutations called “mutational signatures”, which are often found in human tumors. By leveraging a highly-sensitive sequencing technology, this proposal focuses on the development of a blood-based analytical method that can identify environmental carcinogen exposure by their mutational imprints found on circulating cell-free DNA in the blood. The identification of such biomarkers of carcinogen exposure can subsequently guide cancer risk assessment, mitigate further exposure and enable early screening/early detection of cancer in high risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project narrative Spinal interoceptive pathways (SIPs) convey bodily signals to an interoceptive system in the brain and their dysregulation is linked to major depressive disorder (MDD). Based on strong preliminary evidence, we seek to investigate a novel non-invasive spinal cord stimulation approach to elucidate the role of SIPs in MDD and their neuromodulation as a novel therapeutic intervention. Results are expected to generate new knowledge on the neurobiology of MDD and a novel approach to study and treat MDD and other psychiatric disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative  The proposed research is relevant to public health because identifying the components of the cystic fibrosis airway environment that limit the microbicidal activities of immune cells against the main respiratory pathogen in cystic fibrosis, Staphylococcus aureus, is expected to advance our understanding of cystic fibrosis airway inflammation and lay down the groundwork to potentially develop new, immune system-based therapies that can help eliminate S. aureus, or other pathogens in patients of cystic fibrosis, or additional illnesses.  Thus, the proposed research is important to the mission of the NIH by developing fundamental knowledge that will help to fight human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients diagnosed with glioblastoma (GBM) have a dismally poor prognosis (~7.5% relative five-year survival) despite intense standards of care including surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. The goal of this proposal is to investigate a novel photothermal nanoparticle-based approach for generating tumor-specific T cells as an adoptive T cell therapy (ATCT) for treating GBM. The long-term goal is to use this ATCT to improve treatment outcomes for GBM patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative This research project aims to build virtual animals, specifically rats, that can behave and learn like real animals by giving them artificial 'brains' similar to those in real rats. We will teach these virtual animals to mimic rat behavior, then study how these 'brains' control this behavior to generate hypotheses about how biological brains perform similar functions. Any differences between how the virtual rats act and how real rats act will help the researchers improve their model, ultimately leading to a better understanding of how brains implement motor control.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infertility is a common public health problem that is more likely to burden Hispanic women and may increase a woman’s risk of chronic diseases (breast cancer, ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer, cardiometabolic diseases, and mortality). Within the Mexican Teacher´s Cohort, a prospective cohort of over 115,000 Hispanic women of Mexican heritage followed for 18 years, we will combine data on infertility history and specific infertility diagnoses and treatments to evaluate the relationship between infertility and the risk of chronic diseases and mortality.

PHR: Project Narrative Centrosomes are required for error-free mitosis and other cellular functions, and their deregulation drives developmental disorders, such as microcephaly and cancer. This proposal investigates novel paradigms of centrosome regulation by examining the functional consequences of mRNA localized to centrosomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurovascular disorders – including stroke, brain aneurysm, and vascular malformations – strike an estimated seven million Americans annually, and can lead to vascular pathologies, neurological disability, and death. Our ongoing research has uncovered cellular and molecular mechanisms that contribute to a neurovascular disease called brain arteriovenous malformation, a neurovascular disease with no current treatments approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Based on our preliminary data, we propose to test a pharmacological based approach to alleviate features of brain arteriovenous malformation in mice and to prevent abnormalities in cultured human brain vascular cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: A key barrier to widespread public translation and effective use of environmental and non- genomic health research findings is their inaccessibility to study participants and communities that enabled them. To address, this project aims to create ways to vastly improve availability and accessibility of research results to study participants, by enabling data sharing within and across studies, learning directly from participants to create a user-friendly, highly accessible forms of report-back of research results (RBRR). Using a process responsive to community and cultural norms, we will advance environmental health literacy, by discovering and thus leveraging people's motivations toward their decision-making toward reducing/preventing exposures to environmental contaminants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal immune cell transfer to the infant may assist in the education of the neonatal immune system. We recently demonstrated that orally feeding the probiotic Limosilactobacillus reuteri could educate circulating Tregs to become anti-inflammatory; and these T cells when adoptively transferred to newborn pups were more potent than naïve Tregs in facilitating immune tolerance. The proposed experiments will characterize probiotic- modulated immune cells migrating from mother to infant; and we will then assess the transfer of probiotic- modulated immunity from mother to infant in the setting of an established model of autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: B. PROJECT NARRATIVE This shared instrument grant requests funding to acquire an inductively coupled plasma time-of-flight mass spectrometer (icpTOF-MS) for ultrafast multi-elemental mapping of high-value clinical (human) and preclinical (lab animal) biospecimens. The instrument will be coupled to the CBM’s existing state-of-the-art laser ablation platform at the Boston University School of Medicine Center for Biometallomics (CBM), the only hospital/medical school-based bioanalytical core facility of its kind in the region. The proposed icpTOF-MS instrument will facilitate NIH-funded research targeting Alzheimer’s disease (AD), other neurodegenerative diseases, traumatic brain injury, cardiovascular disease, chronic renal disease, degenerative eye disease (cataracts, retinopathy), heavy metal toxicology, and gene-environment (exposome) interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The P2Y10 receptor (P2Y10R) was initially identified as a member of the P2Y family of nucleotide receptors based on structural similarities. This project proposes to use bioinformatic and in vivo techniques to elucidate the role of P2Y10R in Sjögren’s disease (SjD) pathophysiology. Understanding the role of P2Y10R in SjD pathophysiology could establish a druggable target for SjD pharmacotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This project will establish and characterize a novel animal model used to investigate how alcohol affects brain function through the neuroimmune response (specifically through microglia, which are the resident immune cell of the brain). We aim to engraft genetically engineered human microglia derived from stem cells into the mouse brain, allowing us to selectively enrich the molecular signature of only human microglia from the mouse brain after the mice have been exposed to alcohol. Because we are studying the human microglial response in a living animal, we anticipate the results will have higher translational relevance in order to further our understanding of the negative consequences of alcohol use disorder in the human brain.
