IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Signal regulatory protein α (SIRPα) is a polymorphic immunoglobulin receptor that is exclusively expressed on innate cells. We found that donor/recipient SIRPα mismatch is commonly detected in the setting of allo-HSCT and associated with a significantly increased risk of chronic graft-versus-host disease (cGVHD) and a reduced rate of disease relapse in various hematologic malignancies. The proposed research is to investigate the prevalence and clinical relevance of SIRPα mismatch in allo-HSCT from matched related donors (MRD), and the relative impact of SIRPα mismatch by disease type, alloimmune direction of the mismatch, and stem cell source in a registry-based large cohort from Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research (CIBMTR).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Oral and intravenous drug administration lacks spatial targeting, exposing all organs and tissues to high drug concentrations, leading to severe off-target side effects. We have recently achieved proof-of-concept for a focal drug delivery technology using polymer-based intra-arterial implants. This proposal is designed to demonstrate the platform potential of our technology, by focally delivering two different drugs to two different organs.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This S10 application requests funding to obtain a unique Human Connectome 2.0 head-only scanner, which performance will be extraordinary: maximum gradient strength of 500 mT/m and maximum slew rate of 600 T/m/s. The order-of-magnitude boost of the diffusion weightings will enable fast and distortion-free brain MRI and dramatically advance microstructural brain mapping in a wide range of neurological disorders. The addition of the Connectome 2.0 will help us transform the field of microstructure imaging, benefiting brain researchers, patients and physicians who care for them, as well as other academic medical centers within the greater New York City area.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Malaria patients frequently develop severe anemia, which can lead to death. We intend to study Xanthine Oxidase (XO), an oxidative enzyme that is upregulated during malaria and is associated with anemia in patients, to determine whether XO induces the loss of erythrocytes during malaria and whether medicines that inhibit XO could decrease malaria-induced anemia in mice models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The overarching goal of this project is to develop safe continual learning methods for early sepsis detection that can adapt to new data while avoiding catastrophic forgetting and maintaining generalization. First, we will develop methods that update a small subset of weights in the existing model based on the new data, thereby preserving the previously learned knowledge while adapting to the new information and leading to a more robust and adaptive model for early sepsis detection. Second, we will develop methods to automatically detect distribution shift from streaming sepsis data, improve the out-of-distribution generalization capability of continual learning models, and quantify their prediction uncertainty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Currently, there are no FDA-approved treatments for postoperative delirium, a condition that affects up to 80% of older adults in the Intensive Care Unit and is associated with prolonged hospital stays, elevated rates of nursing home placement, and high mortality. Perineuronal nets (PNN) – protective structures around neurons specialized in supporting cognitive functions that are impaired during delirium – hold promise in the search for new targets against delirium. By testing the role of PNN remodeling in the development of postoperative delirium, the proposed experiments aim to open up unprecedented opportunities to target PNN as a novel therapeutic approach against this devastating condition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE B cells that produce the anti-inflammatory mediator IL-10 help clear inflammation of the skin and in other sites. Certain B cells produce the chemokine CXCL10, which attracts pro-inflammatory T cells. The goal of this proposal is to test whether IL-10+ B cells produce CXCL10 to lure pro-inflammatory T cells into their vicinity and to expose them to IL-10 thereby suppressing inflammation. The results of our studies will be relevant for understanding the regulation of immune responses during inflammation, infection, and cancer.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Relatively little is known about cross-gender friendships. In the proposed study, 60 pairs cross-gender friends will be observed in a context in which friends can offer support. Girls are expected to offer more support than boys, and support is expected to be related to positive perceptions of the friendships, so findings may be useful for promoting positive cross-gender interactions.

PHR: Project Narrative Penicillin allergic patients who receive 2nd line antibiotics for surgical site infection (SSI) prophylaxis are at higher risk of postoperative SSIs. We silenced low risk penicillin allergy alerts in our 14-hospital healthcare system. We propose to measure how much this changed SSI prophylaxis prescribing and SSI rates in our healthcare system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse midline gliomas (DMGs) are fatal brain tumors in children. Our studies indicate that targeting the metabolic enzyme glyoxalase 1 is lethal in combination with radiation for DMGs, and that deuterium metabolic imaging provides an early readout of response to therapy. Our proposal has the potential to enable precision metabolic therapy and imaging for DMG patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative: Commercially marketed ∆8-THC products were found to have several contaminants (impurities) resulting from the chemical conversion of hemp-derived CBD to ∆8-THC. This project is directed towards the isolation and purification of those impurities in sufficient amounts to study their pharmacology and their interaction with ∆8-THC. In vitro and in vivo studies will be carried out on each impurity to delineate their individual effects as well as their effects on ∆8-THC activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood vessels in the central nervous system (CNS) have specialized properties, termed the blood-brain barrier (BBB), that facilitate proper CNS function. The BBB is an obstacle to CNS drug delivery and BBB dysfunction contributes to several neurological disorders. In this project, we investigate the cells and molecules that establish the BBB in diverse vertebrate species, which will provide fundamental insights into how the BBB evolved and may yield new strategies to modulate the BBB to treat disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Several lines of evidence suggest that a gut-microbiota-brain axis connection is involved in the pathophysiology of ME/CFS. Mice that received fecal transplants from human donors with other neuroimmune diseases present with behavioral alterations consistent with these diseases, suggesting that fecal transplants may be used to create humanized mouse models of ME/CFS. Therefore, we propose to develop humanized mouse models of ME/CFS by using stool from ME/CFS subjects and healthy controls. Fecal transplants will be made using C57BL/6J mice and Hu-CD34+ NSG-SGM3 transgenic mice engrafted with a human immune system. We will then evaluate these mice for behavioral alterations and mucosal and neuroimmune alterations consistent with ME/CFS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Relevance Autism spectrum disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder that affects approximately 1% of the population, and is defined by social communication impairments, repetitive behaviors, and alterations in sensory and sensorimotor processing. This work will reveal how dysfunction in the autism-linked gene SCN2A disrupts sensory and sensorimotor processing in the brain, and will test whether novel therapeutic methods that restore SCN2A expression to normal levels can rescue cellular, network, and behavioral alterations in a mouse model of Scn2a disruption. This may enable development of novel therapies for severe genetic forms of autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Congenital heart disease (CHD) affects about 40,000 births per year (1%) in the United States and these children frequently need surgery to repair the problem. This project aims to develop, validate, and clinically evaluate a patient-specific heart simulator that will allow surgeons to compare repair techniques for children with single-ventricle physiology. This simulator will enable doctors to make more informed decisions about the best surgical approach for each kid in order to improve their heart health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH

Antibody drugs, which comprise a large fraction of the drugs developed in recent years, are directed against cell surface proteins and their ligands, so the ability to find interactions in an efficient manner may lead to the identification of new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to test the hypothesis that the high incidence of pain in the elderly is due to hyperalgesic priming, caused by cellular senescence and systemic inflammation. Elucidating the Type of priming, the nociceptor population in which it occurs, the role of mitochondrial dysfunction, and the sex differences in priming could provide valuable information about pain mechanisms in the elderly, leading to a more effective and personalized management of their chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Air pollution is an emergent environmental risk factor for neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs), but neurotoxicity profiles of different types of air pollution and gene by environment impacts are lacking. This study will establish Drosophila melanogaster as a model for the analysis of air pollution neurotoxicity by conducting behavioral analyses and metabolomic profiling following developmental exposure to diesel exhaust. Because phenotypic outcomes will be delineated in both wild-type flies and a fragile X syndrome model of Drosophila, this research holds the potential to create a rapid in vivo system both for air pollution neurotoxicity risk assessment and for studying gene-environment interactions relevant to NDDs.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this S10 shared-instrumentation grant is to obtain a BD FACSymphony S6 cell sorter to be placed in the Flow Cytometry Core of the California National Primate Research Center, where it will be dedicated primarily to use in translational, preclinical studies with nonhuman primates. This instrument will significantly benefit studies spanning research domains including immunology, infectious disease, gene therapy and somatic cell genome editing, regenerative medicine and stem cell transplantation, cardiovascular disease, cancer, and neurodevelopment—all to be addressed across the lifespan from pediatrics to geriatrics. The BD FACSymphony S6 will allow investigators to make observations at the single-cell level using samples from nonhuman primates, leading to new mechanistic understanding and eventually improved medical care.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will test the effectiveness of TOGA-DKD, a pharmacist-led transition of care intervention, to improve guideline adherence in patients with diabetic kidney disease identified during a hospitalization. Study pharmacists will meet with patients and their hospital teams before discharge to ensure prescribing of guideline medication and will follow up post-discharge to ensure adherence to the new medication. The knowledge about feasibility gained will demonstrate hospitalization as a viable population health implementation opportunity that can be used to mitigate health disparities in guideline adherence.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Transitions of care program to make guideline-based recommendations actionable for patients with diabetic kidney disease (TOGA-DKD)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: Project Narrative Despite WTCHR Survivor’s high rates of 9-11-related and subsequent losses, minimal research has focused on the examination of grief responses (including the presence of PGD) and their effects on mental (including cognitive difficulties), social, environmental, and physical health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in this population while accounting for the effects of gender, race, and ethnicity. Using existing WTCHR data regarding 9/11 trauma burden and newly-collected information (regarding other traumas, bereavement burden, physical and mental health burden, grief severity, HRQoL, and cognitive difficulties), we will examine the complex inter-relationships among these variables to outline risk pathways in order to better inform WTCHP programming. We also intend to examine whether WTCHR Survivors at-risk for PGD have access to or would engage in grief-specific treatments, given that treatments for PTSD, depression, and anxiety disorders have not been engaged by all WTCHR participants.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Grief and health-related quality of life in WTCHR Survivors: Associations with bereavement, trauma exposures, and mental and physical health conditions

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The North Carolina Occupational Safety and Health Education and Research Center’s (NC OSHERC) education and research program is designed to prepare practitioners and researchers in occupational health and safety (OHS), with a specific focus given to training diverse, underrepresented, and minority practitioners and researchers. In turn, these professionals protect and promote the health and safety of our nation’s workforce. Education and research in OHS are essential to eliminate work-related hazards, improve workplace safety, and promote worker well-being of all workers.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it addresses a major knowledge gap in our understanding of recurrent pregnancy loss by investigating male factor causes. This study will identify abnormalities in the quality of sperm and establish a new clinical paradigm to include diagnostic sperm testing of men with recurrent pregnancy loss. Thus, the proposed research is highly relevant to the NICHD's mission to elucidate the molecular mechanisms of early pregnancy loss.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African American oropharyngeal cancer patients present with more advanced disease and fail conventional treatment at a higher rate compared to their white counterparts. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a six week long undergraduate summer institute in Biostatistics and Data Science: “Transforming Analytical Learning in the Era of Big Data” to be held each summer (2022-2026) at the Department of Biostatistics, University of Michigan (U-M), Ann Arbor, with a group of approximately 30 undergraduate students. The trainees will be taught and mentored by a team of interdisciplinary faculty from Biostatistics, Statistics, Computer Science and Engineering, Epidemiology and Medicine, reflecting the shared intellectual landscape needed for biomedical Big Data research. Research projects will be identified in collaboration with clinicians and public health scientists with a focus on cardiovascular and infectious diseases. The program will offer a strong professional development component and a module on the role of data science in enhancing diversity, equity and inclusion values in society. The resources developed for the summer institute, including lectures, assignments, projects, template codes and datasets will be freely available through a Wiki page and a YouTube channel. This democratic dissemination plan will lead to access of teaching and training material in this new field across the world and allow others to replicate and adapt this program. The overarching goal of our summer institute in big data is to recruit and train the next generation of data scientists using a non- traditional, action-basedlearning paradigm and engage them in influential research related to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: Project Narrative: Cancer health disparities impact millions of people across the US and around the globe. Cancer health disparities are not only associated with poor access to health care, co-morbidities, chronic stress, and ancestry, but also correspond to cultural, socio-economic, biological, and environmental factors. Over the next three years, this conference will continue to increase knowledge and bring together clinicians, faculty, researchers, basic scientists, bioinformaticians, geneticists, and bioethicists on a single platform to move the field forward and make progress in reducing US-Mexico border and global cancer health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is associated with increased risk of heart disease due, in part, to chronic inflammation arising from adipose tissue. There are no current targeted therapies to prevent or reverse the inflammation of obesity, and a better understanding of these inflammatory pathways in adipose tissue is key to future therapeutic interventions. This project will determine the anti-inflammatory potential of the diabetes medication empagliflozin, as well as the contribution of adipose tissue inflammation to heart disease in a randomized controlled trial of obese patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Global observational HIV research is challenged by the significant effort required to collect and harmonize profoundly different data from HIV care and treatment sites around the world. The Harmonist project proposes to develop and share methods and tools for standardizing and coordinating multi-site research collaborations, including standards-enabled tools for secure data exchange, data quality checking, and scientific project and portfolio management. The International epidemiology Databases to Evaluate AIDS (IeDEA) and Regional Prospective Observational Research for Tuberculosis (RePORT) International consortia are participating in the development, testing, and evaluation of this research resource.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this work is to define how cellular metabolism supports and regulates the ability of stem cells to undergo successful differentiation. This proposal utilizes the stepwise, directed- differentiation of human embryonic stem cells into pancreatic epithelium as a model to study the metabolism of human development. Results of this work will provide novel approaches to induce differentiation of cell types of interest from pluripotent stem cells by selectively supporting their growth, and improve our ability to produce stem cell-derived human tissues useful for cell therapies and modeling human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Because patients who receive in-center hemodialysis for the treatment of end-stage kidney disease incur high costs and experience poor health outcomes (e.g. high mortality and frequent hospitalizations), it is important to find ways to improve care delivery. Advances in communications technologies have created numerous opportunities for telemedicine to improve chronic disease management and could help to address existing gaps and inefficiencies in the way that nephrologists deliver care to patients receiving in-center hemodialysis. In a combination of administrative data analyses and in-person interviews, we will exploit rapid increases in the use of telemedicine that have recently occurred in the setting of the COVID-19 pandemic to identify potential effects of telemedicine on healthcare costs, health outcomes, and patient and provider experiences in dialysis care.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: Effective treatment for those with severe COVID-19 remains poor. We found that enoxaparin (a low molecular weight heparin) augments the ability alpha-1-antitrypsin (AAT), a naturally occurring protein, to inhibit a key enzyme that is required for the COVID-19 virus to enter human cells. Both enoxaparin and AAT: (i) were also found to reduce the burden of the COVID-19 virus in human cells; (ii) are currently being used clinically for other reasons with excellent safety record; and (iii) have other biochemical properties that antagonize many of the dire consequences of COVID-19. We will test the therapeutic efficacy of AAT plus enoxaparin in two human cell types and in mice against the COVID-19 virus. Establishing the efficacy of AAT + enoxaparin combination will provide a foundation for future clinical trials with the goal of employing more effective therapy for veterans and non-veterans with severe COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Soluble klotho is a promising biomarker in chronic kidney disease that has positive effects on the heart and kidney although concerns regarding the accuracy of current assays to measure klotho have limited its use in large clinical cohorts. We propose to use an alternative assay, which we have shown to be superior in pilot data, to measure soluble klotho within the CKD sub-cohort of the Systolic Blood Pressure Intervention Trial. We will compare the new assay with the most commonly used commercial assay, examine the relationship of klotho with cardiovascular disease and kidney disease progression and investigate the factors associated with change in klotho concentrations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE: The proposed renewal application examines the relationship between exposure to adversity, DNA methylation, and risk for internalizing symptoms within a unique and established longitudinal study of children from South Africa. Findings generated from this research will help identify sensitive periods in development, or stages in the lifespan when the effects of exposure to adversity on DNA methylation and subsequent psychopathology are most harmful. The identification of sensitive periods in development will aid in determining mechanisms through which adversity increases psychopathology risk and will help guide the investment of public health resources to when they can have the highest impact on reducing risk for mental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Type 1 Diabetes (T1D) is a chronic debilitating autoimmune disorder affecting an estimated 1.6 million Americans with no cure. While B cells are important in the pathogenesis of T1D, little is known regarding which B cells are the pathogenic offenders and how exactly they contribute to disease. The goal of this study is to identify which B cell subset(s) are involved in the pathogenesis of T1D using a novel single cell sequencing platform, we term AVID-seq, to inform our understanding of T1D and aid in development of future therapeutics.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Project Narrative In the Veteran population, peripheral nerve injury is a leading cause of disability within the Military Health System (MHS), with peripheral neuropathy being a primary health concern of Veterans. To treat long-gap nerve injury, donor autografts are isolated from elsewhere in the patient. Autograft isolation leads to donor site morbidity, and some Veterans are unable to donate autografts due to other complications (i.e. diabetes). As alternatives to the autograft, allografts or biomaterial conduits are being developed and used clinically. However, with allografts, extensive decelluarization procedures are required, and biomaterial conduits lack sufficient extracellular matrix (ECM) to promote extension regeneration. Our approach will develop biomaterial conduits releasing mRNA for neurotrophin-3 (NT-3). As a result, we believe the enhanced production of NT-3 by cells at the injury site will lead to extensive regeneration, leading to a new approach to treat neural injury in the Veteran population.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Effective rehabilitation procedures are still lacking for stroke, the leading cause of long-term motor disability. Transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS) is a promising noninvasive brain stimulation approach that can promote motor recovery. Understanding the neurophysiological effects after stroke regarding individual variability, dose-response relationship, safety, and tolerability issues can facilitate implementation of tACS in rehabilitation settings. Our proposed studies will determine if tACS, together with upper limb motor rehabilitation, can improve motor function and the role of cerebral blood flow enhancement as a neurophysiological marker, to optimize post-stroke intervention in mature adult mice (male and female, with or without vascular abnormalities).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project proposes an artificially intelligent, semi-autonomous planning and robotic approach for lung cancer biopsy leveraging MR guidance. An AI-enabled robot planner identifies the least traumatic and safest biopsy needle approach for a particular patient, and then, a dexterous robot inserts the needle under real-time CT guidance. This automated method will allow patient-specific information to be incorporated into planning for lung biopsies, enabling sensitive anatomies to be avoided, lesions to be reached faster and more accurately, providing significant more effective screening and safety than today’s freehanded approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Gene and cell therapy – including gene therapy for rare or complex disease, genome editing, cell replacement, and tissue engineering – is emerging as the next generation of therapeutics to address unmet medical need, and their investigation is also enabling basic investigation of human development and modeling of human disease. Scientists with interdisciplinary backgrounds in biology and engineering are needed to rapidly advance this field. To address this need, the primary objective of this Biology and Biotechnology of Gene and Cell Therapy (BBGCT) Training Program is to provide a structured, supportive, diverse, and interdisciplinary classroom and research training opportunity in our rapidly emerging and expanding discipline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: Project Narrative The replicative CMG helicase is an enzyme that is required for DNA replication and important for cancer cell growth. The goals of this project are to understand how two proteins involved in cancer, Rb and Myc, directly regulate the human CMG helicase at the biochemical level. Knowledge from this work will not only provide an understanding of how these proteins control the CMG helicase in cancer, but also teach us how the CMG helicase can be inhibited enzymatically to inform drug discovery efforts aimed at targeting the CMG helicase for cancer intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic psychosocial stress is associated with increased risk for cardiovascular disease (CVD), and exaggerated stress-related cardiovascular reactivity (CVR) has also been linked with elevated CVD risk. The purpose of this study is to examine the feasibility and effectiveness of a smartphone-based mindfulness training program for reducing stress and stress reactivity measures that have been linked with CVD risk in a population selected for vulnerability to stress and CVD, to examine whether the addition of practice prompts that are presented during daily life enhances these effects, and to develop a computer model to assist in identifying the circumstances in which such prompts may be most fruitfully employed. The goal is to produce a scalable mobile health intervention that can be shown to reduce progression of preclinical CVD as part of a subsequent Phase 2 clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This research investigates how physical or behavioral context can influence our perception of the world around us. Malfunctions of these interactions can lead to maladaptive behaviors exhibited by mental health patients and patients with severe trauma. In particular, the direct integration of context into basic early sensory signals in the brain suggests a deep entanglement that may warrant changes to desensitization strategies for treating post-traumatic stress disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative - Overall There are now increasing numbers of evidence that bone through the hormones, osteocalcin or lipocalin 2, can be involved in the body reactions to various types of stressors. Moreover, some of the functions that are promoted by osteocalcin decrease with age. This application aims at exploring the relationship between bone and stress response and at using this knowledge to combat manifestations of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Platelets are small blood cells that participate in clot formation to stop bleeding and also in the response to inflammation, although only their clot forming abilities are considered when administering platelet transfusions to premature babies, who often receive platelet transfusions in hopes of decreasing their bleeding risk. Premature babies are a vulnerable population with high morbidity and mortality due to multiple disease processes, and a recent large study found that babies who received more platelet transfusions had a higher mortality and risk of lung disease than babies who were transfused less. In this project I will investigate the effects of platelet transfusions in models of neonatal infection and lung disease and the mechanisms through which platelet transfusions increase neonatal mortality and lung injury, with the hope of improving the outcomes of these most vulnerable patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a training program to train promising young scientists at the postdoctoral level (post Ph.D.) in molecular, cellular, behavioral and clinical neuropsychopharmacology. Trainees participate in scientific project development, seminars from visiting scientists, a course in neurobiology of addiction, a course in ethical conduct of research, training in rigor and reproducibility, and training in career development for pathways to independence. Established procedures for recruitment to increase diversity in research, evaluation and career development are in place.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Although telomere regions at the ends of human chromosomes normally shorten with age, accelerated shortening can lead to diseases like idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) that may necessitate lung transplantation. This proposal tests the innovative hypothesis that accelerated telomere shortening may also cause loss of function in the transplanted lung. This novel paradigm could lead to novel diagnostics and interventions to improve survival following lung transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral artery disease (PAD) is atherosclerotic disease with a blood flow obstruction to the lower extremities. Supervised exercise is commonly recommended for PAD patients whereas an exaggerated blood pressure response during exercise is a risk factor for cardiovascular diseases. This grant is to examine the role played by amiloride in improving the exaggerated sympathetic and blood pressure responses to exercise in PAD and further study the cellular mechanisms by which amiloride has beneficial effects, providing a potential base for better improving the blood flow directed to the ischemic limbs and enhancing walking ability in PAD patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Two leading causes of morbidity and mortality in cardiac transplant recipients are allograft rejection and cardiac allograft vasculopathy. Diagnosing these conditions requires repetitive invasive procedures with inherent risks and varying diagnostic yield. Preliminary data suggests that circulating, cell-free microRNAs are novel, non-invasive biomarkers; using next-generation sequencing and bioinformatic analysis, we will identify circulating microRNA biomarkers that can be used to predict rejection and cardiac allograft vasculopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: To effectively perform their function, each cell type in the human body must respond appropriately to incoming signals and cells enlist specific machines to carryout cell-type unique instructions, a layer of information (called the epigenome) on top of the genome. This proposal will investigate how these molecular machines ‘interpret’ incoming signals, ‘read’ the existing epigenetic landscape and ‘respond’ appropriately. Knowledge of this communication network is key to understanding how major breakdowns in information flow, either as a lack of response to extra-cellular signals or to an ill-advised decision, leads to disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deep brain stimulation is a surgical procedure for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. A novel approach to current DBS is called coordinated reset DBS which uses different patterns of stimulation at lower currents and can also induce motor improvement that persist after cessation of stimulation. This study will assess critical features and optimal target site for CR DBS that provide optimal clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study determines how cytokines like interferon influence the development of autoimmunity-associated B cells and autoreactive plasma cells in systemic lupus erythematosus. Kidney tissue is examined to determine if autoimmunity-associated B cell precursors and autoimmunity-promoting factors are found in lupus nephritis. Understanding how these abnormal B cells develop into cells that make self-reactive antibodies may lead to new treatment strategies for lupus and lupus nephritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative This proposal takes advantage of the ability of pluripotent stem cells to uniquely produce differentiated somatic cell types in large quantities. This allows the generation of specific cell populations for regenerative medicine. We have developed methods, based on the conditional expression of myogenic master regulators, Pax3 and Pax7, to induce the muscle program in early mesoderm, and thus derive embryonic muscle progenitors with great efficiency. Our investigations will focus on understanding the interaction and molecular cues provided by the adult niche that favor the in vivo maturation of PSC-derived myogenic progenitors, as well as the clonal dynamics of engraftment and quiescence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative HIV-associated neurological disorder (HAND) in various forms affects about 50% of HIV-infected population and persists despite effective anti-retroviral treatment. The treatment options for this co-morbidity are limited because of poor understanding of its pathogenic mechanisms. In this proposal, we will test an innovative hypothesis that HAND is caused by HIV-mediated impairment of cholesterol metabolism in brain cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Despite the rapidly growing rate of obesity, the development of safe and effective therapeutics has become progressively more promising, yet still limited, largely due to insufficient understanding of how the brain manages body weight and feeding. Serotonin remains an excellent potential target for an anti- obesity therapeutic, but there is a gap in understanding of the most effective way to utilize serotonin as a tool for weight loss. This proposal will focus on how 5-HT (serotonin) neurons are regulated by dopamine and/or GABA, and how these inputs contribute to the meal initiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative PGD occurs in almost a third of lung transplant recipients, is the most common cause of death in the perioperative period and has a major impact on morbidity, quality of life and cost. Uncertainty in organ quality and concern that poor donor quality causes susceptibility to PGD results in high discard rates for potentially transplantable organs. The long-term objective of this line of research is to develop objective tools to stratify PGD risk so more organs will be used for transplant and high-risk organs can be identified early for advanced therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Choroid plexus vascular malformations substantially increase the risk of an intraventricular hemorrhagic stroke which can cause dangerous increases in intracranial pressure as well as hydrocephalus and serious brain damage. The goal of our proposed studies is to understand the molecular and genetic control of choroid plexus vascular development and morphogenesis, providing critical insights into its pathological processes. This research has the potential to reveal novel therapeutic targets to treat or prevent vascular diseases of the choroid plexus as well as in other parts of the central nervous system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative MPNSTs lack effective therapies, highlighting a critical need to develop novel treatment strategies. I hypothesize that MEK-CDK4/6 inhibition causes MPNST regression and increased response to immune checkpoint blockade therapy through a plasma cell-dependent modulation of tumor infiltrating immune cells. These studies will define, for the first time in any tumor type, the biological significance of intratumoral plasma cells in therapy-induced antitumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The vast majority of breast cancer related deaths are caused by the metastatic spread of cancer from the breast to other organs in the body. This project would help to understand which types of cells from the tumor are capable of colonizing the major organs in the body. In the long term, this information should point to ways of preventing metastasis and more effective ways to treat patients who already have metastatic breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Hallucinations are widespread and debilitating but current treatments often fail to improve symptoms and cause severe side effects that limit treatment adherence. We will use a novel fMRI-compatible auditory task, computational modeling, and a validated proxy measure for midbrain dopamine function to identify the neurocognitive mechanisms and circuitry underlying hallucination proneness in the general population. This approach will allow us measure circuit-specific alterations driving false perceptions and could prompt individualized treatment strategies that may not only be more effective but could also limit problematic side effects and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recurrent myocardial infarctions (MI) represent one-third of all MIs and carry a markedly higher risk of morbidity and mortality. While much work has been done to identify common genetic variation for incident coronary artery disease, there is a large gap in the literature as to what variants contribute to recurrent MI. This proposal aims to discover new germline and somatic mutations associated with recurrent MI and then apply them to guide therapeutic decisions in secondary prevention of ischemic heart disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative As the US population becomes older and more diverse, there is urgent need to cultivate a pool of health disparities researchers who can advance translational research in aging and Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD) disparities and promote evidence-based interventions in both clinical practices and community-based settings. With this grant, I propose to: 1) establish a research training program to build academic capacity and leadership to advance the science of aging and ADRD health disparities; 2) advance innovative participatory, systems science, and implementation science frameworks and methods for aging and ADRD research in minority and health disparity populations; and 3) mentor junior scientists in applying multi- level, community-engaged frameworks and rigorous methods to advance the science of aging and ADRD health disparities research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Ribosome-associated quality control (RQC) is a protein surveillance pathway in cells that is activated after the detection of stalled ribosomes and helps maintain the homeostasis and fidelity of protein synthesis. The adaptive mechanisms cells utilize to cope with ribosome stalling stress remain poorly defined. It is understood that the bacterial pathogen Legionella pneumophila (L.p.) secretes specific toxins into cells that cause translational pausing and global ribosome stalling. We take advantage of L.p. derived toxins to challenge the RQC pathway and identify a putative stress response pathway that helps cells cope with ribosome stalling insults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we design, fabricate and validate a new type of microscope objective, namely a non-concentric reflective objective. This objective overcomes all limitations of commercial reflective objectives, which are invariably based on the Schwarzschild-Cassegrain design. The new lens features perfect color correction from the ultraviolet to the mid-infrared, a wide field of view, unparalleled throughput and a well-behaved pointspread function, thus enabling new and advanced nonlinear optical technologies that have so far been stifled by the lack of a high performance objective lens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Recent sequencing efforts have identified hundreds of millions of single nucleotide variants in human genomes that contribute to complex traits and diseases by interacting with one another and with genetic variation in repetitive DNA elements. The challenge of functionally interpreting this vast amount of variation is formidable: even considering only gene deletions, >108 and >1012 combinations for all 2-and 3-way interactions in the human genome would need to be tested. To reduce the complexity of variant combinations, we use genetically tractable model organisms and cutting-edge technologies to rigorously assess the various types of genetic interactions and to identify those with the most impact on phenotype, thereby generating both testable hypotheses for human genetics and novel technologies for testing them.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Myopia or near sightedness affects not only visual acuity, but even when corrected it is linked to a higher risk of retinal detachment, glaucoma, and cataract. We propose studies to better understand how multifocal contact lenses can help slow down myopia progression, focusing on the interaction with crystalline lens accommodation. This will have direct implications for the optimization and personalization strategies for contact lens designs that provide uncompromised visual quality at all distances and effective accommodative response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Older adults represent the fastest growing group of cannabis users, as well as the age group at greatest risk for cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease, but little is known about how cannabis affects age-related cognitive impairments and Alzheimer's disease pathology. The proposed project will use aged rats to determine the effects of cannabis (beneficial, detrimental, or neutral) on cognitive decline in aging and Alzheimer's disease-like neuropathology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children with sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) demonstrate high morbidity and mortality. Successful treatment requires timely delivery of effective antibiotic concentrations to the site of infection, but in sepsis this is often impaired by an over- or under-active host immune response to infection. Within the context of two ongoing randomized trials being conducted within the Collaborative Pediatric Critical Care Research Network (CPCCRN), which will examine how modifying the host immune response to infection in children with sepsis and MODS impacts outcomes, our proposed research will study how the host immune response and organ dysfunction in sepsis influence antibiotic concentrations over time, and how both antibiotic concentrations and the host immune response impact clinical and microbiological outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA SALT LAKE CITY HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to Veteran health because it focuses on identifying therapeutic targets to improve functional capacity, exercise tolerance, and quality of life in Veterans with peripheral artery disease (PAD). Physical activity is the most beneficial and cost-effective treatment for Veterans with PAD, however, issues with oxygen delivery and utilization dramatically impair exercise compliance. The cause of these oxygen delivery and utilization impairments is likely increased oxidative stress and inflammation. The proposed project will comprehensively examine the novel strategy of Nuclear Factor Erythroid-2-like 2 (Nrf2) activation using PB125, aimed at diminishing oxidative stress and inflammation, and thereby abating the negative impacts of the disease. This therapeutic will be evaluated in isolation and in combination with exercise rehabilitation to determine if there is a synergistic benefit. The ultimate goal is to provide insight into a potential novel therapeutic treatment for this disease, therefore, improving exercise tolerance and quality of life in this growing population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: An exciting new area in neurodegenerative disease research is the emerging phenomenon of prion-like spreading of neurodegenerative disease proteins. Our experiments will provide fundamental mechanistic insight into how the proteins spread, how the spread impacts functional decline, and how the spread can be altered for therapy. The tools we apply and the lessons we learn will likely be broadly applicable to other neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer’s disease and related dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Loss of cardiomyocytes by necrotic cell death is the direct mechanistic basis for mortality due to myocardial infarction injury, as well as ensuing heart failure associated with an array of cardiomyopathies. This proposal will explore novel mechanisms in regards to the composition and regulation of the mitochondria permeability transition pore and its opening, which is the critical event that is responsible for regulated necrotic cell death. Further definition and molecular composition of the permeability transition pore is critical for designing new therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many types of endogenous DNA lesions or damage induced by radiation and chemotherapy lead to replication stress and activate the replication checkpoint pathway. While the integrity of the replication checkpoint pathway is critically important for cell survival, the mechanisms underlying replication checkpoint control and cell viability are not fully understood. In this project, we will determine the mechanisms underlying replication and cell cycle checkpoint control with the long-term goal of exploiting this checkpoint pathway for cancer therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is the major cause of non-traumatic neurological disability in young adults in the US. Using a rodent model (Shiverer) for late phase MS, we discovered a major cause of grey matter damage for this disease phase. This damage is caused by inappropriate intrusion of an axonal mitochondrial anchor, Syntaphilin (SNPH), into dendrites. SNPH immobilizes mitochondria in dendrites and causes neurons to be excited to death. We will explore which glutamate receptors are involved in this toxicity, and how synaptic activity causes harmful migration of SNPH to dendrites. Preventing toxic SNPH migration into dendrites is a potential treatment strategy for MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Among the most common muscle disorders, Facioscapulohumeral Muscular Dystrophy (FSHD) is caused by misexpression of the DUX4 gene in skeletal muscles. CRISPR inhibition technology provides an avenue for targeting and reducing such pathogenic gene expression, with long-term or permanent beneficial effects. Here we will test the efficacy, specificity, and stability of CRISPR inhibition in two complementary mouse models of FSHD, including a xenograft model that will allow us to study the effects of this approach in human muscle derived from FSHD patient cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Next generation sequencing (NGS) has transformed the field of genomics, bringing it to the forefront of healthcare, however the rapid pace of technological developments in the field challenges even field experts to remain current. The successful implementation of genomics into clinical practice requires much more than a superficial understanding of the technology. The proposed course, "An Immersive Experience in Medical Genomics" is designed for a broad audience of clinicians seeking a strong foundation in genomics, and will be structured to facilitate collaboration and crosstalk across disciplines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Stress-induced hyperglycemia is an important survival response that fuels the metabolic activity needed to fight and escape threats; however severe or chronic activation of this response can lead to diabetes. This project aims to define the neural circuits and metabolic mechanisms that regulate stress-induced glucose mobilization and differentiate these from the circuits that mediate stress-induced behaviors. Once these mechanisms have been identified, we will be able to develop therapeutics that can target metabolic outcomes of stress-induced hyperglycemia without affecting behavioral responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed project will apply novel methods to identify a comprehensive set of individual sociodemographic and clinical characteristics that define longitudinal patterns of prescription opioid use for chronic pain and predict transitions to fatal and non-fatal overdose in vulnerable groups. This project will also examine linkages between prescription opioid treatment trajectories and broader social and structural characteristics to understand how population-level sociodemographic and socioeconomic factors, the distribution of health care resources, and state policies influence risk of opioid overdose and fatality at the individual level. The research will contribute fundamental knowledge about the patterns and risks associated with opioid prescribing practices for pain management and identify areas where programs and policies are needed to improve health care access and quality to ultimately reduce the risk of opioid overdose and death.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure (HF) is the leading cause of hospitalization in older adults and represents an enormous public health burden. Despite the contributions of countless studies, national campaigns, and financial incentives, high rates of rehospitalization continue to put enormous strain on the U.S. healthcare system and on those suffering from the disease. We propose to integrate the strengths of life course theory, data, and methods to examine the longitudinal patterns and predictors of hospitalization in older adults diagnosed with HF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: We do not understand how melanocytes de-differentiate into transcriptionally heterogeneous melanoma cell states that define poor outcome in patients. Screening for changes in DNA methylation, we discovered de- repression of NR2F2-isoform2 in patients where melanoma had spread from skin to other body parts, and now propose to determine whether and how NR2F2-isoform2 affects melanoma heterogeneity and metastatic potential. By understanding NR2F2-isoform2 function, we expect to identify the cell state responsible for metastatic progression, and factors we can harness to predict, prevent, or inhibit metastasis in melanoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We propose here a theoretically-grounded (in the IMB model), accessible and sustainable mHealth PrEP care continuum intervention for gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (GBMSM) and transgender women (TW), called eSTEP (Electronic Support To Engage with PrEP). The eSTEP WebApp will be tailored by sexuality and gender status and include a set of interactive components delivered before in-person HIV testing (e.g., PrEP information on the benefits of PrEP) and after the participant tests HIV-negative and agrees to start PrEP (e.g., adherence self-monitoring). If feasible and acceptable, eSTEP will be the first scalable mHealth intervention that addresses the full PrEP continuum of care for GBMSM and TW to help reach the End the HIV Epidemic goal of substantially reducing new HIV infections in the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Staphylococcus aureus, including MRSA, is among the most common causes of human bacterial infections, and it is thought that it spreads in hospitals before causing new infections. By examining the whole genomes (that is, all DNA gene sequences) of S. aureus strains carried asymptomatically on admission and those causing infections in patients on two hospital units, we will investigate how genetic characteristics of the bacteria influence the likelihood of their spread from person to person in the hospital. We will also determine if healthcare workers or inanimate objects serve as carriers of bacteria later found to spread to new patients, and with this information, improved, targeted preventive interventions can later be introduced to decrease the risk of S. aureus infections in hospitals.

PHR: Project Narrative There is a shortage of M.D.-scientists despite the growing need in research. We propose a research training program to train a diverse group of M.D. residents who will conduct laboratory-based, translational, clinical, and population research to detect, treat, and prognosticate diseases affecting the heart, lungs, and blood throughout the human lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sepsis is the most frequent cause of death in United States hospitals, and the number one cause of death worldwide, responsible for 11 million deaths in 2017. Primary drivers of sepsis morbidity and mortality are immune exhaustion leading to deadly secondary infection, and organ tissue damage leading to multi-organ failure. Here we seek to develop a deeper understanding of these processes through cell-free DNA epigenomics to track the kinetics and dynamics of dysfunctional/exhausted T cells as well as organ damage during sepsis, which should stimulate future research efforts to ameliorate these primary drivers of sepsis-mediated morbidity and mortality.

PROJECT_TITLE: Cell-free DNA epigenomics to track the dynamics of organ damage and immune exhaustion during sepsis

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Inhibition of the Wnt Receptor Complex by the Tumor Suppressor Adenomatous Polyposis Coli Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States, with limited options for therapy. The goal of this proposed study is to determine how the one critical protein that prevents the initiation step of colorectal cancer normally functions, to elucidate what happens in colorectal cells when this protein is lost, and to devise and test new strategies to block the growth of colorectal cancer cells based on these discoveries. The knowledge gained from this proposed study will provide new approaches for the treatment for colorectal cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetes weakens the immune response to tuberculosis (TB) and triples the risk of developing active TB, but we do not yet know whether gestational diabetes has the same effect. The proposed research addresses a significant research gap that threatens the health of pregnant women worldwide: gestational diabetes affects 16% of pregnancies globally and up to 40% in India, where TB is a major cause of maternal mortality, especially for women with HIV. We propose to determine how HIV causes gestational diabetes and how gestational diabetes leads to increased active TB, which responds to the NIH priority of pursuing novel treatment strategies for HIV, diabetes and TB in pregnant women, a historically underrepresented group in clinical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The populations of US citizens with severe speech and physical impairments secondary to neurodevelopmental and neurodegenerative diseases are increasing as medical technologies advance and successfully support life. These individuals with limited to no movement could potentially contribute to their medical decision making, informed consent, and daily caregiving if they had faster, more reliable means that adapt to their best access methods in communication technologies, as proposed in BCI-FIT. This project implements the translation of basic computer science and engineering into clinical care, supporting the proposed NIH Roadmap and public health initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to establish the feasibility of the first specific therapy for hPAP in children and introduces a novel approach for treating lung diseases, pulmonary macrophage transplantation. This approach will represent a major improvement over the current therapy, whole lung lavage, which is inefficient, highly invasive, and unavailable at most clinical centers particularly for use in children, some of whom require it as frequently as every one to two months. Thus, the proposed re- search is relevant to the part of NIH’s mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help to reduce the burden of human illness, and will also inform mechanisms by which GM-CSF contributes to alve- olar macrophage development, surfactant homeostasis, and lung function in health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Protein-mediated membrane fusion is a fundamental process that is essential for biological functions as wide ranging as gamete fertilization, formation of placenta, synaptic vesicle trafficking, tissue development, mitochondrial function, and enveloped virus infection. Despite its significance, relatively little is understood at a mechanistic and structural level regarding how specialized fusion protein machinery and membranes interact in order to go from a prefusion to activated fusogenic to the final formation of a fusion pore. Here cryo-electron microscopy and structural mass spectrometry will be used to study membrane fusion in two biomedically important enveloped viruses, thus providing new insights into how very different protein machines accomplish similar physical functions of merging two distinct membranes into one.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Being able to customize healthcare based on each person’s unique genetic makeup could enable an era of genomic medicine that would improve prevention, diagnosis and treatment for many types of health conditions. Achieving this vision requires developing computerized tools that help doctors and patients make sense of individual genomic data to show them how to use that data to make better healthcare decisions. Relevant to NHGRI’s interest in the clinical deployment of genomics, the focus of the proposed research program is in the area of implementation science, and will help to address the challenge of adopting unsolicited genomic results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health and specifically to alcohol use disorder, one of the most prevalent mental health disorders, because it will produce a new approach to the analysis of a randomized clinical trial that furthers precision medicine. The new method identifies patient specific predictors of likely response to a test treatment and performs hypothesis tests for treatment differences in the group of likely responders, all in the same study. The method will be applied to data from six completed NIAAA studies and a new method for appraising possibly erroneous model specification and confounding will be utilized.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Arginine methylation is one of the most common post-translational modifications and plays critical roles in many fundamental cellular processes. This proposal focuses on identifying the upstream signal and regulators of PRMT1/5, as well as demethylases and readers of arginine methylation. We will use a range of complementary methods including biochemistry, mass spectrometric (MS) analysis, molecular and cellular biology, and mouse models in our studies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: A moderate traumatic brain injury (TBI) occurring in early or middle adulthood might have long-lasting effects on the brain that can accelerate the decline of physical and cognitive function in older age. The proposed study seeks to better understand the implications of aging with a TBI, in order to help Veterans maintain their health and independence. The overarching hypothesis of this new line of research is that participants who experienced a moderate TBI in early or middle adulthood (at least 15 years prior to study enrollment) will have poorer performance on balance and cognitive tests, despite self-reporting no persistent motor or cognitive impairment from the TBI. We also seek to evaluate the potential for practice-based learning and improvement of complex balance tasks in this population, to gain experience for conducting future rehabilitation studies. The long term goal of this line of research is to design rehabilitative and lifestyle interventions to preserve brain health and function in Veterans who have previously experienced a TBI.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: U.S. veterans are more at risk for developing Alzheimer’s disease (AD) than civilians due to risk factors associated with military service, and women are more likely to develop AD than men. AD is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by progressive loss of neuron function and structure. Immune cell dysfunction contributes to massive cell death within the central nervous system. Treatments that have the potential to reverse immune cell activation and mitigate cognitive impairment at early disease stages, prior to neural degeneration and cell death, are urgently needed. Noninvasive audiovisual neurostimulation is a promising new method to alter immune cell activation in mouse models of disease and is already under investigation in human clinical trials. Despite known sex differences in AD, prior studies have not tested the effects of noninvasive neurostimulation in females, which will be addressed in the proposed research.

PHR: Narrative We propose renewal of the University of Alabama at Birmingham (UAB) health services research (HSR) T32 training program, with 4 predoctoral and 5 postdoctoral slots per year. MPD/MPI Michael Mugavero, MD, MHSc and Emily Levitan, ScD collaborate with 9 Core Faculty and 49 Participating Faculty Mentors to deliver health services research and professional skills training to diverse cohorts of trainees. Our overarching goal is to train change agents who use these skills to improve health outcomes and overcome health disparities in Alabama, across the Deep South, and in other regions in the U.S.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Harvard-wide pediatric Health Services Research (HPHSR) Fellowship is a 30 year collaboration of Boston Children’s Hospital, Massachusetts General Hospital for Children, and the Harvard Department of Population Medicine/Harvard Pilgrim Healthcare Institute. Our multidisciplinary, well-funded faculty provide exemplary training in pediatric health services research and implementation science within leading health systems. This program has an amazing training record- the 154 alumni include 18 graduates from racial or ethnic groups underrepresented in medicine, 61 in academic or research leadership positions including 16 CMOs or Senior VPs, and four alumni elected to the National Academy of Medicine

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Hearing impairment affects over 30 million Americans and can significantly impact their day-to-day life. There are currently no regenerative approaches available in the clinics to reverse hearing loss in the human inner ear. By comparing the regeneration potential in the inner ear between a highly regenerative versus a non- regenerative animal model, this proposed research will identify potential elements from the regenerative species to inform new therapeutic strategies to restore hearing in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Ischemic stroke is an important clinical problem with limited treatment options beyond the first several hours, whereafter infarcted lesion cores are remodeled with fibrotic scar that does not support neural repair. Promoting neural repair at lesion cores will require altering natural stroke wound healing processes to dynamically reestablish viable neurovascular and glia barrier functions. In this proposal, we will use multi-modal intravital imaging methods to longitudinally track cell graft induced glia repair outcomes in sub-acute stroke lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative A large number of research and clinical studies derive information on the functional connectivity, within and between neural circuits in the brain, by analyzing statistical correlations between small signal fluctuations from different brain areas that are measureable during acquisitions of MRI images while a subject is at rest. However, the interpretation of these correlations as indices of functional connectivity has not been substantiated. The studies proposed would establish the relationships between these MRI metrics of connectivity and results obtained by other means of exciting or modifying neural circuits, including gold standard electrophysiological recordings of neural electrical activity, maps of anatomic connections from injected tracers, and behavioral effects, in non-human primates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative The hallmark of neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is bilateral vestibular schwannomas (VSs), tumors that cause progressive hearing loss and are associated with substantially negative impacts to quality of life. Identifying well-tolerated drugs to halt VS growth and ameliorate VS-associated hearing loss is a major unmet medical need. This project will provide pivotal insight into i) the role and mechanisms of HMGB1 in driving neuroinflammation in VS, ii) the treatment potential and the hearing response following HMGB1 blockade, and iii) the design of a future clinical trial for VS using a novel combination strategy of HMGB1 and EGFR blockade to concurrently control tumor growth and prevent VS-induced hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Clinicians use patient-reported measures to understand how communication impairments impact daily life for people with post-stroke speech and language disorders. However, the data from these measures may be misinterpreted and misused in treatment planning if clinicians have not also considered how the client’s psychosocial perspectives (depression, chronic stress, resilience, or self-efficacy) interact with the communication impairment in daily life. In this project, we will examine how clients’ psychosocial perspectives contribute to communicative participation as reported on a common patient-reported measure so that we may guide how clinicians integrate this information into their clinical activities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Pathological axon degeneration is a hallmark of many neurodegenerative conditions. We recently discovered that Schwann cells, the glia of the peripheral nervous system, protect injured axons through a metabolic coupling mechanism which likely supports axonal bioenergetics. The main goal of this proposal is to examine how manipulation of metabolic coupling regulates axonal bioenergetics, thus impacting the survival of axons after acute and subacute injuries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Each cell in the human body contains two meters of DNA that need to be packaged in the tiny micrometer- sized cellular nucleus. This proposal describes new methodologies that can be used to study this process both in vitro and in cells. Understanding the mechanisms of DNA packaging will shed light on normal cell differentiation and development and on the molecular origins of disease such as cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The airway epithelium is the crucial host defense against lung injury and infections. It plays a key role in the development of lung diseases and is an emerging target for new therapies. However, our understanding of how this important barrier is fundamentally regulated is limited. Thus, it is paramount to identify new key regulators of this tissue. Multiciliated cells (MCCs), critical within this epithelium, nucleate up to 300 motile cilia at their apical surface to generate directional fluid flow which constantly cleans airways from inhaled pathogens, pollutants and dust to maintain pulmonary health (mucociliary clearance). Notably, airway ciliated cells are the primary targets of human SARS-CoV-2 infection. Moreover, impaired clearance by defective MCCs, either acquired or due to genetic ciliopathies, causes chronic airway infections and COPD and is associated with asthma. Our new studies produced compelling evidence that the E2f7 and E2f8 members of the E2f family of transcription factors have previously unknown essential roles in the early phases of multiciliogenesis. Moreover, human E2f7 and E2f8 are dysregulated in patients with asthma, fibrosing interstitial lung diseases and COPD. Furthermore, E2f7 and E2f8 directly regulate human primary ciliary dyskinesia-associated genes. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will comprehensively define the essential role of E2f7 and E2f8 as master regulators of MCC differentiation, with the long-term goal to use this knowledge to design innovative therapies and diagnostic strategies for chronic airway diseases. This research is relevant to the mission of NHLBI pertaining to stimulating basic discoveries about airway diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As the rates of multi-drug resistant Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) continue to increase globally, determining the role of pharyngeal NG (pNG) infections, which are largely asymptomatic and are implicated in the emergence of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in NG, has become a critical area of research to prevent further emergence of AMR. We propose an epidemiological study to define predictors of pNG infection, characterize AMR in pNG, and to adapt a single-cell molecular assay to improve characterization of AMR in pNG. Through the use of a multi- pronged approach combining clinical, microbiological, genomic, demographical and behavioral data, and novel diagnostics, this project addresses critical gaps in our understanding of pNG infections, AMR, and increases capacity building for development of diagnostics for AMR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial edema is a common feature of many cardiac injuries including myocardial infarction (MI), a major public health epidemic but the extent to which edema is causally related to myocardial dysfunction remains unclear. By targeting endothelial vascular permeability, we developed a mechanism-based approach to suppress edema while avoiding confounding pleotropic effects. The goals of this project are to: 1) Uncover the effects of myocardial interstitial edema on post-MI myocardial function and remodeling; 2) Study the link between development of myocardial edema following MI and the pathogenesis of ventricular arrhythmias, and 3) Develop, validate and translate first in class human anti-edema mAb for MI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The primary purpose of this proposal is to support ongoing mentorship of early career investigators from the US and Africa in conducting global patient-oriented research, with the ultimate goal of strengthening sustained capacity for performing clinical research in Africa. The specific research aims of this project include studies of the role of HIV co-infection in several aspects of SARS-CoV-2 infection in Botswana (specifically, the impact of HIV on long COVID and on the emergence of SARS-CoV-2 mutations/variants in populations and within individuals, both in the presence and absence of prior SARS-CoV-2 vaccination). Other research aims pertain to the impact of different HIV treatment regimens during pregnancy on cardiometabolic risk factors in women and their role in pregnancy outcomes and child health and growth (including pregnancy and postpartum weight gain, and markers of diabetes and metabolic syndrome in pregnancy).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it focuses on developing new, objective, physiologic- based monitoring methods for adolescent suicidality, an exponentially rising disease in the United States, and overwhelming emergency departments. These methods lead to the potential for significant advances in early detection and utilization of therapeutic interventions when dynamic suicidality changes occur in the outpatient setting. This competitive application aligns with three of the NIMH's strategic goals, including increased preventative measures for early detection, research to study mental illness trajectory over time, and increased public health impact through the ED, where preventive efforts may be introduced/implemented.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Prematurity is a significant public health problem that increases risk of developmental disabilities, but little is known about factors that contribute to resiliency (positive outcome despite risk). This research aims to increase fundamental knowledge about the flexibility and resiliency of the developing preterm brain through state-of-the- art brain imaging and identification of specific socioenvironmental factors that impact resiliency. This knowledge will lead to improved prediction of outcomes and development of interventions to improve those outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The benefits of sustained, regular exercise are well-recognized by the public and often advocated by medical professionals. However, the benefits of acute exercise on the brain have not been well-studied. Using single episodes of voluntary exercise in mice, we identified a novel activity-dependent molecule that we hypothesize is an effector of synaptic plasticity and a trigger for enhanced learning and memory in the hippocampus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Intermediate filaments are abundant cytoskeletal proteins that interact with numerous cellular proteins and contribute to a variety of cellular processes, yet we lack a complete mechanistic understanding of their function. Here we propose to interrogate how intermediate filaments are regulated and how they contribute to inflammation by focusing on the intermediate filament vimentin and its role in neutrophil inflammatory processes and trafficking. The successful completion of this proposal is highly likely to identify new mechanisms by which intermediate filaments contribute to inflammation and to cellular and tissue function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetics researchers have identified tens of thousands of DNA variants that influence risk for human diseases, but identifying the functions of these variants has been challenging. We will develop new approaches to systematically map how many of these variants control particular genes and cell types. Applying these approaches could help to identify new therapeutic targets for an array of common diseases.
