IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The production of new T cells is controlled in an organ called the thymus. This project will study how the type of vasculature in the thymus contributes to the rapid growth of the organ that occurs in the newborn period. The ultimate goal of these studies is to uncover novel pathways to enhance T cell production in the thymus to improve health by reversing immune deficiencies associated with organ transplant, cancer treatment and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative There is strong experimental and epidemiological evidence that arsenic in combination with other environmental insults such as ultraviolet radiation (UVR) increases carcinogenesis at even lower arsenic concentrations than the EPA and WHO standard of 10 ppb, suggesting that arsenic is a co-carcinogen in humans. Recent advances in analysis of next generation sequencing have given rise to powerful tools to define distinct mutational signatures in tumors that identify specific defects in DNA repair processes or carcinogenic exposures. This information is useful for cancer epidemiology, basic DNA repair and mutagenesis research, and studies on potential interventions to reduce the mutagenic risk of a specific or mixed exposure that may lead to human cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Arthritis is a debilitating and painful disease affecting 54 million Americans. This work is aimed at developing a better understanding of the role of the pericellular matrix, a region surrounding chondrocytes, in signaling to the cell how to make enzymes that destroy cartilage and using biomimetic proteoglycans to mitigate the negative consequences. This knowledge may enable minimally invasive strategies for regeneration of cartilage and treatment of early osteoarthritis, a disease state that does not have many options at the current time.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Epidemiological evidence shows that paternal lifetime exposures to environmental perturbations, including stress and prior adverse childhood experiences (ACE), are associated with changes in reproductive outcomes, gestational development, and ultimately, offspring health and disease, and animal models have implicated the germ cell transfer of small non-coding RNA (sncRNA), including miRNA, in programming these effects. We recently published our foundational work which allowed us to construct a model to initially assess the composition of, and dynamic changes in, human sperm sncRNA by utilizing complex between- and within-subject comparisons over time. Our hypotheses to test in this proposal are that our prior model built from repeated sampling of a small homogeneous student cohort will replicate in a larger and more diverse population, will predict unique changes in sperm sncRNA when we add subject ACEs to our model, and will substantiate reproductive and developmental importance when miRNA mimics or inhibitors are injected into mouse zygotes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) improving long-term outcomes of allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT), the only curative option for SCD patients represents an unmet need. In performing HCT in patients with SCD, careful consideration must be given to the conditioning regimen; as the myeloablative total body irradiation (TBI) facilitates full engraftment but it also increases organ toxicities; whereas reduced intensity conditioning (RIC) regimen, is associated with lower organ toxicity but results in higher graft failure/rejection. We propose to develop a paradigm-shifting, highly potent, and safe treatment plan that combines a targeted radiation delivery called “total marrow irradiation” with a thrombopoietin mimetic drug (TPOm) infusion after allogeneic HCT to decrease bone marrow failure and improve engraftment, and potentially protect from further organ damage; resulted from SCD and conditioning regimen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to transform microbiome population genetics so that association studies can be performed at the same level of resolution and scale as in human genetics. We will produce a computationally-efficient method for genotyping microbiome species in situ using metagenomics and statistical models for associating microbiome genes with host traits while accounting for microbial population genetic structure. Applying these tools to our deeply phenotyped cohort of ~50,000 individuals, we will test the hypothesis that cardiovascular disease is linked to microbial genes that vary across strains and alter how gut microbes influence human physiology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Children with developmental language disorders (DLD, aka specific language impairment), a prevalent pediatric disorder, experience hallmark grammar deficits with life-long impacts on educational and occupational outcomes. While effective and early interventions can mitigate the impact of DLD, not enough is known about the neural basis of DLD in young children, yet is needed to inform the design of more individualized interventions. This project uses neuroimaging, along with behavioral methods, with the goal of better understanding the memory- language mechanisms that underlie grammar learning and impairment, while also considering their association to treatment-related changes in preschoolers with DLD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating and fatal neurodegenerative disease, and environmental exposures are hypothesized to play a role in disease pathogenesis. Our goals are to identify how these exposures that contribute to ALS disease risk relate to and influence the genetic, epigenetic, metabolic, and immune features that are also associated with ALS. Importantly, the discovery of new disease mechanisms will support the development of improved diagnostic, prognostic, and therapeutic approaches; thus, our study may have wide-ranging implications on ALS disease prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Nearly all known proteins adopt a single folded structure, but human XCL1 defines a new class of fold-switching, or metamorphic, proteins. We seek to understand how and why this fold-switching protein evolved from a non-metamorphic ancestor, and to develop tools to create new metamorphic proteins. This new knowledge will improve human health by enabling the design, discovery and targeting of metamorphic proteins with biomedical utility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Pentameric ligand-gated ion channels are targets of many neuroactive drugs including anesthetics, anti- epileptics, and potentially cognitive enhancers. The novel approaches that we implement in this project will yield fundamental insights regarding the molecular mechanisms of lipid modulation in these channels, which may inform the rational design of new therapeutics that target these channels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative There is increasing evidence that diet and lifestyle are important risk factors for cognitive impairment particularly Alzheimer’s Disease. Obesity, diabetes, hypertension, cholesterol, and smoking are all risk factors for cognitive impairment and dementia in old age and they can even cause cognitive deficits in young adults. We will feed rabbits a low dose of cholesterol, a high-fat diet, or a diet high in both sugar and fat to determine if these diets produce the cellular, neuropathological, and cognitive hallmarks of late-onset Alzheimer’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prenatal alcohol exposure disrupts physical, brain and behavioral development, leading to a range of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD), a serious, global, and costly public health concern. It is critical that we identify effective treatments for reducing FASD, particularly the cognitive deficits. This proposal will examine how nutritional and behavioral factors modify the severity of FASD, which has important implications for treatment of FASD, and improving the quality of life of affected individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/ Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a devastating syndrome often characterized by comorbid damage to extremities. The proposed project explores the spinal cellular mechanisms engaged by concomitant peripheral injuries and limb disuse in SCI, and tests their contribution to spasticity/hyper-reflexia and chronic spinal recovery impairments. These studies may provide novel targets for improving recovery after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE: The goal of this proposal is to provide key preclinical data and biomarkers for the combination of two FDA-approved cancer drugs (i.e., tazemetostat and anti-PD1 therapies) for breast cancer patients. Specifically, we hypothesize that in breast cancer patients, the overexpression of a lncRNA, EPIC1, is a master regulator of immunotherapy resistance by activating EZH2. We have designed mechanistic and translational experiments to test (1) whether EPIC1 induces immunotherapy resistance by activating EZH2 in breast cancer and (2) whether EZH2 inhibitor treatment can enhance responses to PD-1 antagonists for EPIC1-EZH2-activated breast cancer tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Cervical cancer, while curable when caught earlier, remains a leading cause of death in low-and-middle- income countries. Inadequate screening tactics arise from various factors including pathology bottlenecks, costs, clinical bandwidth, and turnaround times. We propose to advance a low-cost and fast portable platform (based on Nobel Prize-winning technology) for point-of-care and integrated cervical cancer screening in Uganda and Ghana. If successful, cervical cancers would be identified earlier through a sustainable, decentralized approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social memory dysfunction is a hallmark symptom of many neuropsychiatric illnesses, including autism spectrum disorder, major depressive disorder, schizophrenia, and Alzheimer's disease. The proposed research will describe the contribution of hippocampal structural plasticity, and in particular the role of adult-born neurons, to social memory circuits and function. Understanding the mechanistic impact of adult-born neurons to social memory circuits will reveal novel strategies for alleviating social memory deficits associated with neuropsychiatric illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Biomedical research is the backbone of essential advances fueling public health and well-being, but graduate training in biomedical research is plagued by high attrition and deteriorating student well-being. The present research will address a critical source of influence on these issues, particularly among students who are underrepresented in biomedical fields: the mentoring relationships that biomedical graduate students experience with their research advisors. We propose to design and experimentally test the effectiveness of a low-touch and high-touch intervention that equips research advisors with the motivation and conflict management skills needed to improve their mentoring relationships, and examine how these interventions affect mentoring relationships and students’ career-related outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Narrative We propose to continue the Tissue Microenvironment (TiMe) Training Program at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. Focusing on three technological themes — bioengineering, imaging and sensing, and computational modeling and analytics — the program focuses on both intellectual and professional development of students. Building on the collaborative faculty, leading disciplinary expertise at Illinois, and extensive facilities and exceptional institutional support, this unique educational platform trains the next generation of interdisciplinary research leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative There are significant hurdles in the way of investigators wishing to employ xenograft models of various hematopoietic cancers. In addition to the lack of sufficient numbers of robust, readily available xenograft models such as PDX, numerous technical challenges must be overcome to successfully perform xenograft experiments. Based on my extensive experience in the field, I have built a comprehensive resource, the Humanized Mouse Resource, to address these issues that is tailored to meet the needs of internal and external collaborators, particularly those with NCI funded projects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Penn ADRC Project Narrative The Penn ADRC is highly aligned with and will contribute to the National Alzheimer’s Project Act’s (NAPA) ambitious goal of effective prevention or treatment of Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (AD/ADRD) by 2025. To achieve this goal, the Penn ADRC will provide intellectual and physical infrastructure to support research and education across the continuum of normal aging to dementia with the goal of identifying the causes of and cures for AD/ADRD, with a particular focus on AD heterogeneity. The Center will contribute to transformative local efforts, but also will actively participate in broader national efforts, including many supported by the National Institute on Aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Survival outcomes for children, adolescents and young adults with osteosarcoma, the most common malignant bone tumor in this population have remained stagnant for over 3 decades and new approaches utilizing targeted therapies are needed in improve cure rates. In order to identify targeted therapies with highest potential to have clinical efficacy, a robust osteosarcoma preclinical drug screening program with the capacity to rapidly and efficiently screen numerous agents is needed. We propose to use genomic and proteomic profiling in molecularly characterized osteosarcoma patient-derived xenograft models to guide the selection and testing of targeted agents, including antibody-drug conjugates and inhibitors, in preclinical models of osteosarcoma.

PHR: Project Narrative Enteroviruses cause a variety of significant illnesses but the underlying disease mechanisms are largely unknown. We will investigate how enteroviral proteases impair normal cell functioning and contribute to disease development. Consistent with the NIH mission, these studies will reveal the mechanisms of enteroviral pathogenesis and inform the design of novel therapeutic strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE-RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Heart disease is a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in the U.S. This proposal will improve our understanding of adverse nervous system changes that occur in the setting of a heart attack and lead to life threating heart rhythms. The proposed mechanistic research studies have significant potential to develop new targets in the treatment of dangerous heart rhythms that cause sudden cardiac death and recurrent defibrillator shocks through modulation of nerves that supply the heart.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Concussion afflicts 1 in 5 youths in the United States. Headache is one of the most common and disabling symptoms following concussion, affecting 25% of youth for longer than 1 month, yet there are no established recommendations on when or how to treat post-traumatic headache. This project will investigate the biological processes of migraine in youth following concussion to guide the timing and types of treatments used in post- traumatic headache.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In heart (between beats), abnormal intracellular calcium release may trigger arrhythmias that can lead to sudden death. This project defines why this abnormal calcium release occurs and explores therapeutic strategies to make it less likely to occur. And thus, advance our understanding cardiac arrhythmia prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While an expanding body of theory-driven research has consistently shown how factors related to structural sexual minority stigma may drive sexual orientation-based mental health disparities, US-based evidence has been hampered by single stand-alone indicators of structural stigma, leading to important risks for confounding bias. Existing public health datasets have not independently been able to facilitate research that could fully account for such confounding bias, leading to distorted results. Together with newly developed comprehensive structural sexual minority stigma indices, the proposed harmonization and integration of large US public health datasets (i.e., NHIS, Add Health, YRBS, and ABCD) will enable advanced cross-sectional and longitudinal multilevel models to address the risks for confounding that currently bias evidence on how structural sexual minority stigma across both macro (i.e., state) and exo (i.e., county) levels drive and sustain sexual orientation- based disparities in depressive symptoms and suicidality outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: The Socioecology of Sexual Minority Stigma: Data Harmonization to Address Confounding Bias and Investigate Cross-Level MentalHealth Effects

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While several research studies have demonstrated that inflammation plays an important role in the risk of dementia, the knowledge of how this risk develops and how to reduce it is lacking. Understanding the effect of chronic systemic inflammation, and therapies used to suppress it, on the development of dementia in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is crucial, as it can highlight opportunities for prevention and treatment of dementia in RA and beyond. In this proposal, using existing data resources of the Rochester Epidemiology Project and the Mayo Clinic Study of Aging, we will examine the risk and timing of cognitive decline and dementia in patients with RA, depending upon the level of inflammation and the use of medications for RA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although dengue virus infection often manifests as an asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic disease, approximately 10% of dengue-infected patients experience more severe forms of symptomatic disease, characterized by life-threatening complications. In recent studies, we demonstrated that dengue disease susceptibility and severity is associated with elevated levels of specific antibody glycoforms, which engage and activate specific leukocytes, resulting in aberrant immune activation and disease pathogenesis. The proposed studies aim to define the mechanisms by which these glycoforms are generated during dengue infection, significantly advancing our understanding of the mechanisms of dengue disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are marked inequities in HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) provision in the U.S., with Black individuals comprising only 10% of PrEP users, underscoring the urgent need for innovative research to optimize PrEP delivery for Black adults of all genders and sexual orientations. The proposed research will identify key determinants of PrEP delivery (Aim 1); develop a multifaceted implementation strategy to accelerate equitable PrEP delivery for Black primary care patients (Aim 2); and conduct a 12-month two- arm pilot to evaluate strategy feasibility and acceptability at four primary care practices in Philadelphia (Aim 3). Given the critical need to achieve equitable PrEP care continuum outcomes, this research will have significant public health implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: We seek to adapt a rapid, sensitive biosensing device that can identify specific gas molecules for the screening and diagnosis of twenty high-burden human diseases through the `scent' they emanate through the skin. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We aim to determine the molecular requirements for healthy skeletal muscle function, in order to pave the way for discovery and design of more effective therapies for muscle disease and weakness. Our work will answer crucial questions about how the protein myosin-binding protein C (MyBP-C), a cause of distal arthrogryposis, functions in skeletal muscle, using reporter probes to visualize dynamic protein structures in contracting muscle cells. This research will greatly improve the human health prospects for understanding disease by determining effects of disease mutations and developing tools that can be used to discover novel treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE This training program is designed to address the significant and costly public health problem of alcohol use disorder by training postdoctoral biomedical, biobehavioral, health care, and other public health scientists to conduct alcohol intervention research. Our program draws on many scientific disciplines, including biological sciences, epidemiology and etiology, prevention, clinical, and public health research, and emphasizes multidisciplinary approaches to achieving innovations in alcohol research. Cutting-edge training of the next generation of alcohol researchers has the potential to accelerate the pace of science in developing effective alcohol treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) has many advantages over other imaging methods, but MRI is slow. Addi- tional developments are required to shorten the scan time, improve patient comfort, reduce the use of sedation for imaging children, and improve image quality. In this project, we will develop faster and more accurate methods for MRI. These efforts should lead to signiﬁcant improvements in the diagnosis of different diseases, so that patients may beneﬁt from appropriate treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Surgical resection is the only curative therapy for patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. However, only 15-20% of pancreatic cancer patients have resectable disease at diagnosis. For patients with borderline resectable tumors, targeted neoadjuvant therapies can downstage the tumor and enable surgical resection; however, these therapies would be more useful if clinicians had real-time information regarding patient response. To inform therapeutic decisions, we plan to establish shear modulus and vascular perfusion as imaging biomarkers for assessing patient response to neoadjuvant therapy, which should improve the treatment of pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Falls (i) are common, (ii) directly injure or kill many Americans each year, and (iii) increase exponentially as we age. While many factors contribute to falls, we focus on vestibular degradation because new data show that age- related increases in vestibular thresholds mediate (“explain”) nearly half of age-related balance declines; related findings have led to estimates that up to 150,000 Americans might die each year due to sub-optimal vestibular function, including sub-clinical age-related vestibular declines. As crucial steps to reduce age-related falls, we propose extensive human testing designed to develop: (a) targeted vestibular screening tests by quantifying impacts of vestibular declines on age-related balance declines and falls and (b) a potential intervention designed to improve vestibular precision, which could also improve balance and reduce falls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The clinical utility of atovaquone for treatment and prevention of malaria has validated the parasite’s cytochrome bc1 complex as a legitimate target for exploitation. In this application we focus on another bc1 inhibitor, ELQ-300, and seek to modify the structure of this molecule to more comprehensively block the enzyme target to enhance antimalarial potency, selectivity, and overall performance in vitro and in vivo in rodent models of disease infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Anti-HLA antibodies present a formidable barrier to achieving a successful kidney transplant in patient with end-stage renal failure. Many approaches have failed to reduce the level of anti-HLA antibodies. This proposal leverages a novel form of engineered T cell therapy to eradicate the cells responsible for producing these antibodies in patients on the kidney waiting list.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) caused by prenatal alcohol exposure have high prevalence (2-5%) in the US and the world. The proposal will investigate if prenatal ethanol exposure-induced persistent microglia activation contributes to impaired endocannabinoid signaling, which in turn leads to various synaptic dysfunctions and behavioral deficits. We will also investigate if reducing microglia activation can lead to normalization of PE-induced synaptic dysfunctions and behavioral deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative In this study, multiple institutions performing research using 7-tesla (7T) MRI research on patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) will combine data for a large scale, pooled analysis project. The investigators will refine methods for visualizing cortical and deep gray matter lesions, chronically inflamed white matter lesions, and meningeal inflammation on 7T MRI in MS and will evaluate their clinical relevance on a large scale and develop machine learning algorithms for future identification. It is expected that validating findings on 7T and their clinical relevance along with providing automated tools for analysis will lead to the use of 7T MRI as a more widespread clinical tool, resulting in earlier diagnoses, better prognostication, and more effective treatment monitoring in MS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease is a devastating and untreatable disorder that afflicts more than 50 million Americans directly and countless additional family members and caregivers. Progress toward developing treatments for Alzheimer’s disease are hampered by deficiencies in current animal models, particularly a lack of animal models (1) showing pathological hallmarks and clinical features similar to those seen in patients with Alzheimer’s disease, and (2) having similar genetic and environmental heterogeneity to people. The companion dog uniquely captures both of these features, and this proposal synergistically leverages the infrastructure and resources of the Dog Aging Project to establish the companion dog as a premier animal model for Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Animal models have provided great insight into human disease including autoimmunity, however most animal model lack the genetic diversity of human populations. We propose that the Collaborative Cross (CC) mouse strains will improve our ability to study the genetics of autoimmunity. We believe that use of the CC strains will allow us to determine those genes that regulate the molecular and cellular pathways that lead to autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired wound healing in type 2 diabetes (T2DM) is a problem of significant morbidity and cost. Inflammation informed mesenchymal stem cells derived extracellular vesicles (MSC EVs) play a significant role in enhanced bone repair and generation through its immunomodulatory potential. Using a translationally relevant and innovative dual delivery system with leucine zipper (LZ) peptide-based hydrogel and alginate beads, this application aims to evaluate the combinatorial use of engineered MSC EVs and growth factor as tools to enhance the rate and quality of bone repair in T2DM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This project is to study the cochlear micromechanical mechanisms underlying psychoacoustic phenomena by measuring the reticular lamina and basilar membrane vibrations and auditory nerve electrical responses in living cochleae. Results from this study will reveal novel mechanical mechanisms contributing to the pitch of missing fundamentals, psychophysical masking tuning curves, and gap detection. The knowledge gained from this study can be applied in clinics for diagnosing hearing loss in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying environments as novel or familiar can influence memory and the formation of internal spatial maps, which may be impaired in aging, Alzheimer’s disease, and temporal lobe epilepsy. This proposal investigates a novel inhibitory projection from the hippocampus – a brain region involved in spatial memory and spatial maps – to the supramammillary area, which is a region which can signal spatial novelty. This proposal investigates if this novel projection can signal spatial recognition and suppress spatial novelty signals, providing insight into spatial processing and into hippocampal control of the supramammillary area.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY/NARRATIVE – OVERALL  We seek to understand the nature of the pial neurovascular circuit, whose dynamics are characterized by ultralow frequency oscillations near 0.1 Hz that parcellate into separate coherent regions across the cortical mantle. Our approach consists of studies on fundamentals, in terms of optical and MR imaging experiments with mice and theoretical studies of coupled oscillator modes, and applications to humans, in terms of single vessel resolution MR measurements and modeling of oxygen transport. We will use this knowledge to form a mathematical relation between the hemodynamic patterns observed in optical and functional magnetic resonance imaging experiments and the underlying brain state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: In kidney epithelial repair cells renew by rapidly dividing and progressing through the cell cycle. This process requires dynamic cell shape changes which are controlled by the cellular actin cytoskeleton but how this works is not known. Based on our preliminary data, we will test a novel molecular mechanism whereby the actin regulator Rac1 maintains cell morphology during cell division and thereby promotes epithelial regeneration, knowledge which will aid in the development of new therapeutic targets in kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The central goal of the proposed project is to define how inflammation and the clinical morbidities associated with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) can be mitigated with non-invasive vagus nerve stimulation, known as transcutaneous auricular branch vagal nerve stimulation (taVNS). The proposed research is relevant to public health because, given the substantial life-threatening morbidity of SAH, the development of a novel non-pharmacologic method that would be low risk and rapidly scalable would reduce the societal and personal burden of post-SAH morbidity. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NINDS mission, which is to develop knowledge about the brain and to use that knowledge to reduce the burden of the neurologic disease of hemorrhagic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The vestibular sensory system housed in the inner ear sends projections to a multitude of regions in the central nervous system; however, how aging impacts central vestibular pathways is poorly understood. In this study, we propose to rigorously determine using state-of-the-art computational image analysis techniques age-related changes in central vestibular structures, and the relationship with behavioral measures of central vestibular function. Findings from this study will be used to drive further critical research questions, including 1) Does vestibular loss contribute to the accelerated decline in cognitive ability and brain structure that occurs in individuals with cognitive impairment and Alzheimer’s disease; and 2) Can vestibular interventions for vestibular loss prevent/mitigate changes in central vestibular pathways?

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative  The proposed research aims to understand the role of peer victimization (PV) in alcohol and other substance use outcomes among sexual minority adolescents. A mixed methods approach will be used to identify the proximal, longitudinal and situational conditions under which PV contributes to substance-use related outcomes. Public health implications of the study include informing the development of empirically- supported and tailored interventions to reduce PV and associated health disparities in this vulnerable population.

PHR: Project Narrative: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is an incurable and fatal disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Insects transmit a wide variety of diseases to hundreds of millions of people each year, and the geographic ranges of some of these diseases have been increasing. Many of these insects rely on their chemosensory systems to identify their human hosts, their food, and their mates. This project is designed to elucidate how these systems operate and could lead to new means of manipulating them so as to control these insect vectors of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project applies a recent methodological breakthrough in functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to investigate genetic contributions to the organization of human brain networks, such as central executive networks, whose functions are critical to a variety of clinical and developmental outcomes. Identifying genetic loci that influence the development of personalized functional brain networks and contribute to psychiatric risk will lead to novel mechanistic insights into network dysfunction in mental illnesses, improved classification of at- risk individuals, and the potential for targeted neuromodulation guided by individualized neurogenetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Next-Generation DNA sequencing is now widely used in clinical oncology to detect mutations in cancers that inform prognosis and therapeutic options, but is limited in its sensitivity for low-prevalence mutations. This proposal outlines the development and validation of inexpensive, efficient, and ultrasensitive methods for detecting cancer-relevant mutations in clinical specimens. These technologies will be immediately translatable and practical for clinical diagnostics, and will provide enhanced capabilities in a broad range of applications, including the identification of emerging cancer subclones and ultrasensitive screening for the emergence or recurrence of malignancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will clarify how the obese state impacts gene expression in anterior pituitary somatotropes, including remodeling that may result in suppression of normal function. The study will determine how this suppressed state may impact responses to environmental stress and identify the regulatory pathways that may be compromised. The study will introduce state-of-the-art technologies, which present a unique opportunity for mechanistic insights that are critical to identify targets for therapeutic intervention in the obese state.

PHR: Project Narrative  Sporadic Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a major age-related health concern in the US. Single-cell epigenomic profiling of AD vulnerable brain regions in the sporadic natural AD models (degus and dogs) is of high impact. The proposed work will generate invaluable resources for facilitating molecular and circuit studies of sporadic AD by other investigators in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a life-threatening disease that affects predominantly females of childbearing age characterized by progressive small vessel loss and right heart failure. Most current therapies work by dilating blood vessels, but no treatments have been found that can restore angiogenesis and prevent loss of small vessels. The research project presented here aims at demonstrating that Wnt7a/ROR2 is a major orchestrator for cardiopulmonary angiogenesis and its loss contributes to small vessel loss and right heart failure in PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Parkinson disease devastates individuals by disrupting vocal communication and significantly impacts health and quality of life, even in the early stages of the disease. While the prevalence of voice deficits in this population is high, little is known about the mechanisms leading to these deficits, and treatment is often ineffective. This research uses both an in vivo animal model and in vitro larynx muscle and brainstem cell culture to study whole biological pathways, molecular targets, and small-molecule therapeutics to identify new treatments for Parkinsonian vocal communication dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) heart failure is ubiquitous and deadly, however there is a limited understanding of early disease progression due to the lack of relevant human models resulting in no current effective treatments to prevent or limit disease progression. This proposal is designed to allow Dr. Forum Kamdar, an early status investigator, pursue new research directions in cardiac tissue engineering and precise gene editing through the Stephen I. Katz Early Stage Investigator mechanism to develop a 3D DMD heart model using heart cells derived from DMD patient skin cells to understand how the disease progresses with application of force and if these changes can be stopped by correcting the mutation. This research is in tight alignment with NHLBI’s mission to promote the prevention and treatment of heart diseases and enhance the health of all individuals so that they can live longer and more fulfilling lives by identifying the early causes for DMD cardiomyopathy disease progression, test dystrophin gene editing, and to ultimately develop effective, disease-specific treatments to prevent DMD cardiomyopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will advance the field of intravitreal gene therapy for inherited retinal diseases. The aims of this proposal will determine the efficacy of intravitreal compared to subretinal gene therapy, the role of pre-existing circulating antibodies in the host that may mitigate the treatment efficacy, and the degree to which ocular inflammation affects the visual rescue. Together, the aims of this study will advance the understanding of intravitreal gene therapy and its relationship with ocular inflammation and treatment efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Despite decades of research on dementia caregiving, prior work has largely focused on a primary caregiver, neglecting the reality that caregiving is provided within complex networks that have the potential to both support, but also complicate, the work of caregivers. The public health impact of this study is through profiling the shared compositional and psychosocial characteristics of caregiver networks in the nationally representative National Health and Aging Trends study and associated National Study of Caregiving to better understand how these complex networks impact the well-being and healthcare utilization of persons living with dementia such that interventions and supports may be targeted toward at-risk caregiver networks. Interventions to support these individuals require a more nuanced understanding of the complexities of caregivers’ networks, while the broader field of caregiving research would benefit from widening its perspective to fully examine these networks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Radiotherapy for lung cancer is subject to uncertainties in tissue localizations that lead to increased radiation field sizes and spillover radiation to normal tissues, increasing toxicity and limiting the ability to deliver safe and effective treatments. The goal of this proposal is to develop and validate artificial intelligence (AI) methods for tumor and organ segmentation needed for (1) treatment planning, (2) localization at each treatment fraction on cone-beam computed tomography setup scans, and (3) to quantify the feasibility of reducing treatment margins while effectively and safely delivering lung cancer radiation treatments. If successful, the developed AI software tools would result in more accurate and automated tissue localizations, including at the time of treatment, and would consequently enable more focused, less toxic radiotherapy treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We developed a novel urine-based HPV test, with test performances comparing favorably to blood-based HPV testing. Using this test, we obtained preliminary data suggesting first details of the physiological processes underlying blood cell free DNA excretion into urine. This proposal will expand on these findings and explore the potential of our test as a biomarker in oropharyngeal cancer patients undergoing curative intent radiation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop a cold triggered local anesthesia that allows patients to adjust the degree of pain relief according to their changing needs and conditions. With a single perineural injection or site infiltration, the patient can determine the onset of anesthesia, can trigger anesthesia multiple times to mimic the frequent administration of conventional local anesthetics, and can trigger anesthesia for the duration of post-operative pain state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People rely on cognitive abilities to function in situations and natural environments experienced in daily life, but research studies assess cognition in “one-shot” in a laboratory or clinical setting, which can yield unreliable results. This study will develop a smartphone app carefully designed to assess cognition with several brief (<3 min) tests per day over the course of a week in people with Down syndrome (DS) at risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). If successful, this study will provide new insights into DS-AD and could lead to faster results from clinical trials.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With increasing awareness of oncofertility, more patients are seeking out fertility preservation options. For pre- pubertal female patients, ovarian tissue cryopreservation is the only available option, but it has been optimized for adult ovaries. This work investigates how the pubertal transition affects the structural, cellular, and molecular microenvironment of the pediatric ovary to improve and expand reproductive options for pediatric cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF CONNECTICUT SCH OF MED/DNT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globoid cell leukodystrophy (GLD) is a genetic disease characterized by severe neuroinflammation and demyelination, leading to a very early death in most affected individuals. Excitingly, we have discovered that T-cells are present in diseased brain tissue of GLD and they appear to be engaged with a highly activated glial cell type called microglia which we think underlies the aggressive nature of this disease and its pathology. The goal of this project will be to define how these microglial cells function as professional immune cells to foster the pathological activity of T cells and drive brain injury in this untreatable disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The development of new chemotherapeutic approaches for the treatment of infectious disease is, by acclamation, one of the preeminent challenges of modern biomedical science. This Phase II proposal is designed to strengthen and enhance the investments and infrastructure established in Phase I for the Center for Chemical Biology of Infectious Diseases. The CBID Center will continue to address critical gaps and enable researchers at the University of Kansas (KU) and associated institutions to apply these tools to better understand and potentially prevent infectious diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative National studies show that the third leading preventable causes of death in the United States are alcohol-related, emphasizing the importance of early detection of vulnerability to develop alcohol use disorder ( AUD ), for prevention and treatment. In this project, we will use rich to predict , as well as identify biological, clinical, and demographic features associated with this disease. We will conduct our analyses in AUD diagnosed and unaffected populations stratified by age, sex, and ancestry, which will help advance our understanding of longitudinal multi-modal data and innovative machine learning methods AUD AUD in groups underrepresented in the literature, especially African Americans and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are unanswered questions regarding the effectiveness of the recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) on the development and course of herpes zoster (HZ) and herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO). Our proposed project will provide needed information on the changing incidence of HZO and uptake of RZV since implementation, as well as the long-term, real-world effectiveness of the vaccine against HZ and HZO and the effectiveness in under-studied populations with immunocompromising conditions or with a history of HZO. This information could be used to justify support to increase vaccination efforts and to inform recommendations on age-eligibility, the need for additional doses, or to target specific populations to reduce the burden of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed work is to develop a high-fidelity, adaptive electronic interface to the nervous system, capable of interfacing to large populations of neurons at cellular resolution, and use it to probe the function of the parallel visual pathways in behaving animals. The technology will be developed by a team with expertise in neurophysiology, visual behavior, electrical engineering, materials science, surgery, and computation. This platform technology will be used to probe fundamental questions about the function of the early visual pathways, and will be generalizable to a wide variety of scientific and clinical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Bringing together teams from three complementary disciplines, vaccinology, immunology, and systems biology, we propose to use novel methods for machine learning to examine multiple immune parameters in older healthy weight and obese individuals who are weak and robust responders to advanced-generation influenza vaccine. Analyses include single cell transcriptional and chromatin (multi-ome) profiling of the innate and adaptive compartments, cytokine profiling, multi-dimensional antibody profiling, and enumeration of HA-specific memory B and plasma cell precursors. We will combine transcriptomic, epigenetic and cytokine datasets to uncover both predictive correlates and causal latent factors of variable immunogenicity and compare them between healthy weight and obese individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Relevance: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) covers 70% of the dementia spectrum. It is the 6th killer of people 65 and older in the US and yet the five indicated drugs lack clinical efficacy in slowing disease progression or modifying the disease. Since the disease is multi-factorial, this project will generate single molecules (via structural modifications of Tubastatin A) endowed with combo-activity via sigma receptor signaling and histone deacetylase-6 or HDAC6 isozyme (two promising targets for countering neurodegeneration and declines in cognition), in an effort aimed at probing novel druggable mechanisms towards the ultimate development of disease modifying pharmacotherapeutics for AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative and Public Health Relevance Heart failure is a leading cause of mortality in the United States. Cardiac b1 adrenergic signaling is a critical regulator of cardiac function. We aim to characterize a novel pool of intracellular b1 adrenergic receptor that is essential for cardiac function. We aim to find how to target this pool of receptors in enhancing cardiac function in heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mono-allelic antigen receptor gene expression is a hallmark of adaptive immunity that ensures mono-specificity of B and T cells. The applicant discovered that signals emanating from antigen receptor gene assembly on one allele transiently feedback inhibit this process on the other allele to help achieve mono-allelic expression. The applicant presents new preliminary data that identifies two components that might govern inter-allelic control of antigen receptor gene assembly. The applicant proposes experiments to elucidate underlying mechanisms for each component and test their roles in enforcing mono-allelic antigen receptor gene assembly and expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately one-third of pharmaceuticals target a single large class of proteins, the G-protein coupled receptors. This same receptor superfamily is used by olfaction to detect chemicals. This proposal aims to develop a system-wide understanding of the relationship between receptors and the chemicals they detect, and may lead to new principles for understanding how to model or target these receptors.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The creation of holistic K-12 programs that spark student interest in science, empower their academic pursuits, and provide them with bona fide research experiences is essential to enhance the migration of talented, STEM-focused, minoritized students into college STEM majors. Such efforts are essential for the U.S. to realize the immense latent scientific potential contained within its diverse population. By leveraging partnerships with community K-12 organizations and listening to the needs of our partners and their students, we have sculpted a new, integrated program that will provide holistic training and support to minoritized, low- income high school students to help them succeed in STEM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To improve pediatric kidney transplant survival, we propose to investigate how non-invasive MRI and contrast- enhanced ultrasound imaging biomarkers may detect and predict allograft injury at-risk of failure. This research is highly relevant to public health as it targets improving long-term health outcomes globally by validating more accessible imaging technology and enhancing personalized management based on individual imaging patterns of kidney transplant dysfunction; imaging as surveillance tool to assess allograft health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bleeding or excessive blood clots are concerns in multiple diseases, injury, and in many other situations that require blood thinners/anticoagulants. It is difficult to manage these conditions in limited-resource settings, especially since current tools to test blood are expensive, cumbersome, and slow. To overcome these drawbacks, we will create a low cost, highly portable, accurate paper-based clotting analysis test (P-CAT) to assess characteristics of blood clotting, while requiring no external power, similar in concept to rapid antigen tests used for COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth obesity and related disparities are increasingly recognized as a systems problem requiring multi-level, multi-component interventions. Learning from positive deviator schools who show unexpectedly low obesity prev- alence, the proposed study aims to identify factors in food systems that may have contributed to the low preva- lence in these schools and assess the applicability of these factors in other disadvantaged school settings using simulation models. The results of this study will advance our understanding of obesogenic factors in food sys- tems affecting schoolchildren and propose potential changes in food systems to improve diet among youth and mitigate youth obesity disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Oral diseases remain highly prevalent and greatly affect the health of the US population. In addition, there is a well-documented shortage of faculty members in US dental schools and a persistent need for research and improved dental treatments. Therefore, building on our expertise in research training, our goal is to train a cadre of highly skilled scientists who can successfully address the new opportunities in dental, oral, and craniofacial research and serve as future academic faculty in US dental schools.

PROJECT_TITLE: Craniofacial Oral-biology Student Training in Academic Research (COSTAR)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systematic tuberculosis (TB) screening is recommended for all HIV-infected individuals living in TB endemic areas to identify individuals without active TB who are eligible for preventive therapy, an intervention proven to reduce both TB incidence and mortality. However, tests to rule-out TB perform poorly in people living with HIV resulting in millions of eligible individuals being denied this life-saving intervention. We plan to perform a clinical trial to determine whether a more accurate and efficient approach to TB screening – screening based on C-reactive protein levels – reduces TB incidence and mortality by increasing uptake of TB preventive therapy in people living with HIV. Because successful scale-up of TB preventive therapy has been projected to prevent hundreds of thousands of new TB diagnoses and save tens of thousands of lives, findings from this trial have the potential to have enormous clinical and public health impact and are essential for informing future TB/HIV policy.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A gap of knowledge exists in haploid sperm formation with regard to how male germ cells initiate meiotic cell cycle for homologous recombination and reduction of chromosome content. In this project, the investigators will determine the novel role of autophagy, a protein and cellular organelle recycling process, in regulating meiotic initiation. In addition to providing new research directions in studying this process unique to sex cells, the study will offer new approaches for the treatment of male infertility, contraception, and production of haploid sperm cells in culture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A fundamental understanding of how transcription factors control early development events in human is a critical question in basic biology research. This project uses a new large-scale, systematic approach to study the function of these factors. This work is critical to understand basic mechanisms of development and disease as well as provide knowledge that can be directly applied to develop new applications in regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: This multisite mechanistic randomized crossover trial in 180 adults with prediabetes will take place in metropolitan Chicago, IL, and Minneapolis/St. Paul, MN. Comparisons will be made between the effects of six weeks of walking (150 min/week) in natural urban greenspaces and urban areas lacking greenspace. The primary outcomes include measures of psychosocial and physiological stress, air pollution exposure, and biological risk markers for diabetes, inflammation, and cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRDs) are among the most devastating and challenging societal health concerns that we face. The studies described in this application will characterize the cognitive decline and temporal and spatial progression of tau-based pathology in a rhesus monkey model of tauopathy using comprehensive cognitive assessments, in vivo PET and MRI imaging, longitudinal plasma and CSF biomarkers of degeneration and inflammation, with postmortem quantitative microscopic analyses. Such studies will improve our understanding of the progression of degenerative processes related to tauopathy and provide a powerful translational platform for testing new therapies designed to prevent or modulate the degenerative cascade of AD and ADRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This R01 proposal will develop novel nanoformulations of CF10, the first DNA-based fluoropyrimidine (FP) polymer. CF10 displays improved anti-cancer activity relative to standard of care 5-FU in pre-clinical colon cancer models and an improved toxicity profile. Lipid nanoparticle (LNP) formulation and conjugation with polyethylene glycol (PEG) polymers will be implemented to improve CF10’s pharmacological properties. Further, our nanomaterials will be targeted specifically to tumor tissue using a tripeptide motif, RGD, recognized only by malignant cells. We prepare for the first time FP polymers including EdU, a nucleotide analog with complementary cytotoxicity to CF10, and implement the most effective nanoformulation to deliver the most potent FP polymer. Our project will produce a novel nanomaterial with exceptional antitumor activity for clinical development.

PHR: Project Narrative. Post-translational modifications of histone proteins regulates gene expression and dysregulation is associated with a wide range of diseases, making them an important medicinal target. However, many of the fundamental molecular mechanisms are still poorly understood and new chemical tools are needed to advance the field. This proposal develops new approaches to address these challenges and advance biomedical research in the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Podocyte dysfunction, due to defective insulin signaling, oxidative stress or accelerated senescence, is a key determinant of progression of diabetic kidney disease, a severe disease that afflicts hundreds of millions of people worldwide and imposes a heavy burden on the treasury and health-care systems with no definitive treatment available yet. Our preliminary data demonstrated that glycogen synthase kinase (GSK)3β is hyperactive in glomerular podocytes in clinical and experimental diabetic kidney disease, correlating with the severity and progression of diabetic kidney injury. We now propose to continue to examine the role of GSK3β in the pathogenesis of diabetic kidney disease in hopes of developing innovative therapies to halt the progression of diabetic kidney disease by targeting GSK3β with the ultimate goal to improve kidney health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: SCORE NARRATIVE The Brigham and Women's Hospital/Harvard Medical School SCORE Center for Stress and Neural Regulation of Reproductive Aging Health Outcomes will address an important knowledge gap in our understanding of how 1) social and metabolic stress exposures that are more common or unique in women result in health problems during and after menopause—bothersome hot flashes, sleep problems, body fat gain, heart disease; and 2) dissect the brain circuity’s response to stress that drives these health changes during and after menopause. Our Brigham/Harvard SCORE will catalyze women’s health and sex/gender difference research and grow the next generation of investigators in this field. Results of our studies will produce a significant public health impact in aging women by understanding the role and mechanisms of stress in producing midlife women’s health outcomes that are linked with cardiovascular disease and dementia.

The LAC will also ensure engagement of the Brigham/Harvard SCORE with the broader SCORE research consortium. PHR: Narrative: This NCBIB will develop, translate, and disseminate novel noninvasive metabolic imaging technologies to enhance biomedical research, diagnosis, and management in the areas of oncology, cardiovascular disease, neuropsychiatry, and musculoskeletal disorders. These technologies will have substantial impact on the fundamental understanding of disease mechanisms, early diagnosis, and development of novel therapies for several diseases such as Alzheimer’s disease, Epilepsy, Arthritis, Cancer, Stroke, and heart disease, and thus contribute to precision medicine and enhanced patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: SLEEP RESOURCE CORE NARRATIVE The Sleep Resource Core (SRC) will be integrated into this SCORE by providing equipment, analysis, sleep- related expertise, and sleep data to the two human, one animal, and relevant Career Enhancement Core projects. The scientific leadership and technical support to facilitate and integrate rigorous collection, processing, analysis, and interpretation of sleep measures, will enable the SRC to promote interdisciplinary, collaborative, synergistic, and translational work and support the scientific and career enhancement goals of this SCORE. This work will expand the scientific impact of the SCORE by including sleep as a key health measure in human and animal models of women’s health and aging, including impacts on response to stress; body composition; neurological, cardiovascular, reproductive, and metabolic function; cognition; and mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novel strategies to treat pancreatic ductal cancer (PDA) are urgently needed due to its very poor prognosis. Branched chain amino acids (BCAAs) are avidly consumed by the normal pancreas, and circulating BCAA levels are elevated in both PDA and obesity, a strong risk factor for PDA. We propose here that BCAAs contribute to PDA in two keys ways, first by directly promoting tumor initiation, and next by promoting a systemic environment highly supportive of PDA growth, and will test these hypotheses with a range of mouse models and comprehensive studies on the roles of BCAAs in PDA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinol-binding protein 2 (RBP2) is found solely in the adult intestine and its role in dietary vitamin A uptake and metabolism by absorptive cells is well studied. However, in the previous grant period, we established that RBP2 is also expressed in non-absorptive cells in the gut, including in incretin hormone-secreting enteroendocrine cells and in the colon. We are proposing studies aimed at identifying the actions of RBP2 in the synthesis and secretion of incretin hormones in the small intestine and in the colon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Hot flashes and night sweats, or vasomotor symptoms (VMS), affect up to 85% of postmenopausal women, persist 10 or more years in 33–40% of postmenopausal women, and are strongly liked with stress, which exerts its effects through the brain. Understanding biological mechanisms underlying VMS occurrence and persistence will have significant public health impact because VMS affect so many women, have a negative impact on quality of life, and are associated with sleep disruption and cardiometabolic disease, which increase susceptibility to dementia in aging women. As part of the Brigham/Harvard Center for Stress and Neural Regulation of Reproductive Aging Health Outcomes, this study will advance the health of postmenopausal women by determining stress responses, neural processes, and neurobiological mechanisms that are affected when VMS occur and persist.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Exposure to interpersonal violence (IPV) is associated with long-term negative mental health consequences, including an increased risk for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), especially in women. Our previous studies examining the impact and timing of IPV experienced during specific developmental windows revealed increased psychophysiological reactivity and a unique EV protein signature belonging to a 17q21 gene cluster and associated with skin keratinocytes, specific to Merkel cells and only found when IPV was experienced between 14-18 yrs. Our overarching hypothesis to be examined here is that tactile-based IPV trauma exposure during late adolescence increases the sensitivity of threat circuitry, and we propose a cross-species translational study to examine molecular and physiological analyses of the RDoC Acute Threat construct.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE During perimenopause, women experience dramatic changes that extend beyond cessation of menses, including alterations that accelerate the aging process and elevate risks for cardiometabolic diseases cognitive impairment, and dementia as well as Alzheimer’s disease. This Project will investigate physiological and social stressors in early life and around the time of pregnancy as predictors of body composition, neuropsychiatric symptoms, and sleep duration and quality in mid-life. Results from the proposed series of investigations have the potential to influence clinical care of aging women through informing both guidelines on screening and long- term follow-up from the reproductive years into menopause and research priorities related to cardiometabolic diseases and dementia risk profiles in women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative  Translesion DNA synthesis, the predominant DNA damage tolerance pathway in humans, promotes cell survival in the face of DNA damage by allowing replication of a damaged genome to continue. Tight regulation of translesion DNA synthesis is critical as dysfunction can selectively propagate cells with increased mutagenesis or gross chromosomal rearrangements, which can lead to cancer. This research proposal seeks a fundamental, molecular understanding of human translesion DNA synthesis to identify dysfunctions that promote disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Reproductive aging in women (i.e., menopause) leads to a number of distressing physiological alterations associated with the decrease in circulating estrogens, among which vasomotor symptoms (also referred to as hot flashes) significantly disrupt sleep and disturb quality of life and may be relevant to subsequent risk of adverse health outcomes such as cardiovascular disease and dementia. Stress can affect the severity of vasomotor symptoms; however, the mechanisms underlying the control of thermoregulation by sex steroids and how this can be modulated by stress remain unknown. We aim to address this knowledge gap by using a series of genetic, behavioral and pharmacological approaches to identify the neuronal circuitry connecting the reproductive axis, stress, thermoregulation, and sleep quality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The dorsal endopiriform nucleus (DEn) is a long, thin subcortical brain region that is highly connected with the limbic circuit and considered by some to be the limbic component of the claustrum, however its function remains largely unknown. We have found a non-dopaminergic projection from the ventral tegmental area (VTA) to the DEn that is strongly inhibited by mu opioid receptor activation. Here we propose to anatomically and functionally characterize the neural connection from the VTA to the DEn and investigate the contribution of this connection to behavior.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Increasing molecular evidence suggests a lifelong trajectory of lung impairment from prenatal lung development to asthma in childhood to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in adulthood. Multi-omics data collected over time across well-characterized cohorts hold the potential to understand this complex disease progression. Here, we propose to apply network-based computational methods that will integrate and jointly analyze genetic, epigenetic and transcriptomic data to better understand the temporal progression from fetal lung development to childhood asthma, and to determine the key molecules mediating between asthma and COPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This project will use data from the robust Midlife in the United States (MIDUS) study to address how social connectedness contributes to reducing the risk of poor mental health outcomes among Black adults in the United States. Quantitative and qualitative findings are proposed to elucidate key psychosocial pathways and mechanisms relevant to the social experiences of Black adults, particularly those who reside in socially disadvantaged urban neighborhoods. Results are anticipated to have broad translational importance for reducing racial health inequalities and catapult future research on social connectedness in this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammasomes are large protein complexes that trigger inflammatory responses in the presence of injury or infection. Inflammasome dysfunction leads to chronic inflammation; an underlying cause of several human diseases such as atherosclerosis, rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, cancer, and neurological disorders. This project is relevant to public health because it proposes to broadly reduce inflammation by capturing extracellular inflammasomes using a hydrogel technology that does not require drug loading and is tunable to potentially create implantable, injectable, and sprayable hydrogels for expanded biomedical applications.

PHR: The goal of our Program is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) recruits and controls host DNA damage responses to ensure the fidelity of the viral genome. Importantly, this work will define the mechanisms by which HCMV evolves antiviral resistance. Despite advances in diagnostics and therapeutics, HCMV remains a major life-threatening complication following solid organ or stem cell transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Microbial communities relevant for human health are often dense, spatially structured, and interact both chemically and physically, for example by releasing toxins to prevent infection by external colonizing pathogens and building localized pressure to penetrate soft tissues. Our work will reveal the impact of mechanics and microbial antagonism on the evolutionary trajectories of microbial communities and will help us understand how spatial constraints impose selective pressures that lead to the increased invasiveness of microbial infections. By investigating the factors required for the successful replacement of a microbial strain by an invading antagonist, our results will help design better strategies for microbiome engineering and microbial replacement therapies.

PHR: Neuroinvasive herpesviruses are the causative agents of a number of severe diseases including encephalitis, shingles, neonatal infections, and keratitis. The goal of these studies it to develop a working understanding of the neuroinvasive properties of these viruses with the expectation that the research will lead to new resources in the continuing effort to develop antivirals, vaccines, and viral vectors for repair of in-borne genetic errors and treatment of nervous system associated cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peroxisomes and lipid droplets (LDs) are organelles generated in the subdomains of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane. The proposed research seeks to characterize the ER subdomains using yeasts and mammalian cell culture to identify the proteins and lipids essential for the formation of nascent peroxisomes and LDs. This work will have implications for neurological disorders associated with peroxisome function as well as metabolic diseases of improper LD storage including lipodystrophy, fatty liver and type 2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reduced positive affect is a core symptom of stress-related psychiatric disorders, including depression and PTSD, where incidence is higher among females, and current treatments are not as effective as they need to be. Recently, we demonstrated that real-world experiential diversity – exploring new, varied, and different places – predicts increased real-world positive affect, and that this relationship is supported by the strength of hippocampal-nucleus accumbens interactions–a stress susceptible circuit responsible for assigning reward value to novelty. This project will expand this finding in a large sample to define the mechanisms of the complex behavior of experiential diversity to test whether specific types of experiential diversity are most effective at driving affective change, identify the biological mechanisms supporting these effects, and determine whether experiential diversity causes changes in positive affect to improve treatment of anhedonia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our goal is to elucidate the pathways through which county-level structural racism influences hypertension and its risk factors among 30,000+ Black and White participants in counties across the US from the REasons for Geographic and Racial Differences in Stroke (REGARDS) longitudinal cohort. Building on our research using our novel multi-domain measure of structural racism, this multilevel analysis will quantify the contribution of structural racism to hypertension risk factors, morbidity, and severity, and estimate hypertension healthcare costs that could be saved if structural racism was eliminated. This work will provide evidence for structural racism as a fundamental cause of persistent Black-White hypertension disparities and has the potential to impact policy decisions that can reduce hypertension disparities by addressing structural racism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal seeks to elucidate the immune-suppressive mechanism of FGL1, a novel LAG-3 functional ligand, on the regulation of T cell responses in the tumor microenvironment and explore its prognostic value in cancer immunotherapy. We will also characterize a series of new antibodies targeting LAG-3 that differentially block either or both FGL1/MHC-II ligands, both functionally and structurally, and explore better approaches targeting the LAG-3 pathway in the control of tumor immunity for clinical application. The successful completion of our proposed studies will provide important insights into FGL1/LAG-3 cancer immunobiology and suggest new approaches for next-generation cancer immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TOLEDO HEALTH SCI CAMPUS
PHR: Project Narrative  There is an ongoing substance abuse epidemic in western society. Synthetic psychoactive agents are among the newest, most popular, and least understood of the abused substances. This work focuses on the development of a new platform to understand bath salts and related agents to define novel therapeutic targets to treat toxicity and episodic lethality.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will test whether metformin, a drug currently approved to treat diabetes, can be safely used to improve the response to antibiotic treatment of non-diabetic TB in patients with HIV. We predict that metformin will speed up the response to antibiotics and prevent lung damage that afflicts half of all patients who are cured of TB. Positive results from this clinical trial could change the way that TB is treated around the world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Age-related hearing loss is one of the most common conditions in the elderly. Many genetic factors causing hearing loss have been identified, but many more remain to be identified; and our lack of knowledge about the mechanisms by which they cause hearing loss is a barrier that must be overcome if we are to develop methods for preventing (or reversing) age-related hearing loss. This project will develop computational tools that will greatly accelerate the pace of genetic discovery for hearing loss and will characterize the mechanism by which genetic factors cause spontaneous hearing loss in multiple inbred mouse strains.
