IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: People with HIV (PWH) are facing increased morbidity and mortality due to non-infectious heart, lung, blood, and sleep (HLBS) disorders with many unanswered questions in the current era including the role of emerging risk factors such as COVID-19, newer antiretroviral therapy (ART) medications, non-traditional risk factors such as social determinants of health, and the increasingly complex interactions of HLBS conditions with each other. This proposal builds on the large, diverse CNICS cohort of PWH with comprehensive clinical data, specimens, and sociobehavioral measures to study understudied important HLBS conditions such as obstructive sleep apnea, as well as to study evolving risk factors for other conditions such as myocardial infarction, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and venous thromboembolism. New and timely knowledge about the increasing complexity of HLBS conditions among PWH including screening, risk factors, and complex interactions of HLBS conditions with each other and other syndemic conditions will inform clinical decision-making and improve understanding of the mechanisms that increase the frequency of HLBS diseases and risk of poor outcomes in PWH in current clinical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to outdoor air pollution is a risk factor for “accelerated” aging and Alzheimer’s disease, but very few studies have used neuroimaging to define the mechanistic underpinnings of these relationships. This proposal will address this gap through a new environmental working group within the ENIGMA consortium. This will be the first international study to assess how AP 1) affects the structural integrity of the CAN in older adults across geographically diverse datasets, 2) interacts with biopsychosocial factors to influence heterogeneity in AD risk within the aging brain, and 3) influences brain integrity across the life course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TSCORE LIFT will create a community linkage among 5 health systems, 5 universities, and 5 school districts to develop and test a series of 3 educational interventions along the Kansas Health and Biosciences Career Pathway. The community linkages will empower 25 teacher partners to deliver educational content and real life experiences in the health care industry for 1,400 students. This novel health and bioscience program will create educational and workforce pathways for students underrepresented in the health care industry and address critical workforce shortages in the state in the immediate future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: This project will address important challenges of understanding deficits in structural and functional brain networks underlying the transition from regular drinking to Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD) by investigating multidomain measures of brain function—structural/density-weighted/functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (s/d/fMRI) longitudinal electrophysiological (EEG, Event Related Potential/Oscillation (ERP/ERO)) and neurocognitive data in a genetically informative enriched high risk diverse adolescent and young adult prospective study sample, now entering the understudied age of emerging adulthood to midlife. With the use of novel analytic methods to leverage this unique high risk longitudinal multimodal dataset, with data from before and after the initiation of drinking behaviors, this study will elucidate reciprocal relationships among genomic and other risk/protective factors (e.g., COVID-19 related traumatic stress), sex differences and the role of vulnerabilities in neural circuits in the transitions to AUD with utility in prevention and treatment initiatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US Food and Drug Administration is considering reducing nicotine levels in cigarettes so that they are nonaddictive, which could have long-term implications for vulnerable populations that are disproportionately harmed by smoking. This study will use simulation modeling methods to conduct health and economic impact analysis of a reduced nicotine cigarette policy for two vulnerable populations; people with major depression and socioeconomically disadvantaged women of reproductive age. The policy will furthermore be assessed in the context of e-cigarette use and a potential illicit market for normal nicotine cigarettes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Vaccines are urgently needed to prevent genital herpes and treat people already infected. We developed an nucleoside-modified mRNA vaccine candidate to prevent genital herpes that will enter phase 1 human trials in December 2022. In this renewal application, we propose using serum samples from mice and guinea pigs collected during the prior grant cycle to define the immune correlates of protection for the prevention vaccine, and to immunize mice and guinea pigs with nucleoside-modified mRNA antigens to develop a vaccine for treating genital herpes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The direct care workforce – which includes personal care aides, nursing assistants, and home health aides – is the largest occupation serving people living with dementia, but there is little research to guide evaluation and refinement of workforce-related policies and programs that affect their supply, demand, training, skills, and collaboration with other healthcare professionals. The AWARD Network will offer programs and activities to create a strong community of researchers engaged in research on the direct care workforce and its role in care for people living with dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 30% of people recovering from critical illness experience respiratory infections, tracheobronchitis, while weaning from the mechanical ventilator. Despite how common these infections are, we do not understand the long-term impact on recovery, why some people are more susceptible to the infections, or the airway bacterial dynamics during infection. Understanding the natural history and host-pathogen biology of tracheobronchitis during chronic critical illness will improve our ability to develop better diagnostics and more personalized treatments for tracheobronchitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative.  We will identify the global transcriptional network, which is utilized by pulmonary microvascular endothelial cells to regulate lung remodeling and fibrogenesis. Focusing on FOXF1, a key endothelial anti-fibrotic transcription factor, we will determine novel molecular mechanisms through which FOXF1 inhibits the re- programming of normal endothelial cells into fibrosis-associated endothelial cells. We will test the efficacy of nanoparticle based FOXF1 gene therapy to treat lung fibrosis in mouse models. The outcomes from proposed studies are expected to have a positive impact on the development of new therapies for IPF patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Relevance to Public Health By defining the mechanisms of PALB2 and the BRCA1-PALB2-BRCA2 pathway in the DNA damage response and tumor suppression, this study will advance our understanding of hereditary breast cancer development and tumor cell vulnerabilities. Results from this study may inform the rational design of novel approaches for the prevention and better treatment of the cancers. Insights from this study may also apply to other, hereditary or sporadic cancers associated with DNA damage, and therefore have broader implications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Skeletal muscle is unusual in that the functional cell (the contractile myofiber) is formed by fusion of hundreds (in mice) to thousands (in humans) of individual myocytes. To become a myocyte capable of fusion, a myoblast must commit to never proliferating again, so there are adverse consequences for the animal if cells differentiate too slowly, too quickly, or without enough other myocytes nearby that they can fuse with. Our work suggests a contact-mediated mechanism by which a differentiated myocyte can signal to surrounding myoblasts that it has differentiated and is available for fusion, which promotes differentiation in those myoblasts, which then differentiate and signal to their neighbors, and so on, leading to rapid and coordinated differentiation of the whole population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH NARRATIVE The aging and rural populations of northern New England suffer from numerous chronic health issues, including cancer, obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and substance abuse. The Northern New England Clinical and Translational Research Network, which includes healthcare, educational and research institutions in Maine, Vermont, and New Hampshire, has helped build a foundation for clinical and translational research in the tri-state region. In this renewal application, our goal is to strengthen our network of clinical and translational research through a learning infrastructure that is supported by the principles of diversity, inclusion, and equity, for the benefit of all residents in our region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Despite decades of significant progress, cancer is still one of the leading causes of death worldwide. We discovered that an antibody that binds to the G protein-coupled receptor, GPR160, has a direct anti-cancer effect against human colon cancer and triple negative breast cancer cells and greatly increases the effect of the cytotoxins, oxaliplatin and cisplatin. Our goal is to develop a human monoclonal anti-GPR160 antibody suitable for testing in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Genomic instability underlies many human diseases. This project will investigate the role of the conserved HELLS ATP dependent chromatin remodelers in regulation of DNA repair and genome stability. Understanding chromatin-based regulation of genome stability is critically important to advance understanding of the molecular events leading to genome instability, and ultimately to facilitate development of new approaches in disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because the spectrum of neurodevelopmental outcomes for children exposed to Zika-virus in utero is not known at school age and this knowledge is necessary to inform primary and sub-specialty medical providers, educational systems, and public health policy. This knowledge can also improve preparedness for future infectious outbreaks that can affect the developing brain. The proposed research is relevant to NIH's mission because it aims to enhance the lives of children and optimize abilities for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic lung disease is thought to originate from the most distal airspaces, but clinical measures such as spirometry and CT are unable to probe these regions directly. In this ancillary study to the NHLBI-funded Lung Health Cohort, we will use hyperpolarized 129Xe MRI to assess alveolar structure and function in young adults at the ages of peak lung health. In doing so, we aim to determine the structural basis for low normal lung function and unexplained respiratory symptoms that may be the precursors to chronic lung disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The major genetic contribution of the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) region to disease risk has been recognized for nearly fifty years, with hundreds of associations observed in autoimmunity, infectious disease, cancer, and major drug-hypersensitivities. Because of its pivotal role in the immune response to pathogens, we expect that HLA variation will also be found to play a role in SARS-CoV-2 infection and/or COVID-19 outcomes. Here, we will examine the association of HLA and other nearby genes with COVID-19 disease outcomes and explore the molecular basis for these associations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The circadian rhythm orchestrates critical physiological functions at the molecular, cell, and organismal levels. While degradation of the circadian rhythm is known to be associated with aging and believed to contribute to Alzheimer's and other age-related diseases, the underlying molecular mechanisms remain poorly characterized. This project aims to develop and apply powerful computational tools to investigate circadian patterns of gene activity in older adults, with the goal of enabling personalized circadian medicine for an aging population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This proposal is focused on structure-function analysis of the nuclear receptor retinoic acid receptor-related orphan receptor gamma or RORγ, a transcription factor involved in regulation of glucose and lipid metabolism and immune functions. Given the importance of RORγ as a therapeutic target, it is surprising that we have an incomplete understanding of how small molecules modulate its activity where the mechanism for “turning off” RORγ activity appears straightforward, yet it is less clear how the receptor is “turned on.” The studies proposed here will illuminate RORγ activation mechanisms that will help develop better tools to study its pharmacology and can lead to new therapeutic strategies by designing functionally selective ligands.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Dysregulations or mutations found within epigenetic factors are shown to be the main drivers in many human diseases. In this study, we will investigate the function of a novel epigenetic axis comprised of BAP1/ASXL3/BRD4 by examining: 1) its mechanism involving modifications to gene expression based on chromatin signatures at active enhancer regions, 2) modulating the activity of this multi-protein complex by small- molecule inhibitors, and 3) further expanding and applying this study in the context of mouse embryonic stem cell differentiation. Ultimately, this study will help identify novel therapeutic targets to develop practical therapeutic approaches for diseases induced by epigenetic-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE RNA decay is critical for proper cellular functions and homeostasis. In this proposal, we exploit novel RNA sequencing methods to develop a mechanistic understanding of a conserved biological mechanism of co- translational mRNA decay known as “ribothrypsis”. Deciphering the biology of ribothrypsis will enhance our understanding of how gene dysregulation underlies human diseases, paving the way to the development of new RNA-based diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Sepsis-induced kidney injury is a major cause of mortality and morbidity in hospitalized patients. The kidney is a highly complex organ and propagation of septic injury involves intimate cross talk among various renal cell types. We examine the roles of renal purine homeostasis with the hope of developing targeted therapy for sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  Hypoglycemia caused by insulin usage in diabetic patients is a serious health risk which can lead to cognitive impairment, brain damage, coma, and death. The proposed research will test the novel hypotheses that astrocytes contribute to hypoglycemia-induced cerebral blood flow (CBF) increases and that long-term diabetes leads to compromised CBF regulation. A fuller understanding of the cellular mechanisms responsible for the regulation of CBF may lead to therapies for reducing the harmful effects of diabetes and hypoglycemia on the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic differences in how people metabolize cholesterol contribute substantially to the risk of coronary artery disease, which is one of the most common causes of death and disability in the USA. Large population genetic studies have flagged regions of the genome where genetic differences influence cholesterol levels, but it is unknown how these genetic differences alter cholesterol levels. We will pinpoint mechanisms driving genetic differences in cholesterol levels using CRISPR gene editing, which may lead to new therapeutic interventions to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative This study will evaluate how sex (female, male) is associated with sensory perception, appeal, and reinforcing efficacy of e-cigarette flavors in nicotine containing e-cigarettes among adult smokers. Given the low rates of cessation among female compared male smokers and its potential relationship with non-nicotine sensory cues, this proposal will elucidate the role that perception of popular flavor components (sweet, cooling) plays in e- cigarette use, behavior, and abuse liability and how this role differs by sex. The outcomes of this project will provide the FDA with new information in key areas (Behavior, Addiction) to inform potential sex differences in response to e-cigarette flavor regulations with the aim of protecting overall public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial infarction (MI, also known as a heart attack) predisposes patients to deadly cardiac arrhythmias (disturbances of the normal heart rhythm). Following MI, the sympathetic nerves in the heart undergo changes to their structure and function and these changes are associated with arrhythmias. But how exactly sympathetic nerve activity leads to arrhythmias after MI is unknown. The goal of this project is to determine the role of sympathetic nerve activity in leading to arrhythmias and to test how modulating nerve density or function may prevent arrhythmias following MI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Prostate cancer (PCa) remains a serious social and economic burden, and the American Cancer Society (ACS) estimates 191,930 new cases and 33,330 deaths in the United States from this disease in 2020. This project aims to develop a novel mRNA delivery platform for effectively restoring tumor suppressor PTEN and inducing anti-tumor immune responses in PCa, which can also be combined with immune checkpoint blockade therapy for highly potent cancer treatment. We expect this research project will form the foundation for development of a new, rational combination therapy that could significantly extend the lives of PCa patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Low-value care can result in patient harm and billions of dollars in unnecessary health care costs, yet little is known about the factors driving pediatric low-value care and how to best reduce harmful and unnecessary care being delivered to children. This proposal will study the individual and healthcare system factors associated with low-value care and survey providers about perceived barriers to de-implementation. The results will provide the foundation needed to test de-implementation strategies in real-world conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm (ATAA) is a highly lethal event because it renders the aorta vulnerable to dissection, which is the fifteenth leading cause of death in the United States. Due to a lack of understanding of ATAA at the cellular and molecular level, care of patients has been limited to open heart surgery only for advanced-stage aneurysm or for dissection. The two primary objectives of this proposal are to 1) better understand the biology of ATAA to uncover new therapeutic targets aimed at preserving aortic wall integrity and preventing aneurysm progression and 2) develop a multi-parameter, patient-specific (bio)image-based interrogation strategy to develop new diagnostic tools for early detection and better surveillance of ATAA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improvements in individual and public health depend on engaging and training a multidisciplinary cadre of scientists from multiple disciplines and with diverse perspectives and then encouraging and supporting them to come together in highly functioning teams to tackle important and unsolved problems in human and community health. Only then can we translate the explosion of new knowledge from basic biomedical research to actually develop the diagnostic procedures, preventive measures, treatments, and practice guidelines and policies to lessen the burden of disease and improve the health of every American, in every community, across the lifespan. We have developed, and seek to continue, a career development program for junior faculty scientists to enable them to contribute to this research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accurate reduction of joint dislocations is challenged by uncertainties in reckoning 3D anatomy from 2D imaging, extended use of fluoroscopy, and high risk of complications that can lead to poor functional outcomes, osteoarthritis, and disability. Proposed work develops an image-guided robotic approach to enable accurate repair of the ankle syndesmosis through automatic 3D planning, precise robotic execution, and intraoperative image-based confirmation. The solution combines modern robotics approaches with intraoperative imaging to satisfy the high technical demands of joint realignment, limit radiation dose to patient and staff, and provide accurate treatment to ultimately improve long-term patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Women living with HIV are at increased risk of precancerous cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN2/3) and standard treatment modalities for CIN2/3 are less effective in HIV-infected women. We propose to evaluate the acceptability, feasibility (safety, tolerability, adherence, retention), and preliminary efficacy of a combination treatment strategy (i.e., surgery followed by topical therapy with 5% 5-fluorouracil [5FU]) in order to improve cervical cancer prevention and long-term treatment outcomes in this high-risk population. If successful, our proposed combination strategy would have broad relevance for women living with HIV in both resource-rich and resource-poor regions worldwide, including rural and remote areas of the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This timely study examines trends and predictors of unhealthy alcohol use among aging women (≥ age 50) in a large, diverse health care system, and how health services can reduce unhealthy use, with a particular focus on potential disparities for racial/ethnic minority women. We also interview patients, and providers who care for them, to gain a deeper understanding of aging women’s needs, and potential treatment strategies. Findings will inform how health systems can address unhealthy alcohol use among aging women, a critical growing clinical and public health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia and is characterized by a progressive cognitive decline and neuronal dysfunction. Although it is widely accepted that the functional failures of synapses are the initial events leading to the disease, the mechanisms that drive those failures remain poorly understood. Proper cognitive function requires an intricate balance between inhibitory and excitatory synaptic transmission. By understanding how this balance in dysregulated in AD, this study will reveal novel therapeutic targets for restoring synaptic dysfunction at the early stages of the disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE GBM is an incurable disease associated with invariable recurrence despite aggressive therapy with DNA damaging temozolomide and radiation. The focus of this application is to better understand how two specific proteins (RBBP4/p300) interacts to regulate DNA damage response genes that may contribute to the intractable nature of GBM. Ultimately, these studies may identify novel therapeutic strategy that can significantly enhance the efficacy of chemotherapy and/or radiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Research Narrative Use of cannabidiol (CBD) has been increasing rapidly across the United States, particularly among adults over the age of 55 with mild cognitive impairment and who might be at risk for Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The proposed randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trial will examine the effect of CBD biomarkers and behavioral measures associated with the progression of AD over 6 months. The information gained in this research is expected to inform public health about the effects of CBD in this population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: OVERALL – PROJECT NARRATIVE The National Center of Neuromodulation for Rehabilitation (NC NM4R) at the Medical University of South Carolina (MUSC) addresses the critical need for focused rehabilitation research infrastructure to support rigorous clinical research and to translate non-invasive neuromodulation for rehabilitation reserach approaches into effective, evidence-based interventions. The Center has become an integrated system for training researchers across the spectrum from postdocs to senior investigators, enabling critical data collection via pilot awards, advancing careers and extramural grant applications through mentored collaborative consultations, convening world leaders in the field to discuss methods and technology, and enhancing rigor and reproducibility through hands-on workshops culminating in a research-ready workforce. In the renewal, we will enhance our strategies to closely align with the priority areas indentified in the NIH Research Plan for Rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: R.220.8. Project Narrative Relevance to Public Health: Substance use disorders among youth present a tenacious public health problem and despite considerable advances in the development of efficacious treatments, novel treatments are sorely lacking. Interventions that emphasize cognitive-behavioral skills building and address motivation, but also continuing care and social recovery capital, such as the combined, Integrated Treatment for Enhancing Growth in Recovery during Adolescence (InTEGRA), show promise in helping sustain remission in cost-effective ways but need testing in larger samples for appropriateness and efficacy. Using a hybrid type I effectiveness-implementation-design, this study tests the efficacy, mechanisms, and moderators of the promising developmentally appropriate InTEGRA treatment for adolescents while investigating facilitators and barriers to widespread implementation.

The Immunology, Inflammation and Infectious Disease (3i) Training Program will guide the development of the next generation of immunology researchers with the appropriate experience and knowledge to meet this challenge.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: This proposal will assess the capacity of Health Care Systems to move guideline-based care of low back pain (LBP) to the forefront of the patient experience by rigorously evaluating a Multidisciplinary Conservative Care Model that utilizes doctors of chiropractic and physical therapists as the first point of contact for patients with LBP. The results from this study will directly inform implementation and policy efforts to improve the quality of pain management for patients suffering from LBP while simultaneously reducing opioid prescriptions, health care costs and utilization of services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart failure rates are rising globally, and the more common form of heart failure (called heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, HFpEF) has no available treatments. We propose to study South Asians, a unique group that has high rates of diabetes even with normal body weight, to understand how and why individuals develop heart failure. Studying diverse populations broadens our understanding of heart failure and will shed light into new treatments for HFpEF.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to dioxin and related ubiquitous environmental pollutants comprises a persistent human health risk to the general population. This application proposes studies examining the genomic signaling processes affecting expression of an important liver-derived metabolic hormone.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The project proposes to examine functional and structural brain correlates of reading among children obligatorily relying on a single hemisphere following hemispherectomy surgery. This research has the potential to (1) offer a novel perspective on brain plasticity by focusing on reading acquisition using solely a left or right hemisphere; (2) improve our understanding of reading outcomes for students post-hemispherectomy; (3) relate individual differences in reading outcomes to brain structure and function; (4) add to the limited research on acquired reading difficulty during childhood; and (5) update knowledge for medical and education-based stakeholders. Our discovery of neurocognitive correlates of reading in isolated left or right hemispheres will offer a novel consideration of plasticity with insights to improve our understanding of reading difficulties as well as bring attention to proactive and preventative measures in support of children with reading difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mosquito-borne La Crosse virus (LACV) is the leading arboviral cause of pediatric encephalitis in the United States (US), historically circulating in Appalachia and the Midwest. However, a novel genetic lineage (III) has been detected in the Northeastern US in multiple mosquito species, with clinical cases potentially occurring in this new region. Given the unknown public health risk associated with this lineage, this preliminary study will investigate horizontal and vertical transmission efficacies in both native and invasive mosquito species from the new (Northeastern) and traditional (Appalachia and the Midwest) regions, contrasting virus strains from all three LACV lineages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: The proposed research investigates the mechanisms of developmental toxicity of TBBPA- a high production volume flame retardant- and how it interferes with histone modification that are operant during zygotic genome activation. Through multiome assessments of genome-wide acetylation marks, chromatin accessibility and nascent transcription, we will uncover how TBBPA inhibits zygotic genome activation that results in developmental defects. The practical impact of this work is to gain a better understanding of gene products and their regulatory regions that modify zygotic transcription and can be further used in mechanistic or epidemiological studies to evaluate adverse developmental outcomes and disease mechanisms. Project Narrative

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a major population health issue affecting more than 100 million Americans and disparities in chronic pain have been widely documented, indicating minoritized racial and ethnic groups experience a higher burden of chronic pain and are at high risk for undertreatment of that pain. Asian Americans remain under- represented in pain research; evidence regarding chronic pain experiences of Asian Americans is limited, as are resources and evidence-based programs for this group. Our exploratory, developmental study will provide evidence of feasibility and acceptability of a culturally tailored psychosocial education intervention to reduce pain catastrophizing and improve pain outcomes for underrepresented and underserved minority populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic inflammation is a major contributor to the premature mortality due to cardiovascular disease observed in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. This project seeks to leverage murine models to explore the hypothesis that inflammatory arthritis trains innate immune cells leading to increased inflammatory effector function, which may provide a novel mechanism linking inflammatory arthritis and cardiovascular disease. This application seeks pilot funding for a K01 awardee (Dr. MacLauchlan, PI) in her fourth year of funding to pursue this hypothesis and outlines a plan to transition these findings into future R01 funding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Public health relevance In addition to its nutrient-absorption functions, the gut epithelium is the site in which neural, immune, microbial, and dietary factors interact. Through these interactions, the gut could regulate whole-body physiology ranging from metabolism, immunity to cognition. One important but unsolved problem is how mechanical forces naturally present in the gut could regulate the physiological functions of the gut and other tissues. In this collaborative project, we leverage the power of the model organism Drosophila and combine it with the state-of-the-art metabolomic approaches to explore the novel role of gut mechanosensing in metabolism and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of efficient new antimicrobials to Acanthamoeba keratitis is a critical need to avert future blindness. By leveraging the expertise of parasitology and ophthalmology we will test both pitavastatin and isavuconazonium sulfate against cysts and trophozoites of multiple genotypes of Acanthamoeba, and determine the efficacy of pitavastatin and isavuconazonium in an animal model of Acanthamoeba infection, either alone or in combination with each other. Successful completion of the proposed research will lead to repurposing of pitavastatin and isavuconazonium for the treatment of Acanthamoeba keratitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: NARRATIVE Immune checkpoint inhibition therapy controls intracranial disease in 50% of melanoma patients with brain metastases indicating immunotherapy can be clinically effective in the brain. Our study will develop patient derived immunocompetent organoids that can be used to study immunomodulation of the melanoma brain metastases microenvironment leading to novel therapies. By developing these strategies, we have the potential to improve the lives of up to 40% of melanoma patients who develop brain metastases which is the leading cause of death in these patients and portends a median survival of less than a year.

We will study a dual function NO donor/redox modulator as a potential therapy in preeclampsia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The molecular and cellular mechanisms by which inorganic arsenic exposure dramatically increases the risk of urothelial bladder cancer remain unclear. Using our recent discovery of a contractile zebrafish urinary bladder to leverage the many advantages of this model organism in studies of cancer genetics and environmental toxicology, we propose to develop the first zebrafish model of urothelial bladder neoplasia, and to apply single cell transcriptomics as a means to identify how inorganic arsenic interacts with oncogenic stimuli to accelerate bladder cancer initiation and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Only low-to-moderate efficacy is reported in clinical applications of magnetic fields such as transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and magnetotherapy, despite the experimentally proven fact that magnetic fields influence the spin state of photo-generated radical pairs in many flavoproteins which determine the rate of downstream reactions governing important cellular behavior. Improvement in treatment efficacy is limited due to not knowing the molecular mechanism of magnetic modulation and to the incapability to measure effective intracellular magnetic fields, which are likely heterogeneous and not equivalent to the externally applied field of TMS or magnetotherapy. To surmount the technical difficulty in intracellular magnetic field measurement, we propose a genetically encoded magnetometer (GEM) in the form of recombinant protein, with which we will demonstrate that heterogenous intracellular magnetic fields can be mapped by expressing GEM in cells at unprecedented spatial resolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dry eye disease (DED) disproportionately affects females and displays variations among different racial backgrounds. The purpose of this proposal is to investigate the sex- and race-specific disparities in tear miRNAs and proteins, and their correlation with established DED subtypes and severity. Additionally, we will establish a comprehensive database that compiles the miRNAs and proteins detected in human tear fluid, providing a valuable resource to the scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Fracture-related infection (FRI) results in prolonged and costly treatments with unacceptably high treatment failure rates as a result of biofilm formation along the fracture implants. Bacteriophage therapy is a promising novel therapeutic with anti-biofilm activity, however many aspects of this therapy are poorly understood. Consequently, improved understanding of FRI pathophysiology and knowledge gained from animal models will allow for the creation of effective and reproducible FRI-bacteriophage protocols that will contribute to our ultimate goal of expanding treatment options not only in FRI but across the field of musculoskeletal infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The purpose of this project is to understand the evolutionary dynamics between phage and bacteria as they undergo adaptation and counteradaptation to live/die pressures. By determining the mutations that drive bacterial resistance or phage killing, it will inform clinical practice through the selection of phage for cocktails that anticipate and thus prevent resistance (and improve therapeutic outcomes).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE PTP1B, a non-receptor–type oncogenic PTP, also known as PTPN1, is involved in growth factor signaling. The PTP1B gene is frequently amplified in ovarian, gastric, prostate, and breast cancers and correlates with poor prognosis. However, despite the attractiveness of PTP1B as a therapeutic target, the development of drug-like inhibitors of this enzyme has proven difficult, primarily due to low cell permeability and a lack of selectivity towards other PTPs. The goal of this proposal is to develop charge neutral inhibitors that specifically target the oxidized form of PTP1B (PTP1B- ox), which exists principally in the disease state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research program aims to advance our understanding of ADP-ribosylation—a recently discovered DNA modification implicated in critical biological processes, including DNA repair, gene regulation, and pathogen defense. By developing new tools to study this modification, we can deepen our understanding of how our bodies protect against diseases, including infections and cancer. Ultimately, our work could pave the way for novel diagnostic tools and therapeutic strategies, potentially enhancing public health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal aims to understand how spatial and temporal changes in mitochondria impact physiological states throughout the lifespan of animals. By using advanced imaging techniques and an in vivo genetic model, we propose to directly observe and analyze the location, morphology, contacts, and physiological states of individual mitochondria in different tissues and subcellular areas during aging. This research has the potential to enhance our understanding of aging and mitochondrial biology and lead to the development of novel strategies for treating diseases associated with mitochondrial dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRRATIVE Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest is a significant public health concern, affecting approximately 347,000 Americans each year, with a survival rate to hospital discharge as low as 9.0%. Although Black and Hispanic patients exhibit lower survival rates than White patients, the reasons for this health inequity remain unclear. This proposal aims to evaluate racial and ethnic differences in emergency medical services practices during cardiac arrests in order to identify specific areas in prehospital care that can be improved to mitigate this health inequity following out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Reliable biomarker assays could greatly improve diagnosis of Irritable Bowel Disorder and its various subtypes. This proposal aims to develop a method to identify nucleic acid biomarkers for IBD directly from stool samples using healthy and IBD associated specimens. Findings from this work will lead to better clinical diagnosis and subtyping of IBD, and more sensitive measurement of response to therapy, all toward the goal of improving patient outcome and reducing clinical cost and resources.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The preclinical model studies have led to many fundamental discoveries, understanding of normal and abnormal human systems, and transformed human health and medicine. The mouse models have been influential in developing novel vaccines, adjuvants, therapies, and immunotherapies. This proposal proposes to generate a novel strain mouse that helps develop the cell-specific, tailored, targeted, and interventional therapies to enhance the immunity against pulmonary fungal infections, understand the mechanisms of immune responses to pulmonary pathogens, bolster fungal vaccine efficacy, and develop therapeutic strategies against aggressive cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Disruptions in neuronal development and connectivity within the neocortex, the area of the brain responsible for high cognitive function, are found in many neurodevelopmental disorders, including autism spectrum disorders, intellectual disability, and schizophrenia. What causes this atypical development is still poorly understood, but likely includes a combination of genetic, epigenetic, and environmental factors, including maternal nutrition. We propose to employ a novel model system to investigate the mechanisms underlying how in utero exposure to a sufficient versus supplemented folic acid diet can modify neocortical development, in the context of a fixed genetic susceptibility to atypical neurodevelopment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women with severe aortic stenosis face delayed diagnosis, undertreatment, and higher mortality rates compared to men, highlighting the need for improved diagnostics and treatment strategies for female patients. By integrating innovative medical image processing and computational modeling methods, our project aims to gain sex-differentiating insights into cardiac remodeling and dysfunction in severe aortic stenosis among women, with the goal of enhancing treatment outcomes. By providing valuable insights, our research serves as a basis for guiding clinicians in patient selection, optimizing surgical timing, and ultimately enhancing survival rates for female patients with aortic stenosis in future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE B. fragilis is a leading microbial reservoir of antibiotic drug resistance, most concerning of which is through expression of metallo-b-lactamases (MBL). At present, there is a gap in knowledge on how MBL expression is preserved within the native colonic niche of B. fragilis. We have identified a novel bacterial toxin that facilitates competition of MBL-expressing B. fragilis. Understanding the molecular mechanisms by which MBL-expressing B. fragilis gain access to and preserve the colonic niche is expected to inform an understanding of how to combat spread of drug resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  These studies seek to establish a new cost-efficient scalable approach to measure the cell-to-cell variability in the function of regulatory T cells (Treg), a current unmet challenge in the field. We will modify a small-molecule glutathione (GSH) biosensor recently developed by our group and use it to test the hypothesis that cell-to-cell differences in GSH homeostasis within Tregs underlies the heterogeneity in Treg suppressive capacity and to provide proof-of-concept that this approach can capture clinically relevant heterogeneity in circulating Treg from kidney transplant recipients treated with anti-IL6-R antibody (tocilizumab).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE___________________________________________________________________ Periprosthetic joint infection (PJI) is the most common cause of acute joint replacement failure and contributes to substantial morbidity, mortality, and hospital costs following joint replacement surgery. Bacterial biofilm formation makes PJI extremely resistant to antibiotics and the host immune response, which leads to high PJI treatment failure rates. We will test a biofilm disrupting antibody (anti-DNABII monoclonal antibody) as a method to prevent and treat PJI in a well validated mouse model of PJI for enhancement of PJI prevention and treatment strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE While defective trophoblast lineage differentiation is one of the major causes of human pregnancy- related conditions such as preeclampsia (PE), underlying molecular mechanisms underlying PE have been elusive. By defining novel key regulators directly influencing the pathophysiology of PE and understanding their modes of action on trophoblast differentiation, our proposed studies aim to provide diagnostic tools and therapeutic means to improve human pregnancy outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project plans to study the pathogenesis of human diseases that are associated with HLA-B27, such as ankylosing spondylitis and anterior uveitis. Based on newly published information, they hypothesize that CD8+ T cells respond to bacterial challenges which then result in their attack of normal tissues due to cross-reactivity. Such detailed studies will require the development of a mouse model. Here the investigator presents plans to develop such a model by producing mice expressing the relevant human molecules that include HLA-B27, a relevant T cell receptor and other molecules required for optimal T cell responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulse oximetry is used to guide care for critically ill patients, but there is are concerning reports that show racial bias in pulse oximeters may overestimate blood oxygen levels in darkly pigmented patients who actually have low oxygen levels, which can cause harm by delaying or preventing timely respiratory support to these patients. The goal of this proposal is to evaluate sources of bias caused by skin pigmentation and blood perfusion, and to develop a new pulse oximeter that accurately provides blood oxygen estimates for all patients, regardless of skin color.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Pathogenic Vibrio bacteria cause the acute disease vibriosis in humans, resulting in rapid symptom progression and high mortality if untreated. Due to globally increasing rates of vibriosis and multi-antibiotic resistant Vibrio strains, we aim to develop alternative therapeutic approaches to treat vibriosis disease. We will utilize an ex vivo skin wound infection model to study Vibrio vulnificus virulence factor production and treatment with novel antibacterial compounds.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current gold standard to determine the pathogens causing infectious keratitis still includes time consuming culture of corneal samples, which leads to false negative results in many cases and delays in determining the correct treatment approach. These delays frequently cause significant complications and unfavorable clinical outcomes, including blindness. This proposal by a team of PI’s in the Bascom Palmer eye institute (BPEI) will validate a novel assay to identify ocular pathogens, allowing for rapid determination of pathogens. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pain catastrophizing—a negative cognitive and emotional process that involves helplessness, rumination, and magnification of pain complaints—is the most consistent psychosocial factor predicting deleterious outcomes in chronic musculoskeletal pain, including fibromyalgia. We will use real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) neurofeedback to illuminate the role of self-regulatory capacity in shaping the negative effects of pain catastrophizing, and the positive benefits of cognitive-behavioral therapy. In the long term, these results will enable clinicians to boost the efficacy of CBT and facilitate the development of multimodal treatment packages, while patients gain control over their cognitive and emotional responses to pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Spinal cord injuries are devastating physical injuries that cause paralysis, sensory dysfunction, autonomic nervous system dysfunction, as well as bladder, bowel dysfunction and pain. Cell therapies of these injuries that involved Schwann cells have shown promise in animal studies but have been poorly transferrable to humans. In this project, innovative optogenetic (light-controlled) genetic circuits will be built into Schwann cells to improve their therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative This research seeks to revolutionize the process of lower-limb prosthesis prescription by developing a high-precision, haptic, robotic ankle-foot prosthetic that can mimic the behavior of any commercially available prosthesis. By tailoring the prosthesis to the specific gait biomechanics and mobility needs of each patient, it has the potential to dramatically reduce the incidence of secondary complications associated with amputation, such as pain, reduced mobility, and decreased quality of life. As such, this project directly contributes to public health by enhancing the well-being and extending the active lives of individuals living with limb loss, while also reducing the healthcare costs associated with long-term disability and complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Alphaviruses include established and emerging human pathogens that cause serious diseases and are potential biodefense threats, and for which there are no antiviral therapies. This project aims to define the role and mechanisms of newly identified host cell proteins in the alphavirus infection cycle. The results will provide fundamental information on alphavirus-host interactions and inform new antiviral strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Binge drinking has detrimental effects on tissue repair and cold plasma (CP) has emerged as a promising medical tool for wound healing. This project will investigate CP’s potential wound healing benefits by characterizing CP's wound healing properties in F344 rats exposed to binge ethanol (ETOH) and studying CP’s effects on wound healing in human skin organoids treated with EtOH at binge concentration. The study outcomes shall shift the paradigms regarding the interplay between wound healing properties of CP and alcohol-induced impairment of wound healing, eventually leading to clinical application of CP in wound healing during alcohol intoxication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Leveraging 20 years of data collected annually from ages 6-26 among a low-income, underserved sample of Black youth, the current study will map the course of suicide ideation and behaviors (SIB) during adolescence and emerging adulthood, and will unveil critical risk and protective individual- and environmental factors associated with SIB course. Findings from the current study may inform etiological models of SIB in this vulnerable population and yield actionable knowledge regarding developmentally-relevant intervention targets to curb SIB among Black youth across the life course.

PHR: Project Narrative This application proposes creating several strains of knockout and transgenic mice that will allow lineage-restricted deletion of the gene Stat5B or expression of a Stat5B mutant that can form protein dimers but no tetramers. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Endovascular technologies (less invasive, more effective, and less risky) with clot retriever thrombectomy devices, flow diverters, and embolization coils, etc. have been widely used to treat cerebrovascular disease which is the 2nd leading cause of mortality in the world. However, the typical endovascular sequences often result in prolonged operational procedures and X-ray exposures due mainly to difficulties in translating proximal catheter/guidewire movements into anticipated movements at its distal end. This project will develop an innovative ? Robot-guided endovascular guidewire system controlled by a static, compact, cost-effective, and remote acoustic probe (similar to ultrasound imaging probe) that allows for full robotic/telerobotic neurovascular interventions substantially reducing the total procedure time and thus minimizing the exposure to harmful X-ray radiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An ideal engineered biomedical hydrogel should have elastic properties that match well with the native tissue that it is being integrated. Conventional mechanical testing methods have many limitations such as being destructive measurements. In this proposal, we will develop a new technique named two-dimensional acoustic force elastography microscopy (2D-AFEM) for characterizing elastic property of cell encapsulated scaffolds in various biomedical and tissue engineering applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Each year, over 100,000 patients require endoscopic (i.e. minimally invasive) surgery for kidney stone disease in the United States. Approximately 25% of these patients require repeat surgery for residual stone fragments, which can lead to obstruction, pain, kidney injury, and urinary tract infections, with more inexperienced surgeons having a higher risk of repeat surgeries. This proposal aims to create an eye gaze sharing system to improve surgical training and guidance so that trainees acquire skills faster and beneﬁt more from an expert mentor’s experience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maladaptive responses to interoceptive cues underlie several mental and physical health conditions. We propose a novel integrative treatment, Interoceptive Training Enhanced Mindfulness (ITEM), that combines interoceptive exposure with mindfulness to optimize change in anxiety sensitivity, i.e., discomfort with fear- related physiological sensations. The project will involve iterative refinement of ITEM, evaluation of its feasibility and acceptability and development of a multi-modal assessment battery for future efficacy studies.

PHR: Project Narrative  Brucella spp. are bacteria that cause a debilitating, flu-like disease in humans, and these bacteria are classified as Select Agents due to their potential use as biological weapons. Currently, treatment options for human Brucella infection are limited and often do not clear the infection. The proposed research will define a novel small regulatory RNA pathway in Brucella that may be targeted for in future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Resident memory CD8 T cells (TRM) are crucial to the immune defense of the mucosal organs. However local mucosa signals that mediate TRM differentiation, function as well as their long-term maintenance are largely unexplored. This proposal aims to use a novel 3D vaginal epithelial organoid-CD8 T cell coculture system to interrogate the molecular nature of this epithelium-T cell interaction necessary for successful TRM differentiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative We hypothesize that generating consensus on the spectrum of clinical phenotypes of status epilepticus (SE) and building an NLP-based tool, using both structured and unstructured EHR data, to identify and classify SE is essential for the creation of SE registries, needed to conduct future comparative effectiveness and pragmatic trials of SE treatment. In Aim 1, we will apply an innovative sequential mixed methods approach, using (a) a modified Delphi method to establish consensus around labels to identify relevant information elements and (b) a discrete choice experiment method to identify time-evolving attributes of progression to RSE. In Aim 2, we will leverage unstructured EHR data from two large academic centers to fine-tune and apply multiple NLP- based machine-learning models, including Large Language Models, and compare their performance in identifying and extracting cases of SE and RSE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Our ability to develop effective therapeutics to treat human diseases is greatly aided by structural descriptions of macromolecules. However, preserving these isolated targets for structural study with one of the most popular methods for structure determination, cryo-electron microscopy, is a major bottleneck in our ability to understand the mechanisms underlying disease. This proposal aims to overhaul our approach to cryo-electron microscopy structure determination in order to overcome this bottleneck, ushering in a new era of structural biology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The current proposal aims to examine the changes in the synaptic transcriptome of the primary- secondary sensory afferents structure occurring in the spinal cord during synaptic gain of function in neuropathic pain. Completion of this work will yield a comprehensive map of the transcriptomic changes that occur in the synapse during neuropathic pain and examine the factors that contribute to this highly polarized transcriptomic population. Targeting of those factors will yield new therapeutic avenues for neuropathic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative  Brucella spp. are bacteria that cause a debilitating, flu-like disease in humans, and these bacteria are classified as Select Agents due to their potential use as biological weapons. Currently, no safe and effective vaccine exists to protect against human Brucella infection. The proposed research will define a novel small regulatory RNA pathway in Brucella that may be targeted for vaccine and/or therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because the detrimental effects of physical inactivity (PIA) during the initial years of life on adult health are vastly undervalued and unknown. Early life PIA during a key period of development may result in reduced muscle quality and function such that an adult who experiences early life PIA would have the muscular function and physical capacity equivalent to someone many years their senior – premature aging. This work would stress the importance of avoiding early-life PIA to minimize healthcare costs associated with losing physical function and quality of life with earlier development of frailty.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent associations with γδ T cell infiltration and better outcome in different human tumors, the immunobiology of this T cell subset, and its potential as a platform for immunotherapies against cancer, remains elusive. The studies proposed in this application have the potential to exert a profound effect in the field of cancer immunotherapy by demonstrating that a subset of γδ T cells, which is more resilient to loss of effector activity at solid tumor beds, is a superior platform for novel Car T cell therapies against tumors that have so far remain stubbornly refractory to cellular therapies. The insight derived from these studies will provide a mechanistic rationale for novel clinical trials, designed to overcome the hitherto insurmountable challenge of controlling epithelial malignancies using cellular therapies, thus advancing towards the cure of one of the most devastating malignancies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Project Narrative As first-generation, low-income, and racial/ethnic minority students have improved their access to higher education, nutrition insecurity in US campuses has increased and threatens their academic success and well- being. College food pantries have been the most common solution but only offer short-term emergency relief, and stigma has prevented their use. To provide a longer-term evidence-based approach that honors students' choices and dignity, this research will inform the development of an adaptable campus mobile market model that consistently provides access to healthy food and promotes healthy eating.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This R03 proposal addresses a critical public health need by identifying and validating an objective, efficient, and sensitive metric for tracking social communication outcomes in a particularly vulnerable population – autistic adolescents transitioning to adulthood. To achieve this goal, we will employ cutting-edge computational linguistics techniques to analyze the precise ways in which a person’s social conversation skills improve over time as they participate in a long-term, comprehensive intervention program to learn new social communication skills. This proposal has high public health relevance because it aims to identify specific speech and language markers that will allow us to customize and optimize treatment efforts to match the unique needs of each adolescent on the autism spectrum and then rapidly, objectively, and comprehensively evaluate their ongoing response to intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic has disproportionately affected African Americans (AA) and sickle cell disease (SCD), a life-threatening condition primarily affecting AA, has magnified the impact of COVID-19 in AA community. This study will identify the risk factors, both biological and social, for adverse outcomes of COVID-19 in SCD people and characterize the features of long-COVID, a serious post-COVID sequela, in SCD population. Collectively, these discoveries will help develop risk-stratified clinical pathways to prevent adverse outcomes of high-risk SCD patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Impaired intramembranous bone regeneration can lead to failure of orhopaedic or dental implants or delayed fracture healing. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lower urinary tract (LUT) dysfunction and the conditions (i.e., disorders of urination) underlying them affect ~20% of school-aged children and >40% of adults over 40 years old, and there are known sex differences in terms of LUT condition prevalence rates and symptom score at presentation. Current understanding of the pathophysiology of sex differences in LUT dysfunction is limited by the lack of appropriate animal models in which males and females can be compared to each other. The proposed research will define sex-specific effects of chronic social defeat stress in mice on change in urination pattern, determine the impact of sex hormones on development of LUT dysfunction, and potentially lay the groundwork for a future where sex-specific assessment of treatment of LUT dysfunction is possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Creatine kinase (CK) is a protein that plays a vital role in cellular energy. Recently, we observed for the first time that blood levels of CK are decreased in childhood asthma and that children with asthma who have low CK are at increased risk of having persistence of disease into adult life. This R21 application will use data from multiple epidemiological cohorts to characterize the role of CK in blood and in the lungs in children and adults with asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular senescence has recently been found to play a critical role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD), but the underlying mechanism is not clear. This project will dissect the roles of two major senescence pathways in the development of AD cellular pathologies using induced pluripotent stem cell-based AD models. The research will provide new insight into senescence’s role in AD and the impact of aging on AD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Although aberrant PARP1 activation is linked to many neurodegenerative disorders (e.g., C9orf72-mediated amyotrophic lateral sclerosis and frontotemporal dementia or C9orf72-ALS/FTD), how protein Poly-ADP- ribosylation (PARylation) signaling contributes to the pathogenesis of these dementias is poorly understood. In this proposal, we will develop a multiplexed proteomic approach for the global, quantitative and site-specific characterization of the Asp-/Glu-PARylated proteome in C9orf72-ALS/FTD. Combined with functional studies, we will elucidate how deregulated protein PARylation events cause neurodegeneration in C9orf72-ALS/FTD.

PHR: This project will characterize and optimize a novel time and cost saving toolkit that allows simple, rapid, and robust activation of gene expression in the widely used model organism C. elegans, bringing new capabilities to systematically test the effect of gene activation in a broad range of biological problems. These capabilities will be employed to search for novel genes whose activation promotes healthy aging and increases lifespan, an important task unmet by existing tools. When complete, our work will broaden our general understanding of the genetic mechanisms that participate in aging and will identify novel potential targets for anti-aging drugs and therapies. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to understand and discover the biological factors of health disparities in lung cancer between African Americans and European Americans at the multi-omics level. An explainable artificial intelligence-based computational framework will be developed using a cooperative game theory-based machine learning approach, first, to identify patient-specific tumor heterogeneity or disparity information, second, to identify cohort-specific disparity information, and third, to discover disparity between two cohorts. The developed tool will help decipher the race- and sex-specific risk factors such as African American Males, European American Males, African American Females, European American Females, etc., which will guide better treatment strategy, thus, benefitting humanity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE How does Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV) infect most children and young adults, and remain quiescent for decades, but then re-emerge as an active infection to be transmitted to other individuals years later? During MCPyV reactivation, mutations may occur that drive the virus to cause Merkel cell carcinoma, one of the most severe skin cancers, in susceptible people. Understanding MCPyV quiescence and replication is critical to developing therapeutic and preventive measures for this cancer virus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Post-acute sequelae of COVID-19 (PASC), also known as “long COVID”, poses a significant burden on global health systems. In the current project, using hiPSC-based 2-D microglia and 3-D organoid models, we aim to identify brain-specific responses to SARS-CoV-2 that likely contribute to neurological sequelae caused by PASC. Our study will provide novel insight into how different SARS-CoV-2 strains affect microglia function including microglia-neuronal crosstalk, and facilitate the identification of druggable targets for treatment of PASC.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Policies that restrict immigrants’ access to health and other services can erode both mental and physical well- being. We propose to conduct a novel data linkage to analyze how such policies and immigration enforcement associate with measures of diet and obesity for children of Mexican immigrants using nationally-representative data collected across 10+ years. Findings from this study will advance our understanding of the multiple levels of influence that immigration policy climates can impact children of Mexican immigrants, and may in part explain why this important and growing group faces a higher burden of obesity than their non-Hispanic White peers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This project will investigate the role that cognitive health plays in socioeconomic success and wellbeing during the transition from adolescence to early adulthood using data from the Study of the Tsunami Aftermath and Recovery (STAR), a 15-year panel study of coastal communities, households, and individuals in Aceh and North Sumatra on the island of Sumatra in Indonesia, who were at risk of exposure to the 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami and representative of the pre-disaster population, as well as a specially-designed subcomponent of STAR, the Extended Assessment of Biomarkers and Cognition (EABC), which involves two- rounds of longitudinal data of a 25% randomly-selected subsample of STAR respondents that includes a tablet-based approach to precisely measuring seven different cognitive skills using game-like tasks adapted for the setting from widely-used assessments. In contrast to previous studies of cognitive functioning and socioeconomic outcomes, which have largely focused on broader, higher-level measures of cognition in high- income countries, this project uses these innovative data to provide evidence on domain-specific cognitive skills founded in neuroscience for a population-representative sample in a developing country. We will also use the richness of the STAR data to examine the role of parental and family background characteristics in the association between cognition and early adult outcomes and will leverage the unanticipated nature of the tsunami to examine the role of a large unanticipated natural disaster in moderating those relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Brain disorders including the most frequent mental disorders, anxiety and depression, show significant sex bias in prevalence and severity. The major factors that cause brain sex differences are gonadal hormones (estrogen and progesterone in women; testosterone in men) and sex chromosomes (XX in women; XY in men). By decoding female-specific X chromosome plasticity in the brain, induced by ovarian hormones, this study will open new, sex- and gender-informed avenues for treatments, with important implications for women’s brain health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Diabetic kidney disease (DKD) is the leading cause of ESRD in the USA with increasing prevalence at an alarming rate worldwide, and there are no known cures to prevent its progression. We have identified a new risk variant that controls the oxidation state of cells in the kidney in DKD susceptible mice, and plan to develop a new precision medicine therapeutic strategy. The proposed studies will uncovered XOR promoter orthologue variants in humans associated with significant risk for DKD, and provide new avenues for more effective and precise therapies for patients at risk and living with this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Sleep depth, intensity and integrity are important contributors to optimal health that, when disrupted, can escalate vulnerability to mood and behavioral problems in youth. We propose to study the impact of abnormal developmental trajectories of the sleeping brain with psychopathology in young adulthood by leveraging data from a 15-year longitudinal study of a unique cohort of children from the general population recruited for a prior R01. Findings from this study will inform novel biomarkers for clinical trials that aim at improving the pathophysiology and long-term prognosis of diverse forms of psychopathology across the life span by targeting the sleeping brain.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project is relevant to public health because it aims to study competitive interactions between the commensal bacterium Dolosigranulum pigrum and the pathobiont Staphylococcus aureus to identify novel and specific anti-S. aureus metabolites. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Public Health Statement Traumatic brain injury (TBI), even in its mildest form, can lead to long-lasting disability and cognitive dysfunction. The neural mechanisms underlying TBI-associated memory dysfunction have not been fully delineated nor are effective strategies to improve learning and memory available. The present proposal will investigate if stimulation of sharp wave-ripples in the hippocampus can be used to improve hippocampus-dependent memory after TBI.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need for noninvasive and robust endometriosis detection technologies. Although exhaled breath-based endometriosis detection can offer those advantages, primarily due to the lack of sensitivity and reliability of existing engineered gas sensors, exhaled breath-based disease diagnosis has not been implemented in clinical settings. In this proposal, we systematically validate and quantify the performance of our novel olfactory neuron-based gas sensor for early and robust detection of endometriosis using 2-D cell cultures, 3-D organoids, and in a mouse model of endometrisois.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Xylazine is a synthetic non-opioid alpha2-adrenergic agonist that has contributed increasingly to overdose deaths in the United States in recent years. We propose to develop and commercialize the first regulatory approved diagnostic device for rapid xylazine detection, using our patent pending InstaStrip technology. The resources developed in this proposal will serve as a blueprint to allow us to quickly modify the technology for other analytes and respond rapidly to emerging drug threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  “Dietary fructose and NASH/HCC progression”  The rapid rise of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)/nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) has correlated with has a corresponding increase in the prevalence of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Dietary fructose is thought to be a major risk factor for NASH→HCC progression but the mechanisms linking dietary fructose to inflammation-dependent HCC progression are entirely unknown. This project seeks to investigate a highly novel mechanistic pathway that links dietary fructose consumption to inflammation-dependent HCC progression and will explore novel therapeutic approaches with which to target.
