IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: NARRATIVE In this project we will develop and test innovative health information technology (IT) tools that support an outpatient geriatrics care Age-Friendly Learning Healthcare System with a point of care clinical decision support system that leverages patient generated health data (PGHD) and electronic health record (EHR) data reports that support Age-Friendly Health System care. The interoperable tools will be adaptable to additional healthcare systems using any EHR system and will incorporate data directly from patient reports using a patient generated data mobile application and EHR data to support clinicians and patients in shared decisions about age-friendly care. This work will support the emerging evidence base for Age-Friendly Health System care and specifically address the gap in knowledge and implementation of age-friendly approaches in geriatrics outpatient clinics.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: An Age-Friendly Learning Healthcare System: A Transformative Digital Solution for Geriatrics Clinics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To add genomic sequencing into public health newborn screening (NBS) in a way that maximizes benefits (e.g., access to life-saving treatments) and minimizes harm (e.g., treating healthy babies unnecessarily), NBS needs a way to determine for which genes babies should be screened. This project will use the experience of newborn sequencing researchers in combination with the public, parents, patients, and health professionals to identify gene selection criteria to guide ethical and appropriate decision-making on how to select genes to screen. The resulting gene selection criteria will reflect diverse perspectives and provide NBS with much needed guidance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Narrative The interactions of the brain and immune system are important in Alzheimer’s disease and other pathologies, yet are challenging to understand due to the limitations of animal models and very limited human cell culture models. Here we will develop an innovative, tissue engineered model of the communication between the human brain, meninges, and brain-draining lymph nodes. We will use this system to replicate neuroimmune outcomes in normal physiology and Alzheimer’s Disease, thus creating a platform for future study of neuro-inflammatory disease mechanisms and human-based drug testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative:  During retinal development, progenitor cells show dramatic changes in their ability to proliferate and generate specific cell types, a process which is known as temporal patterning. We have recently identified many genes that are dynamically expressed in progenitors during retinal development. We plan to test whether and how they regulate temporal patterning during development and determine whether they can induce mature retinal glial cells to reprogram into progenitor cells that generate early-born neuronal cell types such as retinal ganglion cells and cone photoreceptor receptors. These studies have the potential to form the basis for effective for cell-based therapies aimed at restoring vision in degenerative blinding diseases such as macular degeneration and glaucoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a strong medical need for a better diagnostic approach for celiac disease that accurately reflects the underlying pathogenesis and overcomes the limitations of small intestinal biopsy and antibodies to tissue- transglutaminase-2. This study will evaluate sensitivity of a novel ex vivo gluten challenge whole blood assay that is highly specific for celiac disease in adults treated with a gluten-free diet in children with celiac disease (both treated and untreated). Results of this study will guide protocol development for a multi-center clinical trial to determine the diagnostic accuracy of cytokine release following gluten challenge for diagnosis of celiac disease that may redefine celiac disease and revolutionize diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is a leading cause of medical device infections and treatment failure is commonplace due to the production of bacterial biofilm and subsequent reduced antibiotic activity along with resistance development. Our experimental approach is to investigate the impact of a. a single dose dalbavancin in combination with a single dose of daptomycin b. this combination with addition of phage, in a two-compartment pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic biofilm model. This proposal will assess the potential for antibiotic dose-de- escalation in dalbavancin-daptomycin-phage treatment using pharmacokinetic parameters and without the emergence of resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Although brain arteriovenous malformation (bAVM) is a high-risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage, especially for young patients, the treatment options are severely limited. By the notion that endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT) is a common feature in human bAVM, the current proposal will determine if EndMT can be a target to treat bAVMs using human bAVM tissues and cells. The proposal is relevant to the NIH's mission because the results of this study could lead to the development of therapeutic strategies for bAVM patients, subsequently preventing hemorrhagic stroke.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Although extensive research has focused on the molecular motor protein Myosin 5b in the intestinal epithelium, its role in the liver remains under explored. Recent studies implicate Myosin 5b in liver disorders but to date few studies have used animal models to investigate how Myosin 5b regulates liver function. This proposal seeks to address this gap in knowledge by identifying molecular mechanisms governing metabolic homeostasis in the liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 (HTLV-1) induced adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) is a rare and fatal malignancy with limited therapeutic option. Our preliminary studies revealed that ATLL cells demonstrate a robust immune-suppression phenotype and there is a unique population of markedly expanded, phenotypically exhausted CD8+ T cells at the time of diagnosis. The objective of this study is to functionally characterize the suppressive activity of ATLL cells and define new immune correlates of favorable treatment outcomes in the context of the Belinostat/Zidovudine/IFN trial (NCT02737046).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The NIA Interventions Testing Program (ITP) is a multi-institutional collaboration investigating interventions with the potential to extend lifespan and delay disease or dysfunction in mice. Data management, integration, analysis, and reuse are key to supporting discovery and inference of new knowledge to improve the predictive value of biological information in characterizing normal aging, health span, and age-related diseases. A Data Coordinating Center is critical to complement these efforts as it will be ever more vital to rely on biological data that have been rigorously curated and made publicly available, allowing the scientific community to build upon cumulative results and gain new insights about aging and health span using data from this collaborative effort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Exposure to firearm injury is associated with increased adverse health and mental health needs, further compounding existing health and racial inequities, but few interventions exist to address family and household member health outcomes. This innovative study will develop a methodology to link and define members at the family and household level and has the potential to significantly extend our understanding of the racial and health inequities associated with exposure to firearm injury (and other health outcomes) beyond the direct survivor to inform clinical and community interventions to prevent future morbidity and mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our study will evaluate the role of the endocannabinoid system in hypertension. Based on our previous data, we hypothesize that intensive (<120mm Hg) as compared to standard (<140mm Hg) blood pressure control as performed within the SPRINT trial participants will be accompanied by higher levels of the endocannabinoid anandamide and its congeners. We also hypothesize that subjects with a faster and greater rate of anandamide increase will present with increased incidence of serious adverse effects including hypotension, bradycardia and electrolyte abnormalities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Deep reinforcement learning offers the ability to learn effective empirical algorithms for hard combinatorial optimization problems on high dimensional inputs, allowing us to shift method development from hand-engineered heuristics to data-driven models that can detect and leverage complex patterns in the data. In this proposal we aim to use deep reinforcement learning for the problem of read-based haplotype assembly using data from different sequencing platforms. Improving the accuracy of the assembled human genome haplotypes will have a significant impact on population and medical genetics, and especially on our ability to better characterize and diagnose diseases caused by rare variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Impaired skin development and barrier function significantly impact health and quality of life in patients with inherited ichthyoses and atopic dermatitis. The primary objective of this work is to understand how deficiencies in three skin enriched lipases (epidermal lipases) affect skin development and skin barrier function. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE COVID-19 remains the leading infectious cause of death in children and one of the top ten causes of pediatric death in the U.S. Although other respiratory viruses co-circulating with SARS-CoV-2 may exacerbate the morbidity and mortality attributed to COVID-19, the combined effect of common respiratory viruses (i.e., respiratory syncytial virus, influenza virus) with SARS-CoV-2 is not well understood. To address this knowledge gap, this application proposes the innovative use of an existing, large national U.S. claims-based cohort to evaluate the risk and severity of viral co-infections associated with SARS-CoV-2 in U.S. children and the potential benefits of COVID-19 vaccination.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Proteins of the myelin sheath, such as myelin basic protein (MBP) and myelin oligodendrocyte protein (MOG) have been extensively studied in MS pathogenesis; surprisingly, very little is known about the changes to lipids components of the myelin sheath during the disease process, in particular as it relates to changes in the composition of key myelin lipids during relapses, remission, and progression of MS. Modifications in myelin lipids composition during disease relapses may critically affect the progression of MS, for example by providing targets for lipid peroxidation; this may provide druggable lipid-based targets, which have previously not been explored. This proposal will therefore address an urgent unmet need by determining the effects and mechanism of neuroinflammation on the composition of myelin lipids in relevant preclinical EAE models and help to develop better treatments for progressive MS.

PHR: Project Narrative Adenosine triphosphate-binding cassette transporter subfamily A member 7 (ABCA7) significantly bears on the risk of Alzheimer's disease by a poorly understood mechanism. The present project entails making a mouse model of inducible expression of the human ABCA7. IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Adenomyosis is a common, chronic gynecologic disorder where the uterine lining (endometrium) migrates into the myometrium, causing severe menstrual cramps, bleeding, subfertility, and poor pregnancy outcomes. Its pathogenesis and pathophysiology are poorly understood and understudied, and as current medical and surgical therapies are suboptimal, new and effective therapies are needed. Herein we propose a single cell transcriptomic and spatial proteomic analysis of the three contiguous endometrial-myometrial junction compartments (endometrial functionalis, endometrial basalis, and subendometrial inner myometrium) and a transcriptome- based computational drug-repurposing strategy to identify new and re-purposed drugs through signature reversal that together are anticipated to inform mechanisms of adenomyosis pathophysiology and novel therapeutic strategies to mitigate adenomyosis-related symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) afflicts over 6.5 million Americans, imposes drastic burdens on patients’ families and society, and is the sixth leading cause of death in the US. Currently, there are no treatments that alter the course of AD. This proposal aims to investigate strategies for genetic engineering cells of the central nervous system to enable customizable control over cell functions in the face of pathology that characterizes AD, with the goal of potentiating effective, reliable therapeutics to combat AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The clinical benefits of precision medicine have been limited because genetic predictions in people with ancestries different from the overwhelmingly European- ancestry discovery cohorts are highly error prone. Among the possible factors that can cause this portability issue, gene-by-gene interaction or “epistasis”, has received much less attention as compared to differences in linkage disequilibrium or population-specific causal variants. This study will estimate the extent that gene-by-gene interactions impact phenotypic variation by testing for ancestry-specific effects on methylation in an admixed African population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding predisposition to hematological diseases, such as pediatric Acute Myeloid Leukemia (pAML) is crucial for deciphering disease pathogenesis, finding treatment targets, and selecting appropriate donors for bone marrow transplant. The interaction between germline genetic variation, viral infections, and pediatric malignancies, such as pAML, has received less attention compared to adult tumors and autoimmune diseases. Overcoming obstacles such as small sample sizes and biased cohorts, the Gabriella Miller Kids First! (GMKF) Consortium offers ample data and diverse pediatric samples to characterize germline variants as risk factors for leukemia and offers a unique opportunity to explore strategies for screening or prophylaxis to mitigate predisposition risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical inactivity is associated with worse asthma outcomes, and Black girls are disproportionately impacted by both physical inactivity and asthma morbidity. Family-based approaches to increasing physical activity are more effective and sustainable, yet no study to date addresses the unique asthma-related, culture-specific, and multi-level barriers to physical activity. This project aims to apply a theory-based approach to develop the first evidence for a dyad lifestyle physical activity intervention that is culturally tailored for urban Black girls with asthma, with the goal of improving outcomes and reducing disparities for Black girls with asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Plant secondary metabolites exert a wide variety of beneficial effects on human health. This proposal aims to explore and elucidate the systems-level effect of plant (poly)phenolic compounds on human metabolism by comprehensive quantitation of metabolite concentrations, reaction fluxes, and free energies. Harnessing the mechanisms underlying (poly)phenolic compounds’ biological activities will promote preventive and integrative health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a devastating cause of death and disability. Magnetic resonance elastography (MRE) shows that the brain softens following TBI, and research suggests that such softening is strongly influenced by damage to cerebral blood vessels. Combining these recent findings is expected to dramatically improve understanding of what the brain experiences during trauma and to thus revolutionize prevention and treatment efforts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will develop an artificial intelligence-powered tool to enhance remote video-based monitoring of medication to support proper adherence. It will use machine learning techniques to train a model to recognize fine grained pill-taking actions from a large dataset of existing medication intake videos. The model will be a valuable tool that enhances the efficiency and scalability of video directly observed treatment (VDOT), an existing video-based intervention for monitoring medication adherence across various diseases and settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Currently, 41% of Hispanics (34.2 million persons) have below basic health literacy (HL) levels, and, when combined with multiple burdens of chronic diseases such as type 2 diabetes (T2D), this negatively impacts adherence to treatment. The goal of the proposed project is to create a culturally adapted digital health app that will empower older Hispanics with T2D to improve medication adherence and manage their illness by providing tailored, accurate information on T2D, self-management options, and knowledge on prescribed medications while directly involving pharmacists providing them comprehensive medication management. The results of this project will not only lead to a sustained, powerful influence on T2D management, but will also provide a foundational framework for ubiquitous application to different diseases, languages, and cultures that can be leveraged by various healthcare providers to provide comprehensive medication management in a systematic and efficient manner.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Small and low-quality social networks are established risk factors for poor health behaviors, morbidity, and early mortality in the general population and for recognized health disparity populations, such as individuals with serious mental illnesses and racial/ethnic minority individuals. In a sample of 600 Black and Latinx individuals with serious mental illnesses assessed at baseline, 9-months, and 18-months, the proposed mixed methods study will investigate which risk and protective factors, such as social cognition, substance use, racism, stigma, incarceration, or housing are associated with social networks over time and if social networks in-turn are associated with various mental health services outcomes. Findings from this study will be used to develop culturally nuanced interventions for Black and Latinx individuals with serious mental illnesses, whose experiences with racism, stigma and discrimination make them especially vulnerable to social network deterioration and consequent poor health and mental health outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE: In the United States, Black infants experience a 3.7-times higher risk of preterm birth and 2.1-times higher risk of low birth weight than White infants, with racialized inequities widest among high-SES mothers and recent evidence suggesting comparably wide Black-White inequities in maternal mental health risks post-childbirth. Based on preliminary findings suggesting that early-life contexts may play a significant yet understudied role, the proposed research project is aimed at uncovering how social contextual stressors over the maternal pre- pregnancy life course contribute to maternal and infant health and the racialized inequities in the United States. Results from this project may improve our understanding of the biosocial pathways connecting social contex- tual stress, protective factors, and related racialized health inequities over the life course and intergeneration- ally, which may inform preventative policy and public health measures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antimicrobial resistance has become a global threat to public health with annual deaths expected to grow above 10 million by 2050. The proposed research will develop a rapid antibiotics susceptibility test using a MALDI-TOF instrument commonly available in clinical labs. By incubating bacteria with heavy water (D2O) and antibiotics, its resistance can be measured with a minimal turn-around-time, allowing prompt prescription of the most appropriate antibiotics and reducing overuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is an incurable neurodegenerative condition that causes immense human suffering and economic burden that may be especially pernicious for Latinx older adults. The proposed research will examine the feasibility and effectiveness of a new mindfulness training program designed specifically for this community, in terms of its ability to reduce the risk for AD by enhancing cognitive health and psychological well- being. This project directly addresses a major public health prerogative and holds high impact potential to yield valuable new tools for mitigating the risk of AD in communities that may be particularly vulnerable.

PHR: Project Narrative Even when severe, SLE may go into remission that can last for months or even years. If successful, this proposal may identify the first biomarker and potential therapy linked to the induction of remission in SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Successful completion of this study will greatly advance our understanding of racial-ethnic disparities in lung dose and toxicity of PM exposure, which is critical for identifying drivers of racial-ethnic disparities in PM induced health effects. This study will also stress the consideration of racial-ethnic disparity in levels and toxicity of PM2.5 exposures when tightening the National Ambient Air Quality Standards.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research project has particular relevance for women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) which is the most common endocrine disorder in reproductive-aged women worldwide. In addition to infertility and pregnancy complications, women with PCOS often present with obesity, insulin resistance and dyslipidemia that result in chronic comorbidities which include type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. Understanding how treatment with resistant starch influences cardiometabolic function and the gut microbiome in PCOS may provide a pragmatic, low-cost treatment for women with this disorder specifically in women receiving first-line therapy of oral contraceptives and reveal if modulation of the microbiome provides novel therapeutics options for PCOS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: A pulse-driven micropump for transdermal drug delivery PROJECT NARRATIVE Ambulatory infusion pumps allow millions of patients to go about their daily lives while receiving potentially lifesaving infusions of parenteral nutrition, chemotherapy, postoperative pain medication, and IV antibiotics, but they are bulky, usually connected to the patient via tubing, conspicuous, and can involve pain at the access site, which are the primary self-reported reasons that insulin users, for example, don’t adhere to their insulin regimes. To address these challenges, we developed a featherweight, pulse-driven micropump a fraction of the size of current battery-and-motor driven infusion pumps. Widespread adoption of this minimal, biology-mimicking, pulse- driven pump technology in infusion devices would dramatically shrink their footprint, lowering barriers to ambulatory infusion therapy adherence and transforming the quality of life for patients needing infusions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite advances in automation, manual material handling (MMH) tasks continue to be commonplace in the workplace. Poorly designed and controlled MMH tasks present a substantial health and safety burden in the United States (US) and worldwide. The proposed research will develop novel materially engineered triboelectric wearable and real-time based system that can be widely implemented for 1) accurately identifying both hand activity level and hand force exertions during MMH task performance and 2) predicting the worker threshold limit values (TLV) for upper extremity injury risk during repetitive MMH tasks.

PROJECT_TITLE: Skin-interfaced triboelectric sensors continuously monitor worker forceexertions to prevent workplace injuries
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The microbes in our guts, our microbiome, intimately affect our health, wellness, disease states, and even response to medicines. Unfortunately, microbiomes are difficult to measure; the easily obtained samples that emerge from the ends of our guts do not accurately represent what's inside, nor do they tell us anything about the microbiome's spatial structure across the intestinal tract. This work will develop biosensors that continuously sample free DNA, thus preserving a record of what they see on their way through the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Pulmonary arterial hypertension patients have reduced exercise capacity and quality of life, both of which improve with physical activity. We recently demonstrated that smartphone-based mobile health interventions lead to increased activity, capacity, and quality of life in adults with this condition. Given the unique needs of adolescents and their caregivers, we propose a clinical trial to test the feasibility of a mobile health intervention to increase step counts, quality of life, and other metrics in adolescents with pulmonary arterial hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Preexisting cirrhotic liver disease is strongly associated with severe COVID-19 outcome, including long COVID and death. Recently strong evidence has emerged that senescence, a physiological state of cells that is characterized by cell cycle arrest and pro inflammatory responses, is a functional feature of both cirrhotic liver disease and also is directly induced by SARS-CoV-2 in infected cells. We aim at testing if specific removal of senescent cells will alleviate severe COVID-19 symptoms in SARS-CoV-2 infected mice with preexisting NASH, or in SARS-CoV-2 infected NASH patient liver- derived organoids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell death pathways are essential to several aspects of biological pathways—from development to disease to immune responses to pathogens. The final step in the cell death pathway is plasma membrane rupture, a process which involves a protein known as Ninjurin 1 (Ninj1), which forms large pores on the membrane surface. This proposal will elucidate the mechanisms of Ninj1-mediated membrane rupture and assess its role in the immune response to pathogens using a Yersinia infection model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postoperative delirium is a debilitating and potentially preventable neurological complication in aged adults at risk for Alzheimer's disease and related dementias. While there is currently no pharmacologic agent to prevent delirium, fluvoxamine is an antidepressant that may reduce systemic and neuroinflammation involved in the pathogenesis of this costly disorder. The proposed investigation will establish biological plausibility and infrastructure required for a multisite clinical trial evaluating the repurposing of fluvoxamine to mitigate delirium risk and potential progression of long-term cognitive decline towards Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Parenting interventions that promote responsive caregiving can help remediate early disadvantages for the 43% of children under five in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) who experience compromised early childhood development (ECD), but very few programs examine their sustained effects, and the only LMIC evidence of long-term impacts stems from two very tiny and intensive pilot ECD studies in Jamaica. Our study will conduct a five-year follow-up survey of a longitudinal sample of households across 60 villages in rural Kenya that demonstrated positive impacts from a scalable and cost-effective ECD program up to two years later. Our proposed survey extension can help fill a gap regarding long-term evidence on the effectiveness of ECD programs, as well as shed light on any mechanisms explaining how such impacts were sustained or dissipated to inform the design of future ECD programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Black/African American men have the highest rate of lung cancer morbidity and mortality among all groups, with a 12% higher lung cancer incidence rate and a 15% higher lung cancer death rate than White/European men. We have identified a small genetic difference (called a single nucleotide polymorphism or “SNP”), that is rare in White/European individuals but is present in one third of Black/African American individuals. The SNP might affect the function of a protein involved in detoxification responses to tobacco smoke, and may thereby affect the lung cancer risk of smokers carrying this SNP. If true, this will be important information supporting lung cancer screening and tobacco cessation efforts in the Black/African American community.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: REHABILITATION INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO D/B/A SHIRLEY RYAN ABILITYLAB
PHR: Project Narrative: Current locomotor training programs result in limited improvements in walking ability in individuals with chronic incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI). Here, we propose to assess the contribution of the reticulospinal tract (RST), a major but largely under investigated descending motor tract in humans, to the control of lower limb muscles during locomotion and to apply a novel paradigm aiming to engage RST projections to lower limb muscles in combination with locomotor training to improve walking ability in individuals with chronic SCI. The results of this work will contribute to understand RST contributions to lower limb muscles and might contribute to developing new non-invasive techniques to improve locomotor function in individuals living with SCI.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is a lethal pediatric neuromuscular disorder resulting from loss of dystrophin protein. To restore dystrophin production, we will develop a new type of antisense oligonucleotide drugs that recognizes not only the sequence but also the structure of dystrophin's precursor messenger RNA. We expect these “3D” drugs to be more potent, more efficacious, and of fewer side effects than the existing drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Published estimates indicate that 1 in 44 children are diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) (https://www.cdc.gov/), and while many genetic causes of ASD and related neurodevelopmental disorders have now been discovered, these discoveries have not yet been translated into gene-based treatments for these disorders. This project will use a newly developed mouse strain to test the feasibility of reinstating the function of the DNMT3A gene in order to treat neurodevelopmental disorders caused by mutation of this gene. This work will establish new tools to study therapeutics for DNMT3A-associated disorders and provide fundamental insights into the feasibility of treating an entire class of neurodevelopmental disorders caused by disruption of “epigenetic writer” genes that are related to DNMT3A.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the existence of a highly potent vaccine that can be administered after exposure, rabies still kills an estimated 59,000 people each year. 99% of these deaths occur in low- and middle-income countries due to both an increased exposure risk and the difficulty accessing rabies post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), which typically requires 3 or 4 doses delivered over 1-2 weeks to be effective. To overcome healthcare accessibility challenges that disproportionally affect individuals in poor and rural communities, this project will develop a single-injection rabies vaccine for PEP in which microparticles engineered to exhibit delayed pulsatile release will mimic the antigen exposure kinetics known to be safe and effective, thereby conferring protection.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we will use artificial intelligence and natural language processing to extract social determinants of health, an area of high importance by healthcare systems who care for at risk patient populations. In contrast to prior work on SDH that focused on processing existing EHR data, we will use patient generated data in the form of a narrative. We will process this data using NLP and integrate it into the EHR as structured data that can be used to trigger clinical decision support to bring community resources to those in need.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Using Large Language Models to identify social determinants of health to enhance healthcare services and equity

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Rates of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) are high among foreign-born Mexican-origin adults. Efforts to elucidate the complex interplays between acculturative stress, pro-inflammatory biomarkers, modifiable lifestyle behaviors (e.g., diet), and NAFLD are warranted. The proposed research will identify key pathophysiological and psychosocial mechanisms that will inform an R01 proposal for a culturally appropriate NAFLD stress management risk reduction intervention for foreign-born Mexican-origin adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Survivors of childhood cancer treated with anthracycline chemotherapy or chest-directed radiation are at substantially increased risk for developing cardiomyopathy that progresses to heart failure (HF), but this risk is disproportionately higher (2.5-fold) in African American (AA) survivors than Non-Hispanic Whites (NHWs). There is an urgent need to address this disparity by formulating novel solutions that support effective cardiovascular follow-up care for AA survivors. Leveraging the world’s largest sample of AA survivors of childhood cancer with exceptional clinical and genetic (next-generation sequencing) data, we propose to address this need by: (1) developing and independently validating race-specific clinical risk prediction models for cardiomyopathy; (2) identifying and assessing novel genetic cardiomyopathy predictors; and (3) contextualizing the performance of newly developed race-specific risk algorithms through extensive generalizability and comparative analyses, critically informing future efforts to integrate race-specific cardiomyopathy prediction models into survivorship care clinical workflows.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA HLTH SCIENCES CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infants born to obese (OB) mothers are at higher risk for development of pediatric nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), with accelerated rates of obesity, diabetes and liver transplant. During OB pregnancy, maternal oxidative stress, metabolic inflammation and microbiome dysfunction affect placental function, as well as the offspring’s immune system, metabolic health and gut microbiome development. We seek to test the therapeutic potential of a dietary antioxidant that reduces inflammation in OB dams, pyrroloquinoline quinone (PQQ), to interrupt the transgenerational cycle of NAFLD in a highly translatable non-human primate, the olive baboon.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Insomnia is a leading cause of disability, and although the first-line treatment cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) is effective, many patients have residual insomnia symptoms, suggesting room for improvement. Passive body heating (PBH), which heats the body using infrared blankets, hot baths, or other heat sources, has been observed to improve sleep; yet to date, researchers have not tested whether adding PBH to CBT-I leads to greater treatment outcomes. We will therefore test the feasibility and acceptability of an integrated “mind” (CBT-I) and “body” (PBH) intervention for the treatment of insomnia, and will pilot RCT procedures using the integrated intervention in preparation for a future clinical efficacy trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Recent evidence links synaptic dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) to increased activity of the phosphatase STEP. Genetic deletion as well as pharmacological inhibition of STEP activity attenuates the cognitive impairment in an AD mouse model, validating STEP as a novel drug target for the treatment of AD. We propose to utilize an innovative fragment-based drug discovery approach to develop first-in-class potent, drug-like, and selective STEP proteolysis targeting chimeras (PROTACs), and to provide proof-of-concept for a STEP-targeted protein degradation strategy for the treatment of AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is a chronic, debilitating disease that arises from the autoimmune destruction of insulin- producing β-cells located within pancreatic islets. Pancreatic islet transplantation has shown promise as a potential T1D treatment but is severely limited in clinical settings due to instant blood-mediated inflammatory reaction and delayed re-vascularization of transplanted islets within the intrahepatic site. The objective of this project is to engineer a synthetic biomaterial platform to induce successful vascularization and engraftment of islets in the subcutaneous space, an attractive alternative transplant site with high clinical potential for cell therapies to treat T1D.

However, the role of follow-up protocols in identifying adverse events among telehealth patients is not well understood. This study will evaluate the performance of telehealth sexual and reproductive health follow- up protocols in identifying adverse events. These results will inform the development of telehealth clinical protocols that are cost-effective, patient-centered, and safe.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Enhancing access and use of evidence-based tobacco cessation treatments and eliminating tobacco-related health disparities are top national and VA health services priorities. The prevalence of tobacco use is greater among Veterans compared to non-Veterans. From 2010-2015, 29% of women and 21% of male Veterans reported current cigarette smoking. Evidence-based cessation treatments (EBCTs) such as, tobacco quitlines, behavioral counseling, and pharmacotherapy, are greatly underutilized by Veteran smokers. The role of social network influences and social support on successful smoking cessation is established. This project is innovative for evaluating social support networks as a proactive outreach approach to enhance cessation treatment utilization among Veteran smokers. We will conduct a pragmatic randomized controlled trial (RCT) within the national VHA health system to evaluate the effectiveness of a social support intervention compared with a control condition on utilization of EBCTs among a national sample of VHA-enrolled smokers.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Patients who complete prolonged exposure and cognitive processing therapy, the treatments for posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with the most empirical support, continue to express a need for mental health treatment. A therapist-assisted self-management program for patients who have completed one of these two treatments and achieved symptom improvement has the potential to meet patients' stated treatment needs, maintain or build upon their PTSD symptom reductions, increase their confidence in managing their symptoms, and reduce the number of mental health appointments that they need to attend. Further, reducing the number of mental health sessions attended by completers of these time and resource intensive psychotherapies will increase the likelihood that their implementation in regular-practice clinics will be maintained.

IC_NAME: National Center for Emerging and Zoonotic Infectious Diseases
PHR: The goal of the CDC Southeastern Center of Excellence in Vector-Borne Diseases: Gateway Program (SECVBD) is to maintain our established, comprehensive, applied, and basic research program that fully addresses the epidemiological triad to underpin our understanding of vector-borne disease transmission in the continental U.S. and territories. The SECVBD’s primary Public Health Outcomes include: (i) Diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) in accessing training opportunities in public health entomology (PHE); (ii) Higher resolution of tick vector distribution and tick-borne illness (TBI) prevalence in vector populations; (iii) Enhanced vector surveillance and control operations; (iv) Strengthened PHE Community of Practice in the Southeastern U.S. and U.S. Territories in the Caribbean; (v) Exploration of strategies for proactive vector control; (vi) New delivery modalities for novel chemical active adulticides against insecticide-resistant mosquitoes; and (vii) Socio- behavioral modifications viz. clinical TBI diagnoses, personal protective measures, and adoption of tick- encounter reduction technology.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: CDC Southeastern Center of Excellence in Vector-Borne Diseases: Gateway Program

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The success of the new anti-tuberculosis drug bedaquiline for the treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis has raised hopes for shorter and more tolerable and effective treatment regimens than previously available, though outcomes with programmatic use of some bedaquiline-based regimens are unknown. South Africa has implemented bedaquiline-based, injectable-free regimens for the treatment of drug-resistant tuberculosis, but poor treatment response, defined by positive cultures for Mycobacterium tuberculosis during treatment, and poor treatment outcomes, are a concern. In the proposed studies, we aim to determine the clinical, pharmacokinetic, and mycobacterial genotypic and phenotypic predictors of programmatic poor treatment response and outcomes in South Africa, which will allow targeted interventions among high risk individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – GREAT PLAINS CENTER FOR AGRICULTURAL HEALTH (OVERALL) The Great Plains Center for Agricultural Health is a regional center dedicated to conducting research and providing outreach to protect the health and safety of agricultural workers across our nine-state upper Midwest region. Our research will identify risk factors, develop technology, and evaluate interventions to reduce the burden of injury and disease associated with risk factors relevant to our region’s intensive row crop and livestock production activities -- vehicle vibration, roadway hazards, indoor air quality, and cognitive declines in older workers as well as persistent safety hazards. We will share lessons learned by building expertise throughout the region by developing evidence-based curricula targeting multiple audiences (e.g., youth, college, and healthcare), communicating through storytelling using traditional and innovative multi-media platforms, and building new partner networks to collaboratively influence safety and health perceptions and behaviors of farm workers.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Great Plains Center for Agricultural Health

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Attachment bonds between children and family dogs can result in positive therapeutic outcomes in both typical and clinical populations, including reduction of child stress and anxiety when the dog is present. These outcomes are likely mediated by the strength of the child-dog bond, so identifying the biological mechanisms that support the formation of strong, successful bonds is foundational to maximizing these therapeutic effects. The current proposal longitudinally examines the development of behavioral, neural, and endocrine mechanisms that underlie the stress- and anxiety-reducing effects of social bonds between children and their pet dogs.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to Veteran health because it focuses on improving how national prevention guidelines, which strongly influence preventive care practice in the VA, determine who is eligible for evidence- based prevention. Recent research shows that, for a diverse population, using multivariable prediction to estimate an intervention’s “individualized” net benefit, and to develop what are called tailored recommendations, is a promising alternative to conventional guideline recommendations. Once novel guideline-development methods are developed in this proposal (i.e., best practices for developing and examining tailored recommendations in guidelines), there is the potential for a significant advance toward more nuanced prevention guidelines that, in many cases, could avert more deaths, improve life-year gains, reduce racial disparities, and support more patient-centered shared decision making. Thus, the proposed research supports VA’s mission to advance scientific knowledge to help Veterans live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Veterans with Spinal Cord Injury or Disorders (SCI/D) have complex medical and caretaker treatment needs that put them at elevated risk for negative medical and mental health outcomes, including mortality. Veterans with SCI/D are also at higher risk for COVID-19 and disproportionately experience hardship from disrupted and deferred health services during the COVID-19 pandemic including loss of caregiver support and ancillary but essential services such as wheelchair repair and transportation. Many in this population have limited mobility so existing social isolation was exacerbated. The proposed project aims to identify the impact of the pandemic on the health service delivery, access to essential resources, physical and mental health consequences, and death among Veterans with SCI/D. The goal of this research is to produce knowledge that can be used by the SCI/D National Program Office to create resources to improve health services for Veterans with SCI/D during future emergency events and ultimately improve the health and mortality risk of this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Hospital-acquired pneumonia is predictive of enhanced disability and mortality after SCI; whereas pneumonia qualifies as a potent and targetable outcome-modifying factor, orthodox antibiotic treatments were ineffective to prevent infections or protect outcome at risk. By selecting a mechanistic approach supported by recent data from our lab, we will focus on one goal: Reducing infection susceptibility by restoring immune function. If successful, data from this grant proposal will inform the development of more effective non-antibiotic treatments for immune compromised SCI patients

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we will conduct genome-wide discovery efforts to identify variants and genes that contribute to risk of prostate cancer and aggressive disease in men of European, African, Asian and Latino ancestry. IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Trans women are highly impacted by HIV in Nepal with an HIV prevalence 22 times greater than in the general population. We found that only half of trans women have been tested for HIV recently and HIV care engagement is low relative to national targets. Building on recently-completed NIH funded research, we propose to pilot a multi-level intersectional stigma reduction intervention to increase HIV testing and engagement in HIV care among trans women in Nepal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although a rich epidemiological literature has demonstrated a high comorbidity between asthma, the most common respiratory disease worldwide, and attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), the most common behavioral disorder among children, with reports of significant increases in diagnoses in recent years, no studies have interrogated the potential molecular pathobiology underlying the mutual excess risk between asthma and ADHD. This proposal aims to use integrative techniques by combining genetic and metabolomic data to characterize common and distinct mechanisms and pathways of dysregulated metabolism in the presence of comorbid asthma and ADHD and to develop multiomic profiles which can assist in predicting higher risk of ADHD among asthmatic children. The findings from this study will be instrumental in understanding the molecular underpinnings of two highly prevalent public health concerns, and this study will be the first of its kind to interrogate the molecular intersections between asthma and ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing and balance disorders affect millions of people worldwide, yet the underlying damage patterns in the ear are not understood well for many inner ear-related clinical problems. This project will develop a large human temporal bone collection as a resource for the scientific community to investigate the inner ear correlates of hearing and balance problems in a diverse population. The project will also refine methods for rapid processing of newly obtained temporal bones and create a multi-platform imaging and analysis pipeline for maximization of the information obtained from each specimen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Interdisciplinary Health Equity Research Center Public Health Relevance Summary Because of the diversity of their faculty and students, and places of trust in the community, HBCUs such as Delaware State University, are strategically poised to make important scientific contributions addressing the serious problem of racial/ethnic health disparities. Support from the RCMI program to establish the Interdisciplinary Health Equity Research Center at DSU will build a capacity for biomedical, behavioral and social research targeting understanding and reducing health disparities. The Center will support early stage investigators to reach the level of research capability competitive for external funding and necessary to pursue discovery science that will translate into improvements in the health status of minority individuals and communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative It has been proposed that differences in sensory responsiveness may emerge early in life from altered brain states and impact a child's ability to engage with their environment, thereby producing cascading effects on language acquisition in children affected by autism. The Sensory Project in Infant/Toddler Siblings of Children with Autism (Project SPIS) represents a comprehensive test of this “cascading effects” framework in infants at increased familial likelihood for a future diagnosis of autism and language disorder and infants at relatively lower, general population-level likelihood of these conditions. This innovative and interdisciplinary line of research is expected to facilitate earlier identification of language impairments and point towards novel targets of “preventative” interventions, thereby improving the long-term outcomes of children with, or at elevated likelihood of, autism and language disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune Regulator (Aire) has been demonstrated to be essential for central tolerance in the thymus by inducing tissue specific antigen expression in medullary thymic epithelial cells (mTECs), but little is known about the role of extrathymic Aire in peripheral immune tolerance. Since extrathymic Aire-expressing cells (eTACs) are transcriptionally and functionally similar to both mTECs and migratory dendritic cells, they could play a unique role in the maintenance of immune homeostasis as distinct populations of tolerogenic antigen presenting cells. Studying the biology of eTACs and peripheral Aire will help further elucidate the function of Aire and define basic peripheral tolerance mechanisms, which may have significance for a range of clinical applications from autoimmunity to tumor immunity to maternal-fetal tolerance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative. Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a particularly aggressive breast cancer subtype, disproportionately seen in African Americans, and in contrast to other breast cancer subtypes, there are no current targeted therapies. One goal of this research is to develop non-antibody protein-based targeted immunotherapeutics that are personalized for virtually any TNBC patient, and trigger immune cells to seek out and destroy TNBC cells. Protein immunotherapeutics are designed for long in vivo lifetime, which rival monoclonal antibodies, and use existing serum antibodies to kill TNBC cells. A second goal of this research is to develop a low-cost paper based diagnostic platform that will be used to rapidly identify which protein immunotherapeutics are best suited to serve as a combination therapy for a given TNBC patient, and monitor the therapeutic efficacy of the combination over the course of treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The epidemic of screen- or incidentally detected indeterminate pulmonary nodules (IPNs) presents a substantial public health problem and is associated health care costs of $28 billion annually as well as increased burden on patients in the form of anxiety, morbidity from diagnostic procedures, excessive radiation, and death from missed lung cancer. Clinical predictive models represent an opportunity to reduce this public health burden by noninvasively estimating the probability of malignancy and segregating IPNs into clinically actionable risk groups, thereby reducing the risk of mismanaging IPNs. By leveraging machine learning/deep learning techniques to analyze data that are multi-modal and longitudinal, this project works towards a future where predictive models are used at scale to improve patient outcomes by aiding earlier diagnosis of malignancy and reducing the diagnostic burden of benign IPNs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a feared complication of critical illness that can frequently lead to prolonged mechanical ventilation and death. PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Makrogiannis, Sokratis Narrative Age-related and metabolic diseases, such as type-2 diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, sarcopenia, osteoporosis, and osteoarthritis, have become a worldwide epidemic, and affect the quality of life of millions. This project will contribute novel and non-invasive medical image analysis techniques for studying the human body composition and its changes with increasing age, to achieve timely diagnosis of these pathologies. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Health disparities among underserved populations are multifactorial, and it is now recognized that disparities in sleep health in addition to social determinants of health are important contributors. The results of this study will further substantiate key drivers of sleep disparities for racial/ethnic minorities to reduce health disparities and advance health equities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative  Anxiety disorders are the most common mental illness in the United States and begin to emerge during adolescence. Experiences of childhood trauma are a potent risk factor for anxiety disorders in youth, however, the mechanisms supporting this link are poorly characterized. This study will investigate the impact of childhood trauma on the biochemical mechanisms maintaining cognitive control in the presence of threat, and may aid in identifying novel therapeutic targets and improving care for anxious youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The present study will assess the impact of a history of alcohol dependence on the onset and severity of behavioral and neuropathological deficits associated with Alzheimer's disease. This project will also assess single-cell whole-brain connectivity and whole-brain Aβ deposits in transgenic mice that model Alzheimer's after a history of alcohol dependence and unveil the neuronal networks that are responsible for cognitive and emotional changes that are associated with Alzheimer's disease. This project will further identify whether Memantine is an effective treatment for deficits associated with Alzheimer's disease that are exacerbated by alcohol dependence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: During abstinence, recovering alcoholics experience severe and chronic insomnia that leads them to drink again because alcohol acts as a sedative and hypnotic. The cause of the insomnia is not known but may represent an imbalance of brain neurons regulating waking and sleep. We will use deep-brain imaging and pharmacogenetics to identify and correct the activity of brain neurons in an animal model of alcohol dependence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Tuberculosis (TB) is major causes of disease and death in the world, especially in India, and occurs more frequently among persons living with HIV. People with unhealthy alcohol use may have problems with managing their TB or HIV. We are testing whether an intervention that focuses on alcohol reduction at the same time people with TB and HIV are getting treatment for TB can improve their clinical outcomes and overall health.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We know that exposure to excess stress can produce long-term effects that influence health and increase risk of developing common age-related disorders. Our goal is to better understand the phenomenon of biological embedding of stress – the process by which stress “gets under our skin” to produce permanent changes in biology. We have advanced the hypothesis that the effects of stress may extend all the way down to the level of stem/progenitor cells – the cells that continually replenish our tissues and organ systems. Our project will test this hypothesis in stem/pro- genitor cells obtained from child tissues (umbilical cord blood and cord tissue) at the time of birth, and measure key cellular processes in these stem/progenitor cells that relate to genomic integrity and bioenergetic function (telomere and mitochondrial biology systems) using a unique, translational approach (in vitro to in vivo physiology) in a novel stem cell culture system from these human newborn tissue samples. We expect our study findings to suggest avenues to better optimize long-term health and well-being.

PROJECT_TITLE: Stress and Human Stem/Progenitor Cells: Biobehavioral Mechanisms
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Biobehavioral Mechanisms of Emotion, Stress and Health Study Section[MESH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Survival Motor Neuron protein (SMN) deficiencies cause Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA), the most common genetic cause of infant and toddler mortality. Although therapies have been developed to restore SMN proteins in patients, the function of SMN that critically compromises motor neurons has not been identified. Our recently published and preliminary data suggest a novel and fundamental molecular mechanism for SMN’s activities: the formation of biomolecular condensates (BMCs) that potentially explain the disease and could be druggable.
